006import squidpony.squidgrid.zone.MutableZone;

009import java.io.Serializable;
010import java.util.*;

012import static squidpony.squidmath.CrossHash.Water.*;

014/**
015 * Region encoding of on/off information about areas using bitsets; uncompressed (fatty), but fast (greased lightning).
016 * This can handle any size of 2D data, and is not strictly limited to 256x256 as CoordPacker is. It stores several long
017 * arrays and uses each bit in one of those numbers to represent a single point, though sometimes this does waste bits
018 * if the height of the area this encodes is not a multiple of 64 (if you store a 80x64 map, this uses 80 longs; if you
019 * store an 80x65 map, this uses 160 longs, 80 for the first 64 rows and 80 more to store the next row). It's much
020 * faster than CoordPacker at certain operations (anything that expands or retracts an area, including
021 * {@link #expand()}), {@link #retract()}), {@link #fringe()}), {@link #surface()}, and {@link #flood(GreasedRegion)},
022 * and slightly faster on others, like {@link #and(GreasedRegion)} (called intersectPacked() in CoordPacker) and
023 * {@link #or(GreasedRegion)} (called unionPacked() in CoordPacker).
024 * <br>
025 * Each GreasedRegion is mutable, and instance methods typically modify that instance and return it for chaining. There
026 * are exceptions, usually where multiple GreasedRegion values are returned and the instance is not modified.
027 * <br>
028 * Typical usage involves constructing a GreasedRegion from some input data, like a char[][] for a map or a double[][]
029 * from DijkstraMap, and modifying it spatially with expand(), retract(), flood(), etc. It's common to mix in data from
030 * other GreasedRegions with and() (which gets the intersection of two GreasedRegions and stores it in one), or() (which
031 * is like and() but for the union), xor() (like and() but for exclusive or, finding only cells that are on in exactly
032 * one of the two GreasedRegions), and andNot() (which can be considered the "subtract another region from me" method).
033 * There are 8-way (Chebyshev distance) variants on all of the spatial methods, and methods without "8way" in the name
034 * are either 4-way (Manhattan distance) or not affected by distance measurement. Once you have a GreasedRegion, you may
035 * want to:
036 * <ul>
037 *     <li>get a single random point from it (use {@link #singleRandom(IRNG)}),</li>
038 *     <li>get several random points from it with random sampling (use {@link #randomPortion(IRNG, int)}),</li>
039 *     <li>mutate the current GreasedRegion to keep random points from it with random sampling (use {@link #randomRegion(IRNG, int)}),</li>
040 *     <li>get random points that are likely to be separated (use {@link #mixedRandomSeparated(double, int, long)} with
041 *     a random long for the last parameter, or {@link #quasiRandomSeparated(double)} if you don't want a random seed),</li>
042 *     <li>do what any of the above "separated" methods can do, but mutate the current GreasedRegion (use
043 *     {@link #mixedRandomRegion(double, int, long)} or {@link #quasiRandomRegion(double, int)}),</li>
044 *     <li>get all points from it (use {@link #asCoords()} to get a Coord array, or produce a 2D array of the contents
045 *     with {@link #decode()} or {@link #toChars(char, char)}),</li>
046 *     <li>use it to modify other 2D data, such as with {@link #mask(char[][], char)},
047 *     {@link #inverseMask(char[][], char)}, {@link #writeDoubles(double[][], double)}, or
048 *     {@link #writeIntsInto(int[][], int)}, along with variations on those.</li>
049 * </ul>
050 * <br>
051 * You may also want to produce some 2D data from one or more GreasedRegions, as with {@link #sum(GreasedRegion...)} or
052 * {@link #toChars()}. The most effective techniques regarding GreasedRegion involve multiple methods, like getting a
053 * few random points from an existing GreasedRegion representing floor tiles in a dungeon with
054 * {@link #randomRegion(IRNG, int)}, then finding a random expansion of those initial points with
055 * {@link #spill(GreasedRegion, int, IRNG)}, giving the original GreasedRegion of floor tiles as the first argument.
056 * This could be used to position puddles of water or toxic waste in a dungeon level, while still keeping the starting
057 * points and finished points within the boundaries of valid (floor) cells. If you wanted to place something like mold
058 * that can be on floors or on cells immediately adjacent to floors (like walls), you could call {@link #expand()} on
059 * the floor tiles before calling spill, allowing the spill to spread onto non-floor cells that are next to floors.
060 * <br>
061 * For efficiency, you can place one GreasedRegion into another (typically a temporary value that is no longer needed
062 * and can be recycled) using {@link #remake(GreasedRegion)}, or give the information that would normally be used to
063 * construct a fresh GreasedRegion to an existing one of the same dimensions with {@link #refill(boolean[][])} or any
064 * of the overloads of refill(). These re-methods don't do as much work as a constructor does if the width and height
065 * of their argument are identical to their current width and height, and don't create more garbage for the GC.
066 * <br>
067 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 6/24/2016.
068 */
069@Beta
070public class GreasedRegion extends Zone.Skeleton implements Collection<Coord>, Serializable, MutableZone {
071    private static final long serialVersionUID = 0;
072    private static final SobolQRNG sobol = new SobolQRNG(2);
073
074    public long[] data;
075    public int height;
076    public int width;
077    private int ySections;
078    private long yEndMask;
079    private boolean tallied;
080    private int ct;
081    private int[] counts;
082
083    private void tally()
084    {
085        ct = 0;
086        for (int i = 0, tmp; i < counts.length; i++) {
087            tmp = Long.bitCount(data[i]);
088            counts[i] = tmp == 0 ? 0 : (ct += tmp);
089        }
090        tallied = true;
091    }
092
093    /**
094     * Constructs an empty 64x64 GreasedRegion.
095     * GreasedRegions are mutable, so you can add to this with insert() or insertSeveral(), among others.
096     */
097    public GreasedRegion()
098    {
099        width = 64;
100        height = 64;
101        ySections = 1;
102        yEndMask = -1L;
103        data = new long[64];
104        counts = new int[64];
105        ct = 0;
106        tallied = true;
107    }
108
109    /**
110     * Constructs a GreasedRegion with the given rectangular boolean array, with width of bits.length and height of
111     * bits[0].length, any value of true considered "on", and any value of false considered "off."
112     * @param bits a rectangular 2D boolean array where true is on and false is off
113     */
114    public GreasedRegion(final boolean[][] bits)
115    {
116        width = bits.length;
117        height = bits[0].length;
118        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
119        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
120        data = new long[width * ySections];
121        for (int x = 0, xs = 0; x < width; x++, xs += ySections) {
122            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
123                if(bits[x][y]) data[xs + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
124            }
125        }
126        counts = new int[width * ySections];
127        tallied = false;
128    }
129    /**
130     * Reassigns this GreasedRegion with the given rectangular boolean array, reusing the current data storage (without
131     * extra allocations) if this.width == map.length and this.height == map[0].length. The current values stored in
132     * this are always cleared, then any value of true in map is considered "on", and any value of false in map is
133     * considered "off."
134     * @param map a rectangular 2D boolean array where true is on and false is off
135     * @return this for chaining
136     */
137    public GreasedRegion refill(final boolean[][] map) {
138        if (map != null && map.length > 0 && width == map.length && height == map[0].length) {
139            Arrays.fill(data, 0L);
140            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
141                for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
142                    data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= (map[x][y] ? 1L : 0L) << (y & 63);
143                }
144            }
145            tallied = false;
146            return this;
147        } else {
148            width = (map == null) ? 0 : map.length;
149            height = (map == null || map.length <= 0) ? 0 : map[0].length;
150            ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
151            yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
152            data = new long[width * ySections];
153            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
154                for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
155                    if(map[x][y]) data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
156                }
157            }
158            counts = new int[width * ySections];
159            tallied = false;
160            return this;
161        }
162    }
163
164    /**
165     * Constructs a GreasedRegion with the given rectangular char array, with width of map.length and height of
166     * map[0].length, any value that equals yes is considered "on", and any other value considered "off."
167     * @param map a rectangular 2D char array where yes is on and everything else is off
168     * @param yes which char to encode as "on"
169     */
170    public GreasedRegion(final char[][] map, final char yes)
171    {
172        width = map.length;
173        height = map[0].length;
174        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
175        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
176        data = new long[width * ySections];
177        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
178            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
179                if(map[x][y] == yes) data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
180            }
181        }
182        counts = new int[width * ySections];
183        tallied = false;
184    }
185    /**

190     * @param yes which char to encode as "on"
191     * @return this for chaining
192     */

220    /**
221     * Constructs a GreasedRegion with the given rectangular char array, with width of map.length and height of
222     * map[0].length, any value that equals yes is considered "on", and any other value considered "off."
223     * @param map a rectangular 2D char array where yes is on and everything else is off
224     * @param yes which char to encode as "on"
225     */
226    public GreasedRegion(final char[][] map, final char[] yes)
227    {
228        width = map.length;
229        height = map[0].length;
230        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
231        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
232        data = new long[width * ySections];
233        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
234            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
235                for(char e : yes)
236                {
237                    if(map[x][y] == e) {
238                        data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
239                        break;
240                    }
241                }
242            }
243        }
244        counts = new int[width * ySections];
245        tallied = false;
246    }
247    /**
248     * Reassigns this GreasedRegion with the given rectangular char array, reusing the current data storage (without
249     * extra allocations) if this.width == map.length and this.height == map[0].length. The current values stored in
250     * this are always cleared, then any value that equals yes is considered "on", and any other value considered "off."
251     * @param map a rectangular 2D char array where yes is on and everything else is off
252     * @param yes which char to encode as "on"
253     * @return this for chaining
254     */
255    public GreasedRegion refill(final char[][] map, final char[] yes) {
256        if (map != null && map.length > 0 && width == map.length && height == map[0].length) {
257            Arrays.fill(data, 0L);
258            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
259                for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
260                    for(char e : yes)
261                    {
262                        if(map[x][y] == e) {
263                            data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
264                            break;
265                        }
266                    }
267                }
268            }
269            tallied = false;
270            return this;
271        } else {
272            width = (map == null) ? 0 : map.length;
273            height = (map == null || map.length <= 0) ? 0 : map[0].length;
274            ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
275            yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
276            data = new long[width * ySections];
277            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
278                for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
279                    for(char e : yes)
280                    {
281                        if(map[x][y] == e) {
282                            data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
283                            break;
284                        }
285                    }
286                }
287            }
288            counts = new int[width * ySections];
289            tallied = false;
290            return this;
291        }
292    }

294    /**
295     * Weird constructor that takes a String array, _as it would be printed_, so each String is a row and indexing would
296     * be done with y, x instead of the normal x, y.
297     * @param map String array (as printed, not the normal storage) where each String is a row
298     * @param yes the char to consider "on" in the GreasedRegion
299     */
300    public GreasedRegion(final String[] map, final char yes)
301    {
302        height = map.length;
303        width = map[0].length();
304        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
305        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
306        data = new long[width * ySections];
307        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
308            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
309                if(map[y].charAt(x) == yes) data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
310            }
311        }
312        counts = new int[width * ySections];
313        tallied = false;
314    }
315

317     * Weird refill method that takes a String array, _as it would be printed_, so each String is a row and indexing
318     * would be done with y, x instead of the normal x, y.
319     * @param map String array (as printed, not the normal storage) where each String is a row
320     * @param yes the char to consider "on" in the GreasedRegion
321     * @return this for chaining
322     */
323    public GreasedRegion refill(final String[] map, final char yes) {
324        if (map != null && map.length > 0 && height == map.length && width == map[0].length()) {
325            Arrays.fill(data, 0L);
326            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
327                for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
328                    data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= ((map[y].charAt(x) == yes) ? 1L : 0L) << (y & 63);
329                }
330            }
331            tallied = false;
332            return this;
333        } else {
334            height = (map == null) ? 0 : map.length;
335            width = (map == null || map.length <= 0) ? 0 : map[0].length();
336            ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
337            yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
338            data = new long[width * ySections];
339            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
340                for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
341                    if(map[y].charAt(y) == yes) data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
342                }
343            }
344            counts = new int[width * ySections];
345            tallied = false;
346            return this;
347        }
348    }

405    /**
406     * Constructs this GreasedRegion using an int[][], treating cells as on if they are greater than or equal to lower
407     * and less than upper, or off otherwise.
408     * @param map an int[][] that should have some ints between lower and upper
409     * @param lower lower bound, inclusive; all on cells will have values in map that are at least equal to lower
410     * @param upper upper bound, exclusive; all on cells will have values in map that are less than upper
411     */
412    public GreasedRegion(final int[][] map, final int lower, final int upper)
413    {
414        width = map.length;
415        height = map[0].length;
416        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
417        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
418        data = new long[width * ySections];
419        int[] column;
420        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
421            column = map[x];
422            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
423                if(column[y] >= lower && column[y] < upper) data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
424            }
425        }
426        counts = new int[width * ySections];
427        tallied = false;
428    }

431     * Reassigns this GreasedRegion with the given rectangular int array, reusing the current data storage (without
432     * extra allocations) if this.width == map.length and this.height == map[0].length. The current values stored in

435     * @param map a rectangular 2D int array that should have some values between lower and upper

438     * @return this for chaining
439     */

448                }
449            }

456            yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));

496    /**
497     * Reassigns this GreasedRegion with the given rectangular byte array, reusing the current data storage (without
498     * extra allocations) if this.width == map.length and this.height == map[0].length. The current values stored in
499     * this are always cleared, then cells are treated as on if they are greater than or equal to lower and less than
500     * upper, or off otherwise.
501     * @param map a rectangular 2D byte array that should have some values between lower and upper
502     * @param lower lower bound, inclusive; all on cells will have values in map that are at least equal to lower
503     * @param upper upper bound, exclusive; all on cells will have values in map that are less than upper
504     * @return this for chaining
505     */
506    public GreasedRegion refill(final byte[][] map, final int lower, final int upper) {
507        if (map != null && map.length > 0 && width == map.length && height == map[0].length) {
508            Arrays.fill(data, 0L);
509            byte[] column;
510            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
511                column = map[x];
512                for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
513                    data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= ((column[y] >= lower && column[y] < upper) ? 1L : 0L) << (y & 63);
514                }
515            }
516            tallied = false;
517            return this;
518        } else {
519            width = (map == null) ? 0 : map.length;
520            height = (map == null || map.length <= 0) ? 0 : map[0].length;
521            ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
522            yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
523            data = new long[width * ySections];
524            byte[] column;
525            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
526                column = map[x];
527                for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
528                    if(column[y] >= lower && column[y] < upper) data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
529                }
530            }
531            counts = new int[width * ySections];
532            tallied = false;
533            return this;
534        }
535    }

538    /**
539     * Constructs this GreasedRegion using a short[][], treating cells as on if they are greater than or equal to lower
540     * and less than upper, or off otherwise.
541     * @param map a short[][] that should have some shorts between lower and upper
542     * @param lower lower bound, inclusive; all on cells will have values in map that are at least equal to lower
543     * @param upper upper bound, exclusive; all on cells will have values in map that are less than upper
544     */
545    public GreasedRegion(final short[][] map, final int lower, final int upper)
546    {
547        width = map.length;
548        height = map[0].length;
549        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
550        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
551        data = new long[width * ySections];
552        short[] column;
553        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
554            column = map[x];
555            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
556                if(column[y] >= lower && column[y] < upper) data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
557            }
558        }
559        counts = new int[width * ySections];
560        tallied = false;
561    }

563    /**
564     * Reassigns this GreasedRegion with the given rectangular short array, reusing the current data storage (without
565     * extra allocations) if this.width == map.length and this.height == map[0].length. The current values stored in
566     * this are always cleared, then cells are treated as on if they are greater than or equal to lower and less than
567     * upper, or off otherwise.
568     * @param map a rectangular 2D short array that should have some values between lower and upper
569     * @param lower lower bound, inclusive; all on cells will have values in map that are at least equal to lower
570     * @param upper upper bound, exclusive; all on cells will have values in map that are less than upper
571     * @return this for chaining
572     */
573    public GreasedRegion refill(final short[][] map, final int lower, final int upper) {
574        if (map != null && map.length > 0 && width == map.length && height == map[0].length) {
575            Arrays.fill(data, 0L);
576            short[] column;
577            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
578                column = map[x];
579                for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
580                    data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= ((column[y] >= lower && column[y] < upper) ? 1L : 0L) << (y & 63);
581                }
582            }
583            tallied = false;
584            return this;
585        } else {
586            width = (map == null) ? 0 : map.length;
587            height = (map == null || map.length <= 0) ? 0 : map[0].length;
588            ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
589            yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
590            data = new long[width * ySections];
591            short[] column;
592            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
593                column = map[x];
594                for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
595                    if(column[y] >= lower && column[y] < upper) data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
596                }
597            }
598            counts = new int[width * ySections];
599            tallied = false;
600            return this;
601        }
602    }
603    /**
604     * Constructs this GreasedRegion using a double[][] (typically one generated by
605     * {@link squidpony.squidai.DijkstraMap}) that only stores two relevant states:  an "on" state for values less than
606     * or equal to upperBound (inclusive), and an "off" state for anything else.
607     * @param map a double[][] that probably relates in some way to DijkstraMap.
608     * @param upperBound upper inclusive; any double greater than this will be off, any others will be on
609     */
610    public GreasedRegion(final double[][] map, final double upperBound)
611    {
612        width = map.length;
613        height = map[0].length;
614        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
615        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
616        data = new long[width * ySections];
617        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
618            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
619                if(map[x][y] <= upperBound)
620                    data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
621            }
622        }
623        counts = new int[width * ySections];
624        tallied = false;
625    }
626    /**
627     * Reassigns this GreasedRegion with the given rectangular double array, reusing the current data storage (without
628     * extra allocations) if this.width == map.length and this.height == map[0].length. The current values stored in
629     * this are always cleared, then cells are treated as on if they are less than or equal to upperBound, or off
630     * otherwise.
631     * @param map a rectangular 2D double array that should usually have some values less than or equal to upperBound
632     * @param upperBound upper bound, inclusive; all on cells will have values in map that are less than or equal to this
633     * @return this for chaining
634     */
635    public GreasedRegion refill(final double[][] map, final double upperBound) {
636        if (map != null && map.length > 0 && width == map.length && height == map[0].length) {
637            Arrays.fill(data, 0L);
638            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
639                for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
640                    if(map[x][y] <= upperBound) data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
641                }
642            }
643            tallied = false;
644            return this;
645        } else {
646            width = (map == null) ? 0 : map.length;
647            height = (map == null || map.length <= 0) ? 0 : map[0].length;
648            ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
649            yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
650            data = new long[width * ySections];
651            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
652                for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
653                    if(map[x][y] <= upperBound) data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
654                }
655            }
656            counts = new int[width * ySections];
657            tallied = false;
658            return this;
659        }
660    }

662    /**
663     * Constructs this GreasedRegion using a double[][] (typically one generated by
664     * {@link squidpony.squidai.DijkstraMap}) that only stores two relevant states:  an "on" state for values between
665     * lowerBound (inclusive) and upperBound (exclusive), and an "off" state for anything else.
666     * @param map a double[][] that probably relates in some way to DijkstraMap.
667     * @param lowerBound lower inclusive; any double lower than this will be off, any equal to or greater than this,
668     *                   but less than upper, will be on
669     * @param upperBound upper exclusive; any double greater than or equal to this this will be off, any doubles both
670     *                   less than this and equal to or greater than lower will be on
671     */
672    public GreasedRegion(final double[][] map, final double lowerBound, final double upperBound)
673    {
674        width = map.length;
675        height = map[0].length;
676        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
677        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
678        data = new long[width * ySections];
679        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
680            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
681                if(map[x][y] >= lowerBound && map[x][y] < upperBound)
682                    data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
683            }
684        }
685        counts = new int[width * ySections];
686        tallied = false;
687    }
688    /**
689     * Reassigns this GreasedRegion with the given rectangular double array, reusing the current data storage (without
690     * extra allocations) if this.width == map.length and this.height == map[0].length. The current values stored in
691     * this are always cleared, then cells are treated as on if they are greater than or equal to lower and less than
692     * upper, or off otherwise.
693     * @param map a rectangular 2D double array that should have some values between lower and upper
694     * @param lower lower bound, inclusive; all on cells will have values in map that are at least equal to lower
695     * @param upper upper bound, exclusive; all on cells will have values in map that are less than upper
696     * @return this for chaining
697     */
698    public GreasedRegion refill(final double[][] map, final double lower, final double upper) {
699        if (map != null && map.length > 0 && width == map.length && height == map[0].length) {
700            Arrays.fill(data, 0L);
701            double[] column;
702            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
703                column = map[x];
704                for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
705                    data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= ((column[y] >= lower && column[y] < upper) ? 1L : 0L) << (y & 63);
706                }
707            }
708            tallied = false;
709            return this;
710        } else {
711            width = (map == null) ? 0 : map.length;
712            height = (map == null || map.length <= 0) ? 0 : map[0].length;
713            ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
714            yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
715            data = new long[width * ySections];
716            double[] column;
717            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
718                column = map[x];
719                for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
720                    if(column[y] >= lower && column[y] < upper) data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
721                }
722            }
723            counts = new int[width * ySections];
724            tallied = false;
725            return this;
726        }

729    /**
730     * Constructs this GreasedRegion using a double[][] (this was made for use inside
731     * {@link squidpony.squidgrid.BevelFOV}) that only stores two relevant states:  an "on" state for values between
732     * lowerBound (inclusive) and upperBound (exclusive), and an "off" state for anything else. This variant scales the
733     * input so each "on" position in map produces a 2x2 on area if scale is 2, a 3x3 area if scale is 3, and so on.
734     * @param map a double[][] that may relate in some way to BevelFOV
735     * @param lowerBound lower inclusive; any double lower than this will be off, any equal to or greater than this,
736     *                   but less than upper, will be on
737     * @param upperBound upper exclusive; any double greater than or equal to this this will be off, any doubles both
738     *                   less than this and equal to or greater than lower will be on
739     * @param scale      the size of the square of cells in this that each "on" value in map will correspond to
740     */
741    public GreasedRegion(final double[][] map, final double lowerBound, final double upperBound, int scale)
742    {
743        scale = Math.min(63, Math.max(1, scale));
744        int baseWidth = map.length, baseHeight = map[0].length;
745        width =  baseWidth * scale;
746        height = baseHeight * scale;
747        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
748        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
749        data = new long[width * ySections];
750        long shape = (1L << scale) - 1L, leftover;
751        for (int bx = 0, x = 0; bx < baseWidth; bx++, x += scale) {
752            for (int by = 0, y = 0; by < baseHeight; by++, y += scale) {
753                if(map[bx][by] >= lowerBound && map[bx][by] < upperBound) {
754                    for (int i = 0; i < scale; i++) {
755                        data[(x + i) * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= shape << (y & 63);
756                        if((leftover = (y + scale - 1 & 63) + 1) < (y & 63) + 1 && (y + leftover >> 6) < ySections)
757                        {
758                            data[(x + i) * ySections + (y >> 6) + 1] |= (1L << leftover) - 1L;
759                        }
760                    }
761                }
762            }
763        }
764        counts = new int[width * ySections];
765        tallied = false;
766    }
767    /**
768     * Reassigns this GreasedRegion with the given rectangular double array, reusing the current data storage (without
769     * extra allocations) if {@code this.width == map.length * scale && this.height == map[0].length * scale}. The
770     * current values stored in this are always cleared, then cells are treated as on if they are greater than or equal
771     * to lower and less than upper, or off otherwise, before considering scaling. This variant scales the input so each
772     * "on" position in map produces a 2x2 on area if scale is 2, a 3x3 area if scale is 3, and so on.
773     * @param map a double[][] that may relate in some way to BevelFOV
774     * @param lowerBound lower inclusive; any double lower than this will be off, any equal to or greater than this,
775     *                   but less than upper, will be on
776     * @param upperBound upper exclusive; any double greater than or equal to this this will be off, any doubles both
777     *                   less than this and equal to or greater than lower will be on
778     * @param scale      the size of the square of cells in this that each "on" value in map will correspond to
779     * @return this for chaining
780     */
781    public GreasedRegion refill(final double[][] map, final double lowerBound, final double upperBound, int scale) {
782        scale = Math.min(63, Math.max(1, scale));
783        if (map != null && map.length > 0 && width == map.length * scale && height == map[0].length * scale) {
784            Arrays.fill(data, 0L);
785            double[] column;
786            int baseWidth = map.length, baseHeight = map[0].length;
787            long shape = (1L << scale) - 1L, leftover;
788            for (int bx = 0, x = 0; bx < baseWidth; bx++, x += scale) {
789                column = map[bx];
790                for (int by = 0, y = 0; by < baseHeight; by++, y += scale) {
791                    if(column[by] >= lowerBound && column[by] < upperBound) {
792                        for (int i = 0; i < scale; i++) {
793                            data[(x + i) * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= shape << (y & 63);
794                            if((leftover = (y + scale - 1 & 63) + 1) < (y & 63) + 1 && (y + leftover >> 6) < ySections)
795                            {
796                                data[(x + i) * ySections + (y >> 6) + 1] |= (1L << leftover) - 1L;
797                            }
798                        }
799                    }
800                }
801            }
802            tallied = false;
803            return this;
804        } else {
805            int baseWidth = (map == null) ? 0 : map.length,
806                    baseHeight = (map == null || map.length <= 0) ? 0 : map[0].length;
807            width =  baseWidth * scale;
808            height = baseHeight * scale;
809            ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
810            yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
811            data = new long[width * ySections];
812            long shape = (1L << scale) - 1L, leftover;
813            for (int bx = 0, x = 0; bx < baseWidth; bx++, x += scale) {
814                for (int by = 0, y = 0; by < baseHeight; by++, y += scale) {
815                    if(map[bx][by] >= lowerBound && map[bx][by] < upperBound) {
816                        for (int i = 0; i < scale; i++) {
817                            data[(x + i) * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= shape << (y & 63);
818                            if((leftover = (y + scale - 1 & 63)) < y && y < height - leftover)
819                            {
820                                data[(x + i) * ySections + (y >> 6) + 1] |= (1L << leftover) - 1L;
821                            }
822                        }
823                    }
824                }
825            }
826            counts = new int[width * ySections];
827            tallied = false;
828            return this;
829        }
830    }
831
832    /**
833     * Constructs a GreasedRegion with the given 1D boolean array, with the given width and height, where an [x][y]
834     * position is obtained from bits given an index n with x = n / height, y = n % height, any value of true
835     * considered "on", and any value of false considered "off."
836     * @param bits a 1D boolean array where true is on and false is off
837     * @param width the width of the desired GreasedRegion; width * height should equal bits.length
838     * @param height the height of the desired GreasedRegion; width * height should equal bits.length
839     */
840    public GreasedRegion(final boolean[] bits, final int width, final int height)
841    {
842        this.width = width;
843        this.height = height;
844        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
845        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
846        data = new long[width * ySections];
847        for (int a = 0, x = 0, y = 0; a < bits.length; a++, x = a / height, y = a % height) {
848            if(bits[a]) data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
849        }
850        counts = new int[width * ySections];
851        tallied = false;
852    }
853    /**
854     * Reassigns this GreasedRegion with the given 1D boolean array, reusing the current data storage (without
855     * extra allocations) if this.width == width and this.height == height, where an [x][y]
856     * position is obtained from bits given an index n with x = n / height, y = n % height, any value of true
857     * considered "on", and any value of false considered "off."
858     * @param bits a 1D boolean array where true is on and false is off
859     * @param width the width of the desired GreasedRegion; width * height should equal bits.length
860     * @param height the height of the desired GreasedRegion; width * height should equal bits.length
861     * @return this for chaining
862     */
863    public GreasedRegion refill(final boolean[] bits, final int width, final int height) {
864        if (bits != null && this.width == width && this.height == height) {
865            Arrays.fill(data, 0L);
866            for (int a = 0, x = 0, y = 0; a < bits.length; a++, x = a / height, y = a % height) {
867                data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= (bits[a] ? 1L : 0L) << (y & 63);
868            }
869            tallied = false;
870            return this;
871        } else {
872            this.width = (bits == null || width < 0) ? 0 : width;
873            this.height = (bits == null || bits.length <= 0 || height < 0) ? 0 : height;
874            ySections = (this.height + 63) >> 6;
875            yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (this.height & 63));
876            data = new long[this.width * ySections];
877            if(bits != null) {
878                for (int a = 0, x = 0, y = 0; a < bits.length; a++, x = a / this.height, y = a % this.height) {
879                    if (bits[a]) data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
880                }
881            }
882            counts = new int[width * ySections];
883            tallied = false;
884            return this;
885        }
886    }

888    /**
889     * Constructor for an empty GreasedRegion of the given width and height.
890     * GreasedRegions are mutable, so you can add to this with insert() or insertSeveral(), among others.
891     * @param width the maximum width for the GreasedRegion
892     * @param height the maximum height for the GreasedRegion
893     */
894    public GreasedRegion(final int width, final int height)
895    {
896        this.width = width;
897        this.height = height;
898        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
899        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
900        data = new long[width * ySections];
901        counts = new int[width  * ySections];
902        ct = 0;
903        tallied = true;
904    }
905
906    /**
907     * If this GreasedRegion has the same width and height passed as parameters, this acts the same as {@link #empty()},
908     * makes no allocations, and returns this GreasedRegion with its contents all "off"; otherwise, this does allocate
909     * a differently-sized amount of internal data to match the new width and height, sets the fields to all match the
910     * new width and height, and returns this GreasedRegion with its new width and height, with all contents "off". This
911     * is meant for cases where a GreasedRegion may be reused effectively, but its size may not always be the same.
912     * @param width the width to potentially resize this GreasedRegion to
913     * @param height the height to potentially resize this GreasedRegion to
914     * @return this GreasedRegion, always with all contents "off", and with the height and width set.
915     */
916    public GreasedRegion resizeAndEmpty(final int width, final int height) {
917        if (width == this.width && height == this.height) {
918            Arrays.fill(data, 0L);
919            Arrays.fill(counts, 0);
920            ct = 0;
921            tallied = true;
922        } else {
923            this.width = (width <= 0) ? 0 : width;
924            this.height = (height <= 0) ? 0 : height;
925            ySections = (this.height + 63) >> 6;
926            yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (this.height & 63));
927            data = new long[this.width * ySections];
928            counts = new int[this.width * ySections];
929            ct = 0;
930            tallied = true;
931        }
932        return this;
933
934    }
935
936    /**
937     * Constructor for a GreasedRegion that contains a single "on" cell, and has the given width and height.
938     * Note that to avoid confusion with the constructor that takes multiple Coord values, this takes the single "on"
939     * Coord first, while the multiple-Coord constructor takes its vararg or array of Coords last.
940     * @param single the one (x,y) point to store as "on" in this GreasedRegion
941     * @param width the maximum width for the GreasedRegion
942     * @param height the maximum height for the GreasedRegion
943     */
944    public GreasedRegion(final Coord single, final int width, final int height)
945    {
946        this.width = width;
947        this.height = height;
948        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
949        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
950        data = new long[width * ySections];
951        counts = new int[width * ySections];
952        if(single.x < width && single.y < height && single.x >= 0 && single.y >= 0)
953        {
954            data[ct = single.x * ySections + (single.y >> 6)] |= 1L << (single.y & 63);
955            counts[ct] = 1;
956            ct = 1;
957            tallied = true;
958        }
959        else
960        {
961            ct = 0;
962            tallied = true;
963        }
964    }
965
966    /**
967     * Constructor for a GreasedRegion that can have several "on" cells specified, and has the given width and height.
968     * Note that to avoid confusion with the constructor that takes one Coord value, this takes the vararg or array of
969     * Coords last, while the single-Coord constructor takes its one Coord first.
970     * @param width the maximum width for the GreasedRegion
971     * @param height the maximum height for the GreasedRegion
972     * @param points an array or vararg of Coord to store as "on" in this GreasedRegion
973     */
974    public GreasedRegion(final int width, final  int height, final Coord... points)
975    {
976        this.width = width;
977        this.height = height;
978        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
979        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
980        data = new long[width * ySections];
981        if(points != null)
982        {
983            for (int i = 0, x, y; i < points.length; i++) {
984                x = points[i].x;
985                y = points[i].y;
986                if(x < width && y < height && x >= 0 && y >= 0)
987                    data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
988            }
989        }
990        counts = new int[width * ySections];
991        tallied = false;
992    }

994    /**
995     * Constructor for a GreasedRegion that can have several "on" cells specified, and has the given width and height.
996     * Note that to avoid confusion with the constructor that takes one Coord value, this takes the Iterable of
997     * Coords last, while the single-Coord constructor takes its one Coord first.
998     * @param width the maximum width for the GreasedRegion
999     * @param height the maximum height for the GreasedRegion
1000     * @param points an array or vararg of Coord to store as "on" in this GreasedRegion
1001     */
1002    public GreasedRegion(final int width, final int height, final Iterable<Coord> points)
1003    {
1004        this.width = width;
1005        this.height = height;
1006        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
1007        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
1008        data = new long[width * ySections];
1009        if(points != null) {
1010            int x, y;
1011            for (Coord c : points) {
1012                x = c.x;
1013                y = c.y;
1014                if (x < width && y < height && x >= 0 && y >= 0)
1015                    data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
1016            }
1017        }
1018        counts = new int[width * ySections];
1019        tallied = false;
1020
1021    }

1023    /**
1024     * Constructor for a random GreasedRegion of the given width and height, typically assigning approximately half of
1025     * the cells in this to "on" and the rest to off. A RandomnessSource can be slightly more efficient than an RNG when
1026     * you're making a lot of calls on it.
1027     * @param random a RandomnessSource that should have a good nextLong() method; DiverRNG is excellent but Lathe32RNG is faster on GWT (only there) 
1028     * @param width the maximum width for the GreasedRegion
1029     * @param height the maximum height for the GreasedRegion
1030     */
1031    public GreasedRegion(final RandomnessSource random, final int width, final int height)
1032    {
1033        this.width = width;
1034        this.height = height;
1035        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
1036        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
1037        data = new long[width * ySections];
1038        for (int i = 0; i < width * ySections; i++) {
1039            data[i] = random.nextLong();
1040        }
1041        if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
1042            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
1043                data[a] &= yEndMask;
1044            }
1045        }
1046        counts = new int[width * ySections];
1047        tallied = false;
1048    }
1049    /**
1050     * Reassigns this GreasedRegion by filling it with random values from random, reusing the current data storage
1051     * (without extra allocations) if this.width == width and this.height == height, and typically assigning
1052     * approximately half of the cells in this to "on" and the rest to off. A RandomnessSource can be slightly more
1053     * efficient than an RNG when you're making a lot of calls on it.
1054     * @param random a RandomnessSource that should have a good nextLong() method; DiverRNG is excellent but Lathe32RNG is faster on GWT (only there) 
1055     * @param width the width of the desired GreasedRegion
1056     * @param height the height of the desired GreasedRegion
1057     * @return this for chaining
1058     */
1059    public GreasedRegion refill(final RandomnessSource random, final int width, final int height) {
1060        if (random != null){
1061            if(this.width == width && this.height == height) {
1062                for (int i = 0; i < width * ySections; i++) {
1063                    data[i] = random.nextLong();
1064                }
1065            } else {
1066                this.width = (width <= 0) ? 0 : width;
1067                this.height = (height <= 0) ? 0 : height;
1068                ySections = (this.height + 63) >> 6;
1069                yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (this.height & 63));
1070                data = new long[this.width * ySections];
1071                for (int i = 0; i < this.width * ySections; i++) {
1072                    data[i] = random.nextLong();
1073                }
1074                counts = new int[this.width * ySections];
1075            }
1076            if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
1077                for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
1078                    data[a] &= yEndMask;
1079                }
1080            }
1081            tallied = false;
1082        }
1083        return this;
1084    }

1086    /**
1087     * Constructor for a random GreasedRegion of the given width and height, typically assigning approximately half of
1088     * the cells in this to "on" and the rest to off. A RandomnessSource can be slightly more efficient than an RNG when
1089     * you're making a lot of calls on it, so you may prefer {@link #GreasedRegion(RandomnessSource, int, int)}.
1090     * @param random an IRNG, such as an RNG, that this will use to generate its contents
1091     * @param width the maximum width for the GreasedRegion
1092     * @param height the maximum height for the GreasedRegion
1093     */
1094    public GreasedRegion(final IRNG random, final int width, final int height)
1095    {
1096        this.width = width;
1097        this.height = height;
1098        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
1099        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
1100        data = new long[width * ySections];
1101        for (int i = 0; i < width * ySections; i++) {
1102            data[i] = random.nextLong();
1103        }
1104        if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
1105            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
1106                data[a] &= yEndMask;
1107            }
1108        }
1109        counts = new int[width * ySections];
1110        tallied = false;
1111    }
1112    /**
1113     * Reassigns this GreasedRegion by filling it with random values from random, reusing the current data storage
1114     * (without extra allocations) if this.width == width and this.height == height, and typically assigning
1115     * approximately half of the cells in this to "on" and the rest to off.
1116     * @param random an IRNG that should have a good nextLong() method; an RNG constructed with the default RandomnessSource will be fine
1117     * @param width the width of the desired GreasedRegion
1118     * @param height the height of the desired GreasedRegion
1119     * @return this for chaining
1120     */
1121    public GreasedRegion refill(final IRNG random, final int width, final int height) {
1122        if (random != null){
1123            if(this.width == width && this.height == height) {
1124                for (int i = 0; i < width * ySections; i++) {
1125                    data[i] = random.nextLong();
1126                }
1127            } else {
1128                this.width = (width <= 0) ? 0 : width;
1129                this.height = (height <= 0) ? 0 : height;
1130                ySections = (this.height + 63) >> 6;
1131                yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (this.height & 63));
1132                data = new long[this.width * ySections];
1133                for (int i = 0; i < this.width * ySections; i++) {
1134                    data[i] = random.nextLong();
1135                }
1136                counts = new int[width * ySections];
1137            }
1138            if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
1139                for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
1140                    data[a] &= yEndMask;
1141                }
1142            }
1143            tallied = false;
1144        }
1145        return this;
1146    }
1147
1148    /**
1149     * Constructor for a random GreasedRegion of the given width and height, trying to set the given fraction of cells
1150     * to on. Depending on the value of fraction, this makes between 0 and 6 calls to the nextLong() method of random's
1151     * internal RandomnessSource, per 64 cells of this GreasedRegion (if height is not a multiple of 64, round up to get
1152     * the number of calls this makes). As such, this sacrifices the precision of the fraction to obtain significantly
1153     * better speed than generating one random number per cell, although the precision is probably good enough (fraction
1154     * is effectively rounded down to the nearest multiple of 0.015625, and clamped between 0.0 and 1.0). The parameter
1155     * {@code random} can be an object like a {@link DiverRNG}, an {@link RNG} backed by a well-distributed
1156     * RandomnessSource like its default, DiverRNG, a {@link GWTRNG} (especially if you target GWT, where it will
1157     * perform much better than most alternatives), or any of various other RandomnessSource implementations that
1158     * distribute bits well for {@link RandomnessSource#nextLong()}, but should not be intentionally-biased RNGs like
1159     * {@link DharmaRNG} or {@link EditRNG}, nor double-based QRNGs like {@link VanDerCorputQRNG} or {@link SobolQRNG}.
1160     * @param random a RandomnessSource that should produce high-quality long values, like the defaults for {@link RNG}
1161     * @param fraction between 0.0 and 1.0 (clamped), only considering a precision of 1/64.0 (0.015625) between steps
1162     * @param width the maximum width for the GreasedRegion
1163     * @param height the maximum height for the GreasedRegion
1164     */
1165    public GreasedRegion(final RandomnessSource random, final double fraction, final int width, final int height)
1166    {
1167        this.width = width;
1168        this.height = height;
1169        int bitCount = (int) (fraction * 64);
1170        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
1171        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
1172        data = new long[width * ySections];
1173        for (int i = 0; i < width * ySections; i++) {
1174            data[i] = approximateBits(random, bitCount);
1175        }
1176        if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
1177            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
1178                data[a] &= yEndMask;
1179            }
1180        }
1181        counts = new int[width * ySections];
1182        tallied = false;
1183    }
1184    /**
1185     * Reassigns this GreasedRegion randomly, reusing the current data storage (without extra allocations) if this.width
1186     * == width and this.height == height, while trying to set the given fraction of cells to on. Depending on the value
1187     * of fraction, this makes between 0 and 6 calls to the nextLong() method of random's internal RandomnessSource, per
1188     * 64 cells of this GreasedRegion (if height is not a multiple of 64, round up to get the number of calls this
1189     * makes). As such, this sacrifices the precision of the fraction to obtain significantly better speed than
1190     * generating one random number per cell, although the precision is probably good enough (fraction is effectively
1191     * rounded down to the nearest multiple of 0.015625, and clamped between 0.0 and 1.0). The parameter {@code random}
1192     * can be an object like a {@link DiverRNG}, an {@link RNG} backed by a well-distributed RandomnessSource like its
1193     * default, DiverRNG, a {@link GWTRNG} (especially if you target GWT, where it will perform much better than most
1194     * alternatives), or any of various other RandomnessSource implementations that distribute bits well for
1195     * {@link RandomnessSource#nextLong()}, but should not be intentionally-biased RNGs like {@link DharmaRNG} or
1196     * {@link EditRNG}, nor double-based QRNGs like {@link VanDerCorputQRNG} or {@link SobolQRNG}.
1197     * @param random a RandomnessSource that should produce high-quality long values, like the defaults for {@link RNG}
1198     * @param fraction between 0.0 and 1.0 (clamped), only considering a precision of 1/64.0 (0.015625) between steps
1199     * @param width the maximum width for the GreasedRegion
1200     * @param height the maximum height for the GreasedRegion
1201     * @return this for chaining
1202     */
1203    public GreasedRegion refill(final RandomnessSource random, final double fraction, final int width, final int height) {
1204        if (random != null){
1205            int bitCount = (int) (fraction * 64);
1206            if(this.width == width && this.height == height) {
1207                for (int i = 0; i < width * ySections; i++) {
1208                    data[i] = approximateBits(random, bitCount);
1209                }
1210            } else {
1211                this.width = (width <= 0) ? 0 : width;
1212                this.height = (height <= 0) ? 0 : height;
1213                ySections = (this.height + 63) >> 6;
1214                yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (this.height & 63));
1215                data = new long[this.width * ySections];
1216                for (int i = 0; i < this.width * ySections; i++) {
1217                    data[i] = approximateBits(random, bitCount);
1218                }
1219                counts = new int[width * ySections];
1220            }
1221            if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
1222                for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
1223                    data[a] &= yEndMask;
1224                }
1225            }
1226        }
1227        tallied = false;
1228        return this;
1229    }

1231    /**
1232     * Copy constructor that takes another GreasedRegion and copies all of its data into this new one.
1233     * If you find yourself frequently using this constructor and assigning it to the same variable, consider using the
1234     * {@link #remake(GreasedRegion)} method on the variable instead, which will, if it has the same width and height
1235     * as the other GreasedRegion, avoid creating garbage and quickly fill the variable with the other's contents.
1236     * @see #copy() for a convenience method that just uses this constructor
1237     * @param other another GreasedRegion that will be copied into this new GreasedRegion
1238     */
1239    public GreasedRegion(final GreasedRegion other)
1240    {
1241        width = other.width;
1242        height = other.height;
1243        ySections = other.ySections;
1244        yEndMask = other.yEndMask;
1245        data = new long[width * ySections];
1246        counts = new int[width * ySections];
1247        System.arraycopy(other.data, 0, data, 0, width * ySections);
1248        System.arraycopy(other.counts, 0, counts, 0, width * ySections);
1249        ct  = other.ct;
1250        tallied = other.tallied;
1251    }

1253    /**
1254     * Primarily for internal use, this constructor copies data2 exactly into the internal long array the new
1255     * GreasedRegion will use, and does not perform any validation steps to ensure that cells that would be "on" but are
1256     * outside the actual height of the GreasedRegion are actually removed (this only matters if height is not a
1257     * multiple of 64).
1258     * @param data2 a long array that is typically from another GreasedRegion, and would be hard to make otherwise
1259     * @param width the width of the GreasedRegion to construct
1260     * @param height the height of the GreasedRegion to construct
1261     */
1262    public GreasedRegion(final long[] data2, final int width, final int height)
1263    {
1264        this.width = width;
1265        this.height = height;
1266        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
1267        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
1268        data = new long[width * ySections];
1269        System.arraycopy(data2, 0, data, 0, width * ySections);
1270        if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
1271            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
1272                data[a] &= yEndMask;
1273            }
1274        }
1275        counts = new int[width * ySections];
1276        tallied = false;
1277    }
1278
1279    /**
1280     * Primarily for internal use, this constructor copies data2 into the internal long array the new GreasedRegion will
1281     * use, but treats data2 as having the dimensions [dataWidth][dataHeight], and uses the potentially-different
1282     * dimensions [width][height] for the constructed GreasedRegion. This will truncate data2 on width, height, or both
1283     * if width or height is smaller than dataWidth or dataHeight. It will fill extra space with all "off" if width or
1284     * height is larger than dataWidth or dataHeight. It will interpret data2 as the same 2D shape regardless of the
1285     * width or height it is being assigned to, and data2 will not be reshaped by truncation.
1286     * @param data2 a long array that is typically from another GreasedRegion, and would be hard to make otherwise
1287     * @param dataWidth the width to interpret data2 as having
1288     * @param dataHeight the height to interpret data2 as having
1289     * @param width the width of the GreasedRegion to construct
1290     * @param height the height of the GreasedRegion to construct
1291     */
1292    public GreasedRegion(final long[] data2, final int dataWidth, final int dataHeight, final int width, final int height)
1293    {
1294        this.width = width;
1295        this.height = height;
1296        ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
1297        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
1298        data = new long[width * ySections];
1299
1300        final int ySections2 = (dataHeight + 63) >> 6;
1301        if(ySections2 == 0)
1302        {
1303            counts = new int[0];
1304            tallied = false;
1305            return;
1306        }
1307        if(ySections == 1) {
1308            System.arraycopy(data2, 0, data, 0, Math.min(dataWidth, width));
1309        }
1310        else
1311        {
1312            if(dataHeight >= height) {
1313                for (int i = 0, j = 0; i < width && i < dataWidth; i += ySections2, j += ySections) {
1314                    System.arraycopy(data2, i, data, j, ySections);
1315                }
1316            }
1317            else
1318            {
1319                for (int i = 0, j = 0; i < width && i < dataWidth; i += ySections2, j += ySections) {
1320                    System.arraycopy(data2, i, data, j, ySections2);
1321                }
1322            }
1323        }
1324        if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
1325            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
1326                data[a] &= yEndMask;
1327            }
1328        }
1329        counts = new int[width * ySections];
1330        tallied = false;
1331    }
1332    /**
1333     * Primarily for internal use, this method copies data2 into the internal long array the new GreasedRegion will
1334     * use, but treats data2 as having the dimensions [dataWidth][dataHeight], and uses the potentially-different
1335     * dimensions [width][height] for this GreasedRegion, potentially re-allocating the internal data this uses if width
1336     * and/or height are different from what they were. This will truncate data2 on width, height, or both if width or
1337     * height is smaller than dataWidth or dataHeight. It will fill extra space with all "off" if width or height is
1338     * larger than dataWidth or dataHeight. It will interpret data2 as the same 2D shape regardless of the width or
1339     * height it is being assigned to, and data2 will not be reshaped by truncation.
1340     * @param data2 a long array that is typically from another GreasedRegion, and would be hard to make otherwise
1341     * @param dataWidth the width to interpret data2 as having
1342     * @param dataHeight the height to interpret data2 as having
1343     * @param width the width to set this GreasedRegion to have
1344     * @param height the height to set this GreasedRegion to have
1345     */
1346    public GreasedRegion refill(final long[] data2, final int dataWidth, final int dataHeight, final int width, final int height)
1347    {
1348        if(width != this.width || height != this.height) {
1349            this.width = width;
1350            this.height = height;
1351            ySections = (height + 63) >> 6;
1352            yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (height & 63));
1353            data = new long[width * ySections];
1354            counts = new int[width * ySections];
1355        }
1356        else {
1357            Arrays.fill(data, 0L);
1358        }
1359        final int ySections2 = (dataHeight + 63) >> 6;
1360        if(ySections2 == 0)
1361            return this;
1362        if(ySections == 1) {
1363            System.arraycopy(data2, 0, data, 0, Math.min(dataWidth, width));
1364        }
1365        else
1366        {
1367            if(dataHeight >= height) {
1368                for (int i = 0, j = 0; i < width && i < dataWidth; i += ySections2, j += ySections) {
1369                    System.arraycopy(data2, i, data, j, ySections);
1370                }
1371            }
1372            else
1373            {
1374                for (int i = 0, j = 0; i < width && i < dataWidth; i += ySections2, j += ySections) {
1375                    System.arraycopy(data2, i, data, j, ySections2);
1376                }
1377            }
1378        }
1379        if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
1380            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
1381                data[a] &= yEndMask;
1382            }
1383        }
1384        tallied = false;
1385        return this;
1386    }
1387
1388    /**
1389     * A useful method for efficiency, remake() reassigns this GreasedRegion to have its contents replaced by other. If
1390     * other and this GreasedRegion have identical width and height, this is very efficient and performs no additional
1391     * allocations, simply replacing the cell data in this with the cell data from other. If width and height are not
1392     * both equal between this and other, this does allocate a new data array, but still reassigns this GreasedRegion
1393     * in-place and acts similarly to when width and height are both equal (it just uses some more memory).
1394     * <br>
1395     * Using remake() or the similar refill() methods in chains of operations on multiple GreasedRegions can be key to
1396     * maintaining good performance and memory usage. You often can recycle a no-longer-used GreasedRegion by assigning
1397     * a GreasedRegion you want to keep to it with remake(), then mutating either the remade value or the one that was
1398     * just filled into this but keeping one version around for later usage.
1399     * @param other another GreasedRegion to replace the data in this GreasedRegion with
1400     * @return this for chaining
1401     */
1402    public GreasedRegion remake(GreasedRegion other) {
1403        if (width == other.width && height == other.height) {
1404            System.arraycopy(other.data, 0, data, 0, width * ySections);
1405            System.arraycopy(other.counts, 0, counts, 0, width * ySections);
1406            ct = other.ct;
1407            tallied = other.tallied;
1408            return this;
1409        } else {
1410            width = other.width;
1411            height = other.height;
1412            ySections = other.ySections;
1413            yEndMask = other.yEndMask;
1414            data = new long[width * ySections];
1415            System.arraycopy(other.data, 0, data, 0, width * ySections);
1416            System.arraycopy(other.counts, 0, counts, 0, width * ySections);
1417            ct = other.ct;
1418            tallied = other.tallied;
1419            return this;
1420        }
1421    }
1422
1423    /**
1424     * Changes the width and/or height of this GreasedRegion, enlarging or shrinking starting at the edges where
1425     * {@code x == width - 1} and {@code y == height - 1}. There isn't an especially efficient way to expand from the
1426     * other edges, but this method is able to copy data in bulk, so at least this method should be very fast. You can
1427     * use {@code insert(int, int, GreasedRegion)} if you want to place one GreasedRegion inside another one,
1428     * potentially with a different size. The space created by any enlargement starts all off; shrinking doesn't change
1429     * the existing data where it isn't removed by the shrink.
1430     * @param widthChange the amount to change width by; can be positive, negative, or zero
1431     * @param heightChange the amount to change height by; can be positive, negative, or zero
1432     * @return this for chaining
1433     */
1434    public GreasedRegion alterBounds(int widthChange, int heightChange)
1435    {
1436        int newWidth = width + widthChange;
1437        int newHeight = height + heightChange;
1438        if(newWidth <= 0 || newHeight <= 0)
1439        {
1440            width = 0;
1441            height = 0;
1442            ySections= 0;
1443            yEndMask = -1;
1444            data = new long[0];
1445            counts = new int[0];
1446            ct = 0;
1447            tallied = true;
1448            return this;
1449        }
1450        int newYSections = (newHeight + 63) >> 6;
1451        yEndMask = -1L >>> (64 - (newHeight & 63));
1452        long[] newData = new long[newWidth * newYSections];         
1453        counts = new int[newWidth * newYSections];
1454        
1455        for (int x = 0; x < width && x < newWidth; x++) {
1456            for (int ys = 0; ys < ySections && ys < newYSections; ys++) {
1457                newData[x * newYSections + ys] = data[x * ySections + ys];
1458            }
1459        }
1460        ySections = newYSections;
1461        width = newWidth;
1462        height = newHeight;
1463        data = newData;
1464        if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
1465            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
1466                data[a] &= yEndMask;
1467            }
1468        }
1469        tallied = false;
1470        return this;
1471    }
1472
1473    /**
1474     * Sets the cell at x,y to on if value is true or off if value is false. Does nothing if x,y is out of bounds.
1475     * @param value the value to set in the cell
1476     * @param x the x-position of the cell
1477     * @param y the y-position of the cell
1478     * @return this for chaining
1479     */
1480    public GreasedRegion set(boolean value, int x, int y)
1481    {
1482        if(x < width && y < height && x >= 0 && y >= 0) {
1483            if(value)
1484                data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
1485            else
1486                data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] &= ~(1L << (y & 63));
1487            tallied = false;
1488        }
1489        return this;
1490    }
1491
1492    /**
1493     * Sets the cell at point to on if value is true or off if value is false. Does nothing if point is out of bounds,
1494     * or if point is null.
1495     * @param value the value to set in the cell
1496     * @param point the x,y Coord of the cell to set
1497     * @return this for chaining
1498     */
1499    public GreasedRegion set(boolean value, Coord point)
1500    {
1501        if(point == null) return this;
1502        return set(value, point.x, point.y);
1503    }
1504
1505    /**
1506     * Sets the cell at x,y to "on". Does nothing if x,y is out of bounds.
1507     * More efficient, slightly, than {@link #set(boolean, int, int)} if you just need to set a cell to "on".
1508     * @param x the x-position of the cell
1509     * @param y the y-position of the cell
1510     * @return this for chaining
1511     */
1512    public GreasedRegion insert(int x, int y)
1513    {
1514        if(x < width && y < height && x >= 0 && y >= 0)
1515        {
1516            data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] |= 1L << (y & 63);
1517            tallied = false;
1518        }
1519        return this;
1520    }
1521
1522    /**
1523     * Sets the given cell, "tightly" encoded for a specific width/height as by {@link #asTightEncoded()}, to "on".
1524     * Does nothing if the cell is out of bounds.
1525     * @param tight a cell tightly encoded for this GreasedRegion's width and height
1526     * @return this for chaining
1527     */
1528    public GreasedRegion insert(int tight)
1529    {
1530        if(tight < width * height && tight >= 0)
1531        {
1532            data[(tight % width) * ySections + ((tight / width) >>> 6)] |= 1L << ((tight / width) & 63);
1533            tallied = false;
1534        }
1535        return this;
1536    }
1537    /**
1538     * Sets the cell at point to "on". Does nothing if point is out of bounds, or if point is null.
1539     * More efficient, slightly, than {@link #set(boolean, Coord)} if you just need to set a cell to "on".
1540     * @param point the x,y Coord of the cell
1541     * @return this for chaining
1542     */
1543    public GreasedRegion insert(Coord point)
1544    {
1545
1546        if(point == null) return this;
1547        return insert(point.x, point.y);
1548    }

1550    /**
1551     * Takes another GreasedRegion, called other, with potentially different size and inserts its "on" cells into thi
1552     * GreasedRegion at the given x,y offset, allowing negative x and/or y to put only part of other in this.
1553     * <br>
1554     * This is a rather complex method internally, but should be about as efficient as a general insert-region method
1555     * can be.
1556     * @param x the x offset to start inserting other at; may be negative
1557     * @param y the y offset to start inserting other at; may be negative
1558     * @param other the other GreasedRegion to insert
1559     * @return this for chaining
1560     */
1561    public GreasedRegion insert(int x, int y, GreasedRegion other)
1562    {
1563        if(other == null || other.ySections <= 0 || other.width <= 0)
1564            return this;
1565
1566        int start = Math.max(0, x), len = Math.min(width, Math.min(other.width, other.width + x) - start),
1567        oys = other.ySections, jump = (y == 0) ? 0 : (y < 0) ? -(-y >>> 6) : (y >>> 6), lily = (y < 0) ? -(-y & 63) : (y & 63),
1568        originalJump = Math.max(0, -jump), alterJump = Math.max(0, jump);
1569        long[] data2 = new long[other.width * ySections];
1570
1571        long prev, tmp;
1572        if(oys == ySections) {
1573            if (x < 0) {
1574                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {
1575                    for (int j = Math.max(0, -x), jj = 0; jj < len; j++, jj++) {
1576                        data2[jj * ySections + i] = other.data[j * oys + oi];
1577                    }
1578                }
1579            } else if (x > 0) {
1580                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {
1581                    for (int j = 0, jj = start; j < len; j++, jj++) {
1582                        data2[jj * ySections + i] = other.data[j * ySections + oi];
1583                    }
1584                }
1585            } else {
1586                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {
1587                    for (int j = 0; j < len; j++) {
1588                        data2[j * ySections + i] = other.data[j * ySections + oi];
1589                    }
1590                }
1591            }
1592        }
1593        else if(oys < ySections)
1594        {
1595            if (x < 0) {
1596                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {
1597                    for (int j = Math.max(0, -x), jj = 0; jj < len; j++, jj++) {
1598                        data2[jj * ySections + i] = other.data[j * oys + oi];
1599                    }
1600                }
1601            } else if (x > 0) {
1602                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {// oi < oys - Math.max(0, jump)
1603                    for (int j = 0, jj = start; j < len; j++, jj++) {
1604                        data2[jj * ySections + i] = other.data[j * oys + oi];
1605                    }
1606                }
1607            } else {
1608                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {
1609                    for (int j = 0; j < len; j++) {
1610                        data2[j * ySections + i] = other.data[j * oys + oi];
1611                    }
1612                }
1613            }
1614        }
1615        else
1616        {
1617            if (x < 0) {
1618                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {
1619                    for (int j = Math.max(0, -x), jj = 0; jj < len; j++, jj++) {
1620                        data2[jj * ySections + i] = other.data[j * oys + oi];
1621                    }
1622                }
1623            } else if (x > 0) {
1624                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {
1625                    for (int j = 0, jj = start; j < len; j++, jj++) {
1626                        data2[jj * ySections + i] = other.data[j * oys + oi];
1627                    }
1628                }
1629            } else {
1630                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {
1631                    for (int j = 0; j < len; j++) {
1632                        data2[j * ySections + i] = other.data[j * oys + oi];
1633                    }
1634                }
1635            }
1636        }
1637
1638        if(lily < 0) {
1639            for (int i = start; i < len; i++) {
1640                prev = 0L;
1641                for (int j = 0; j < ySections; j++) {
1642                    tmp = prev;
1643                    prev = (data2[i * ySections + j] & ~(-1L << -lily)) << (64 + lily);
1644                    data2[i * ySections + j] >>>= -lily;
1645                    data2[i * ySections + j] |= tmp;
1646                }
1647            }
1648        }
1649        else if(lily > 0) {
1650            for (int i = start; i < start + len; i++) {
1651                prev = 0L;
1652                for (int j = 0; j < ySections; j++) {
1653                    tmp = prev;
1654                    prev = (data2[i * ySections + j] & ~(-1L >>> lily)) >>> (64 - lily);
1655                    data2[i * ySections + j] <<= lily;
1656                    data2[i * ySections + j] |= tmp;
1657                }
1658            }
1659        }
1660        len = Math.min(width, start + len);
1661        for (int i = start; i < len; i++) {
1662            for (int j = 0; j < ySections; j++) {
1663                data[i * ySections + j] |= data2[i * ySections + j];
1664            }
1665        }
1666
1667        if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
1668            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
1669                data[a] &= yEndMask;
1670            }
1671        }
1672        tallied = false;
1673        return this;
1674    }
