1718    public GreasedRegion insertRectangle(int startX, int startY, int rectangleWidth, int rectangleHeight)
1719    {
1720        if(rectangleWidth < 1 || rectangleHeight < 1 || ySections <= 0)
1721            return this;
1722        if(startX < 0)
1723            startX = 0;
1724        else if(startX >= width)
1725            startX = width - 1;
1726        if(startY < 0)
1727            startY = 0;
1728        else if(startY >= height)
1729            startY = height - 1;
1730        int endX = Math.min(width, startX + rectangleWidth) - 1,
1731                endY = Math.min(height, startY + rectangleHeight) - 1,
1732                startSection = startY >> 6, endSection = endY >> 6;
1733        if(startSection < endSection)
1734        {
1735            long startMask = -1L << (startY & 63),
1736                    endMask = -1L >>> (~endY & 63);
1737            for (int a = startX * ySections + startSection; a <= endX * ySections + startSection; a += ySections) {
1738                data[a] |= startMask;
1739            }
1740            if(endSection - startSection > 1)
1741            {
1742                for (int b = 1; b < endSection - startSection; b++) {
1743                    for (int a = startX * ySections + startSection + b; a < endX * ySections + ySections; a += ySections) {
1744                        data[a] = -1;
1745                    }
1746                }
1747            }
1748            for (int a = startX * ySections + endSection; a <= endX * ySections + endSection; a += ySections) {
1749                data[a] |= endMask;
1750            }
1751        }
1752        else
1753        {
1754            long mask = (-1L << (startY & 63)) & (-1L >>> (~endY & 63));
1755            for (int a = startX * ySections + startSection; a <= endX * ySections + startSection; a += ySections) {
1756                data[a] |= mask;
1757            }
1758        }
1759
1760        if(yEndMask != -1L) {
1761            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
1762                data[a] &= yEndMask;
1763            }
1764        }
1765        tallied = false;
1766        return this;
1767    }
1768
1769    public GreasedRegion insertCircle(Coord center, int radius)
1770    {
1771        float high, changedX;
1772        int rndX, rndY;
1773        for (int dx = -radius; dx <= radius; ++dx) {
1774            changedX = dx - 0.25f * (dx >> 31 | -dx >>> 31); // project nayuki signum
1775            rndX = Math.round(changedX);
1776            high = (float) Math.sqrt(radius * radius - changedX * changedX);             
1777            insert(center.x + rndX, center.y);
1778            for (float dy = high; dy >= 0.75f; --dy) {
1779                rndY = Math.round(dy - 0.25f);                 
1780                insert(center.x + rndX, center.y + rndY);
1781                insert(center.x + rndX, center.y - rndY);
1782            }
1783        }
1784        return this;
1785    }
1786
1787    public GreasedRegion remove(int x, int y)
1788    {
1789        if(x < width && y < height && x >= 0 && y >= 0)
1790        {
1791            data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] &= ~(1L << (y & 63));
1792            tallied = false;
1793        }
1794        return this;
1795    }
1796    public GreasedRegion remove(Coord point)
1797    {
1798        return remove(point.x, point.y);
1799    }
1800    /**
1801     * Takes another GreasedRegion, called other, with potentially different size and removes its "on" cells from this
1802     * GreasedRegion at the given x,y offset, allowing negative x and/or y to remove only part of other in this.
1803     * <br>
1804     * This is a rather complex method internally, but should be about as efficient as a general remove-region method
1805     * can be. The code is identical to {@link #insert(int, int, GreasedRegion)} except that where insert only adds
1806     * cells, this only removes cells. Essentially, insert() is to {@link #or(GreasedRegion)} as remove() is to
1807     * {@link #andNot(GreasedRegion)}.
1808     * @param x the x offset to start removing other from; may be negative
1809     * @param y the y offset to start removing other from; may be negative
1810     * @param other the other GreasedRegion to remove
1811     * @return this for chaining
1812     */
1813    public GreasedRegion remove(int x, int y, GreasedRegion other)
1814    {
1815        if(other == null || other.ySections <= 0 || other.width <= 0)
1816            return this;
1817
1818        int start = Math.max(0, x), len = Math.min(width, Math.min(other.width, other.width + x) - start),
1819                oys = other.ySections, jump = (y == 0) ? 0 : (y < 0) ? -(-y >>> 6) : (y-1 >>> 6), lily = (y < 0) ? -(-y & 63) : (y & 63),
1820                originalJump = Math.max(0, -jump), alterJump = Math.max(0, jump);
1821        long[] data2 = new long[other.width * ySections];
1822
1823        long prev, tmp;
1824        if(oys == ySections) {
1825            if (x < 0) {
1826                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {
1827                    for (int j = Math.max(0, -x), jj = 0; jj < len; j++, jj++) {
1828                        data2[jj * ySections + i] = other.data[j * oys + oi];
1829                    }
1830                }
1831            } else if (x > 0) {
1832                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {
1833                    for (int j = 0, jj = start; j < len; j++, jj++) {
1834                        data2[jj * ySections + i] = other.data[j * ySections + oi];
1835                    }
1836                }
1837            } else {
1838                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {
1839                    for (int j = 0; j < len; j++) {
1840                        data2[j * ySections + i] = other.data[j * ySections + oi];
1841                    }
1842                }
1843            }
1844        }
1845        else if(oys < ySections)
1846        {
1847            if (x < 0) {
1848                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {
1849                    for (int j = Math.max(0, -x), jj = 0; jj < len; j++, jj++) {
1850                        data2[jj * ySections + i] = other.data[j * oys + oi];
1851                    }
1852                }
1853            } else if (x > 0) {
1854                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {// oi < oys - Math.max(0, jump)
1855                    for (int j = 0, jj = start; j < len; j++, jj++) {
1856                        data2[jj * ySections + i] = other.data[j * oys + oi];
1857                    }
1858                }
1859            } else {
1860                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {
1861                    for (int j = 0; j < len; j++) {
1862                        data2[j * ySections + i] = other.data[j * oys + oi];
1863                    }
1864                }
1865            }
1866        }
1867        else
1868        {
1869            if (x < 0) {
1870                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {
1871                    for (int j = Math.max(0, -x), jj = 0; jj < len; j++, jj++) {
1872                        data2[jj * ySections + i] = other.data[j * oys + oi];
1873                    }
1874                }
1875            } else if (x > 0) {
1876                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {
1877                    for (int j = 0, jj = start; j < len; j++, jj++) {
1878                        data2[jj * ySections + i] = other.data[j * oys + oi];
1879                    }
1880                }
1881            } else {
1882                for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < oys; i++, oi++) {
1883                    for (int j = 0; j < len; j++) {
1884                        data2[j * ySections + i] = other.data[j * oys + oi];
1885                    }
1886                }
1887            }
1888        }
1889
1890        if(lily < 0) {
1891            for (int i = start; i < len; i++) {
1892                prev = 0L;
1893                for (int j = 0; j < ySections; j++) {
1894                    tmp = prev;
1895                    prev = (data2[i * ySections + j] & ~(-1L << -lily)) << (64 + lily);
1896                    data2[i * ySections + j] >>>= -lily;
1897                    data2[i * ySections + j] |= tmp;
1898                }
1899            }
1900        }
1901        else if(lily > 0) {
1902            for (int i = start; i < start + len; i++) {
1903                prev = 0L;
1904                for (int j = 0; j < ySections; j++) {
1905                    tmp = prev;
1906                    prev = (data2[i * ySections + j] & ~(-1L >>> lily)) >>> (64 - lily);
1907                    data2[i * ySections + j] <<= lily;
1908                    data2[i * ySections + j] |= tmp;
1909                }
1910            }
1911        }
1912        len = Math.min(width, start + len);
1913        for (int i = start; i < len; i++) {
1914            for (int j = 0; j < ySections; j++) {
1915                data[i * ySections + j] &= ~data2[i * ySections + j];
1916            }
1917        }
1918
1919        if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
1920            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
1921                data[a] &= yEndMask;
1922            }
1923        }
1924        tallied = false;
1925
1926        return this;
1927    }

1932            y = points[i].y;
1933            if(x < width && y < height && x >= 0 && y >= 0)
1934            {

1947            y = pt.y;
1948            if(x < width && y < height && x >= 0 && y >= 0)

1957    /**
1958     * Removes all "on" cells from (startX, startY) inclusive 
1959     * to (startX+rectangleWidth, startY+rectangleHeight) exclusive, removing a total width of rectangleWidth and a
1960     * total height of rectangleHeight in cells.
1961     * @param startX left side x-coordinate
1962     * @param startY top side (or bottom if positive y is up) y-coordinate
1963     * @param rectangleWidth how many cells wide the area to remove is
1964     * @param rectangleHeight how many cells tal the area to remove is
1965     * @return this, after modification, for chaining
1966     */
1967    public GreasedRegion removeRectangle(int startX, int startY, int rectangleWidth, int rectangleHeight)
1968    {
1969        if(startX < 0)
1970        {
1971            rectangleWidth += startX;
1972            startX = 0;
1973        }
1974        else if(startX >= width)
1975        {
1976            rectangleWidth = 1;
1977            startX = width - 1;
1978        }
1979        if(startY < 0)
1980        {
1981            rectangleHeight += startY;
1982            startY = 0;
1983        }
1984        else if(startY >= height)
1985        {
1986            rectangleHeight = 1;
1987            startY = height - 1;
1988        }
1989        if(rectangleWidth < 1 || rectangleHeight < 1 || ySections <= 0)
1990            return this;
1991        int endX = Math.min(width, startX + rectangleWidth) - 1,
1992                endY = Math.min(height, startY + rectangleHeight) - 1,
1993                startSection = startY >> 6, endSection = endY >> 6;
1994        if(startSection < endSection)
1995        {
1996            long startMask = ~(-1L << (startY & 63)),
1997                    endMask = ~(-1L >>> (~endY & 63));
1998            for (int a = startX * ySections + startSection; a <= endX * ySections + startSection; a += ySections) {
1999                data[a] &= startMask;
2000            }
2001            if(endSection - startSection > 1)
2002            {
2003                for (int b = 1; b < endSection - startSection; b++) {
2004                    for (int a = startX * ySections + startSection + b; a < endX * ySections + ySections; a += ySections) {
2005                        data[a] = 0;
2006                    }
2007                }
2008            }
2009            for (int a = startX * ySections + endSection; a <= endX * ySections + endSection; a += ySections) {
2010                data[a] &= endMask;
2011            }
2012        }
2013        else
2014        {
2015            long mask = ~((-1L << (startY & 63)) & (-1L >>> (~endY & 63)));
2016            for (int a = startX * ySections + startSection; a <= endX * ySections + startSection; a += ySections) {
2017                data[a] &= mask;
2018            }
2019        }
2020        tallied = false;
2021        return this;
2022    }
2023
2024    public GreasedRegion removeCircle(Coord center, int radius)
2025    {
2026        float high, changedX;
2027        int rndX, rndY;
2028        for (int dx = -radius; dx <= radius; ++dx) {
2029            changedX = dx - 0.25f * (dx >> 31 | -dx >>> 31); // project nayuki signum
2030            rndX = Math.round(changedX);
2031            high = (float) Math.sqrt(radius * radius - changedX * changedX);
2032            remove(center.x + rndX, center.y);
2033            for (float dy = high; dy >= 0.75f; --dy) {
2034                rndY = Math.round(dy - 0.25f);
2035                remove(center.x + rndX, center.y + rndY);
2036                remove(center.x + rndX, center.y - rndY);
2037            }
2038        }
2039        return this;
2040    }

2042    /**
2043     * Equivalent to {@link #clear()}, setting all cells to "off," but also returns this for chaining.
2044     * @return this for chaining
2045     */
2046    public GreasedRegion empty()
2047    {
2048        Arrays.fill(data, 0L);
2049        Arrays.fill(counts, 0);
2050        ct = 0;
2051        tallied = true;
2052        return this;
2053    }
2054
2055    /**
2056     * Sets all cells in this to "on."
2057     * @return this for chaining
2058     */
2059    public GreasedRegion allOn()
2060    {
2061        if(ySections > 0)
2062        {
2063            if(yEndMask == -1) {
2064                Arrays.fill(data, -1);
2065                Arrays.fill(counts, 64);
2066                ct = ySections * width << 6;
2067                tallied = true;
2068            }
2069            else
2070            {
2071                ct = Long.bitCount(yEndMask);
2072                for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
2073                    data[a] = yEndMask;
2074                    counts[a] = ct;
2075                    for (int i = 0; i < ySections - 1; i++) {
2076                        data[a-i-1] = -1;
2077                        counts[a-i-1] = 64;
2078                    }
2079                }
2080                ct *= width;
2081                ct += (ySections - 1) * width << 6;
2082                tallied = true;
2083            }
2084        }
2085        return this;
2086    }
2087
2088    /**
2089     * Sets all cells in this to "on" if contents is true, or "off" if contents is false.
2090     * @param contents true to set all cells to on, false to set all cells to off
2091     * @return this for chaining
2092     */
2093    public GreasedRegion fill(boolean contents)
2094    {
2095        if(contents)
2096        {
2097            if(ySections > 0)
2098            {
2099                if(yEndMask == -1) {
2100                    Arrays.fill(data, -1);
2101                    Arrays.fill(counts, 64);
2102                    ct = ySections * width << 6;
2103                    tallied = true;
2104                }
2105                else
2106                {
2107                    ct = Long.bitCount(yEndMask);
2108                    for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
2109                        data[a] = yEndMask;
2110                        counts[a] = ct;
2111                        for (int i = 0; i < ySections - 1; i++) {
2112                            data[a-i-1] = -1;
2113                            counts[a-i-1] = 64;
2114                        }
2115                    }
2116                    ct *= width;
2117                    ct += (ySections - 1) * width << 6;
2118                    tallied = true;
2119                }
2120            }
2121            //else... what, if ySections is 0 there's nothing to do
2122        }
2123        else
2124        {
2125            Arrays.fill(data, 0L);
2126            Arrays.fill(counts, 0);
2127            ct = 0;
2128            tallied = true;
2129        }
2130        return this;
2131    }
2132    /**
2133     * Turns all cells that are adjacent to the boundaries of the GreasedRegion to "off".
2134     * @return this for chaining
2135     */
2136    public GreasedRegion removeEdges()
2137    {
2138        if(ySections > 0) {
2139            for (int i = 0; i < ySections; i++) {
2140                data[i] = 0L;
2141                data[width * ySections - 1 - i] = 0L;
2142            }
2143            if (ySections == 1) {
2144                for (int i = 0; i < width; i++) {
2145                    data[i] &= yEndMask >>> 1 & -2L;
2146                }
2147            } else {
2148                for (int i = ySections; i < data.length - ySections; i += ySections) {
2149                    data[i] &= -2L;
2150                }
2151                for (int a = ySections * 2 - 1; a < data.length - ySections; a += ySections) {
2152                    data[a] &= yEndMask >>> 1;
2153                }
2154            }
2155            tallied = false;
2156        }
2157        return this;
2158    }

2164     */
2165    public GreasedRegion copy()
2166    {
2167        return new GreasedRegion(this);
2168    }

2172     * treated as false.

2174     */
2175    public boolean[][] decode()
2176    {
2177        boolean[][] bools = new boolean[width][height];
2178        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
2179            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
2180                bools[x][y] = (data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] & (1L << (y & 63))) != 0;
2181            }
2182        }
2183        return bools;
2184    }

2198                chars[x][y] = (data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] & (1L << (y & 63))) != 0 ? on : off;
2199            }
2200        }
2201        return chars;

2250    /**
2251     * Returns this GreasedRegion's data as a StringBuilder, with each row made of the parameter on for "on" cells and
2252     * the parameter off for "off" cells, separated by newlines, with no trailing newline at the end.
2253     * @param on the char to use for "on" cells
2254     * @param off the char to use for "off" cells
2255     * @return a StringBuilder that stores each row of this GreasedRegion as chars, with rows separated by newlines.
2256     */
2257    public StringBuilder show(char on, char off)
2258    {
2259        StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder((width+1) * height);
2260        for (int y = 0; y < height;) {
2261            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
2262                sb.append((data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] & (1L << (y & 63))) != 0 ? on : off);
2263            }
2264            if(++y < height)
2265                sb.append('\n');
2266        }
2267        return sb;
2268    }

2271     * Returns a legible String representation of this that can be printed over multiple lines, with all "on" cells
2272     * represented by '.' and all "off" cells by '#', in roguelike floors-on walls-off convention, separating each row
2273     * by newlines (without a final trailing newline, so you could append text right after this).
2274     * @return a String representation of this GreasedRegion using '.' for on, '#' for off, and newlines between rows

2282    /**
2283     * Returns a copy of map where if a cell is "on" in this GreasedRegion, this keeps the value in map intact,
2284     * and where a cell is "off", it instead writes the char filler.
2285     * @param map a 2D char array that will not be modified
2286     * @param filler the char to use where this GreasedRegion stores an "off" cell
2287     * @return a masked copy of map
2288     */
2289    public char[][] mask(char[][] map, char filler)
2290    {
2291        if(map == null || map.length == 0)
2292            return new char[0][0];
2293        int width2 = Math.min(width, map.length), height2 = Math.min(height, map[0].length);
2294        char[][] chars = new char[width2][height2];
2295        for (int x = 0; x < width2; x++) {
2296            for (int y = 0; y < height2; y++) {
2297                chars[x][y] = (data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] & (1L << (y & 63))) != 0 ? map[x][y] : filler;
2298            }
2299        }
2300        return chars;
2301    }

2317        for (int x = 0; x < width2; x++) {
2318            for (int y = 0; y < height2; y++) {

2320            }

2332    public char[][] inverseMask(char[][] map, char toWrite)
2333    {

2335            return new char[0][0];

2338        for (int x = 0; x < width2; x++) {
2339            for (int y = 0; y < height2; y++) {

2341            }

2362            }

2369     * the value in map intact, and where a cell is "on", it instead writes the int toWrite. Modifies map in-place,
2370     * unlike {@link #writeInts(int[][], int)}.
2371     * @param map a 2D int array that <b>will</b> be modified
2372     * @param toWrite the int to use where this GreasedRegion stores an "on" cell
2373     * @return map, with the changes applied; not a copy
2374     */
2375    public int[][] writeIntsInto(int[][] map, int toWrite)
2376    {
2377        if(map == null || map.length == 0)
2378            return map;
2379        int width2 = Math.min(width, map.length), height2 = Math.min(height, map[0].length);
2380        for (int x = 0; x < width2; x++) {
2381            for (int y = 0; y < height2; y++) {
2382                if((data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] & (1L << (y & 63))) != 0)
2383                    map[x][y] = toWrite;
2384            }
2385        }
2386        return map;
2387    }

2452    /**
2453     * Union of two GreasedRegions, assigning the result into this GreasedRegion. Any cell that is "on" in either
2454     * GreasedRegion will be made "on" in this GreasedRegion.
2455     * @param other another GreasedRegion that will not be modified
2456     * @return this, after modification, for chaining
2457     */
2458    public GreasedRegion or(GreasedRegion other)
2459    {
2460        for (int x = 0; x < width && x < other.width; x++) {
2461            for (int y = 0; y < ySections && y < other.ySections; y++) {
2462                data[x * ySections + y] |= other.data[x * ySections + y];
2463            }
2464        }
2465
2466        if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
2467            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
2468                data[a] &= yEndMask;
2469            }
2470        }
2471        tallied = false;
2472
2473        return this;
2474    }

2476    /**
2477     * Intersection of two GreasedRegions, assigning the result into this GreasedRegion. Any cell that is "on" in both
2478     * GreasedRegions will be kept "on" in this GreasedRegion, but all other cells will be made "off."
2479     * @param other another GreasedRegion that will not be modified
2480     * @return this, after modification, for chaining
2481     */
2482    public GreasedRegion and(GreasedRegion other)
2483    {
2484        for (int x = 0; x < width && x < other.width; x++) {
2485            for (int y = 0; y < ySections && y < other.ySections; y++) {
2486                data[x * ySections + y] &= other.data[x * ySections + y];
2487            }
2488        }
2489        tallied = false;
2490        return this;
2491    }

2493    /**
2494     * Intersection of two GreasedRegions, assigning the result into this GreasedRegion, with the special requirement
2495     * that other must be a 64x64 area, and the special property that other will be considered tiled to cover all of the
2496     * area of this GreasedRegion. Any cell that is "on" in both GreasedRegions (treating other as tiling) will be kept
2497     * "on" in this GreasedRegion, but all other cells will be made "off."
2498     * @param other another GreasedRegion that will not be modified but must be 64x64 in size; will act as if it tiles
2499     * @return this, after modification, for chaining
2500     */
2501    public GreasedRegion andWrapping64(GreasedRegion other)
2502    {
2503        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
2504            for (int y = 0; y < ySections; y++) {
2505                data[x * ySections + y] &= other.data[x & 63];
2506            }
2507        }
2508        tallied = false;
2509        return this;
2510    }
2511    /**
2512     * Difference of two GreasedRegions, assigning the result into this GreasedRegion. Any cell that is "on" in this
2513     * GreasedRegion and "off" in other will be kept "on" in this GreasedRegion, but all other cells will be made "off."
2514     * @param other another GreasedRegion that will not be modified
2515     * @return this, after modification, for chaining
2516     * @see #notAnd(GreasedRegion) notAnd is a very similar method that acts sort-of in reverse of this method
2517     */
2518    public GreasedRegion andNot(GreasedRegion other)
2519    {
2520        for (int x = 0; x < width && x < other.width; x++) {
2521            for (int y = 0; y < ySections && y < other.ySections; y++) {
2522                data[x * ySections + y] &= ~other.data[x * ySections + y];
2523            }
2524        }
2525        tallied = false;
2526        return this;
2527    }

2529    /**
2530     * Like andNot, but subtracts this GreasedRegion from other and stores the result in this GreasedRegion, without
2531     * mutating other.
2532     * @param other another GreasedRegion that will not be modified
2533     * @return this, after modification, for chaining
2534     * @see #andNot(GreasedRegion) andNot is a very similar method that acts sort-of in reverse of this method
2535     */
2536    public GreasedRegion notAnd(GreasedRegion other)
2537    {
2538        for (int x = 0; x < width && x < other.width; x++) {
2539            for (int y = 0; y < ySections && y < other.ySections; y++) {
2540                data[x * ySections + y] = other.data[x * ySections + y] & ~data[x * ySections + y];
2541            }
2542        }
2543        tallied = false;
2544        return this;
2545    }

2547    /**
2548     * Symmetric difference (more commonly known as exclusive or, hence the name) of two GreasedRegions, assigning the
2549     * result into this GreasedRegion. Any cell that is "on" in this and "off" in other, or "off" in this and "on" in
2550     * other, will be made "on" in this; all other cells will be made "off." Useful to find cells that are "on" in
2551     * exactly one of two GreasedRegions (not "on" in both, or "off" in both).
2552     * @param other another GreasedRegion that will not be modified
2553     * @return this, after modification, for chaining
2554     */
2555    public GreasedRegion xor(GreasedRegion other)
2556    {
2557        for (int x = 0; x < width && x < other.width; x++) {
2558            for (int y = 0; y < ySections && y < other.ySections; y++) {
2559                data[x * ySections + y] ^= other.data[x * ySections + y];
2560            }
2561        }
2562
2563        if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
2564            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
2565                data[a] &= yEndMask;
2566            }
2567        }
2568        tallied = false;
2569        return this;
2570    }

2572    /**
2573     * Negates this GreasedRegion, turning "on" to "off" and "off" to "on."
2574     * @return this, after modification, for chaining
2575     */
2576    public GreasedRegion not()
2577    {
2578        for (int a = 0; a < data.length; a++)
2579        {
2580            data[a] = ~data[a];
2581        }
2582
2583        if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
2584            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
2585                data[a] &= yEndMask;
2586            }
2587        }
2588        tallied = false;
2589        return this;
2590    }

2592    /**
2593     * Moves the "on" cells in this GreasedRegion to the given x and y offset, removing cells that move out of bounds.
2594     * @param x the x offset to translate by; can be negative
2595     * @param y the y offset to translate by; can be negative
2596     * @return this for chaining
2597     */
2598    public GreasedRegion translate(int x, int y)
2599    {
2600        if(width < 1 || ySections <= 0 || (x == 0 && y == 0))
2601            return this;
2602        int start = Math.max(0, x), len = Math.min(width, width + x) - start,
2603                jump = (y == 0) ? 0 : (y < 0) ? -(-y >>> 6) : (y >>> 6), lily = (y < 0) ? -(-y & 63) : (y & 63),
2604                originalJump = Math.max(0, -jump), alterJump = Math.max(0, jump);
2605        long[] data2 = new long[width * ySections];
2606
2607        long prev, tmp;
2608        if (x < 0) {
2609            for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < ySections; i++, oi++) {
2610                for (int j = Math.max(0, -x), jj = 0; jj < len; j++, jj++) {
2611                    data2[jj * ySections + i] = data[j * ySections + oi];
2612                }
2613            }
2614        } else if (x > 0) {
2615            for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < ySections; i++, oi++) {
2616                for (int j = 0, jj = start; j < len; j++, jj++) {
2617                    data2[jj * ySections + i] = data[j * ySections + oi];
2618                }
2619            }
2620        } else {
2621            for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < ySections; i++, oi++) {
2622                for (int j = 0; j < len; j++) {
2623                    data2[j * ySections + i] = data[j * ySections + oi];
2624                }
2625            }
2626        }
2627
2628        if(lily < 0) {
2629            for (int i = start; i < len; i++) {
2630                prev = 0L;
2631                for (int j = 0; j < ySections; j++) {
2632                    tmp = prev;
2633                    prev = (data2[i * ySections + j] & ~(-1L << -lily)) << (64 + lily);
2634                    data2[i * ySections + j] >>>= -lily;
2635                    data2[i * ySections + j] |= tmp;
2636                }
2637            }
2638        }
2639        else if(lily > 0) {
2640            for (int i = start; i < start + len; i++) {
2641                prev = 0L;
2642                for (int j = 0; j < ySections; j++) {
2643                    tmp = prev;
2644                    prev = (data2[i * ySections + j] & ~(-1L >>> lily)) >>> (64 - lily);
2645                    data2[i * ySections + j] <<= lily;
2646                    data2[i * ySections + j] |= tmp;
2647                }
2648            }
2649        }
2650
2651
2652        if(yEndMask != -1) {
2653            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data2.length; a += ySections) {
2654                data2[a] &= yEndMask;
2655            }
2656        }
2657
2658        data = data2;
2659        tallied = false;
2660        return this;
2661    }
2662
2663    /**
2664     * Adds to this GreasedRegion with a moved set of its own "on" cells, moved to the given x and y offset.
2665     * Ignores cells that would be added out of bounds. Keeps all cells that are currently "on" unchanged.
2666     * @param x the x offset to translate by; can be negative
2667     * @param y the y offset to translate by; can be negative
2668     * @return this for chaining
2669     */
2670    public GreasedRegion insertTranslation(int x, int y)
2671    {
2672        if(width < 1 || ySections <= 0 || (x == 0 && y == 0))
2673            return this;
2674        int start = Math.max(0, x), len = Math.min(width, width + x) - start,
2675                jump = (y == 0) ? 0 : (y < 0) ? -(-y >>> 6) : (y >>> 6), lily = (y < 0) ? -(-y & 63) : (y & 63),
2676                originalJump = Math.max(0, -jump), alterJump = Math.max(0, jump);
2677        long[] data2 = new long[width * ySections];
2678        long prev, tmp;
2679        if (x < 0) {
2680            for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < ySections; i++, oi++) {
2681                for (int j = Math.max(0, -x), jj = 0; jj < len; j++, jj++) {
2682                    data2[jj * ySections + i] = data[j * ySections + oi];
2683                }
2684            }
2685        } else if (x > 0) {
2686            for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < ySections; i++, oi++) {
2687                for (int j = 0, jj = start; j < len; j++, jj++) {
2688                    data2[jj * ySections + i] = data[j * ySections + oi];
2689                }
2690            }
2691        } else {
2692            for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i < ySections && oi < ySections; i++, oi++) {
2693                for (int j = 0; j < len; j++) {
2694                    data2[j * ySections + i] = data[j * ySections + oi];
2695                }
2696            }
2697        }
2698
2699        if(lily < 0) {
2700            for (int i = start; i < len; i++) {
2701                prev = 0L;
2702                for (int j = 0; j < ySections; j++) {
2703                    tmp = prev;
2704                    prev = (data2[i * ySections + j] & ~(-1L << -lily)) << (64 + lily);
2705                    data2[i * ySections + j] >>>= -lily;
2706                    data2[i * ySections + j] |= tmp;
2707                }
2708            }
2709        }
2710        else if(lily > 0) {
2711            for (int i = start; i < start + len; i++) {
2712                prev = 0L;
2713                for (int j = 0; j < ySections; j++) {
2714                    tmp = prev;
2715                    prev = (data2[i * ySections + j] & ~(-1L >>> lily)) >>> (64 - lily);
2716                    data2[i * ySections + j] <<= lily;
2717                    data2[i * ySections + j] |= tmp;
2718                }
2719            }
2720        }
2721
2722        for (int i = 0; i < width * ySections; i++) {
2723            data2[i] |= data[i];
2724        }
2725
2726
2727        if(yEndMask != -1) {
2728            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data2.length; a += ySections) {
2729                data2[a] &= yEndMask;
2730            }
2731        }
2732
2733        data = data2;
2734        tallied = false;
2735        return this;
2736    }

2738    /**
2739     * Effectively doubles the x and y values of each cell this contains (not scaling each cell to be larger, so each
2740     * "on" cell will be surrounded by "off" cells), and re-maps the positions so the given x and y in the doubled space
2741     * become 0,0 in the resulting GreasedRegion (which is this, assigning to itself).
2742     * @param x in the doubled coordinate space, the x position that should become 0 x in the result; can be negative
2743     * @param y in the doubled coordinate space, the y position that should become 0 y in the result; can be negative
2744     * @return this for chaining
2745     */
2746    public GreasedRegion zoom(int x, int y)
2747    {
2748        if(width < 1 || ySections <= 0)
2749            return this;
2750        x = -x;
2751        y = -y;
2752        int
2753                width2 = width + 1 >>> 1, ySections2 = ySections + 1 >>> 1,
2754                start = Math.max(0, x), len = Math.min(width, width + x) - start,
2755                //tall = (Math.min(height, height + y) - Math.max(0, y)) + 63 >> 6,
2756                jump = (y == 0) ? 0 : (y < 0) ? -(-y >>> 6) : (y >>> 6), lily = (y < 0) ? -(-y & 63) : (y & 63),
2757                originalJump = Math.max(0, -jump), alterJump = Math.max(0, jump),
2758                oddX = (x & 1), oddY = (y & 1);
2759        long[] data2 = new long[width * ySections];
2760
2761        long prev, tmp, yEndMask2 = -1L >>> (64 - ((height + 1 >>> 1) & 63));
2762        if (x < 0) {
2763            for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i <= ySections2 && oi < ySections; i++, oi++) {
2764                for (int j = Math.max(0, -x), jj = 0; jj < len; j++, jj++) {
2765                    data2[jj * ySections + i] = data[j * ySections + oi];
2766                }
2767            }
2768        } else if (x > 0) {
2769            for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i <= ySections2 && oi < ySections; i++, oi++) {
2770                for (int j = 0, jj = start; j < len; j++, jj++) {
2771                    data2[jj * ySections + i] = data[j * ySections + oi];
2772                }
2773            }
2774        } else {
2775            for (int i = alterJump, oi = originalJump; i <= ySections2 && oi < ySections; i++, oi++) {
2776                for (int j = 0; j < len; j++) {
2777                    data2[j * ySections + i] = data[j * ySections + oi];
2778                }
2779            }
2780        }
2781
2782        if(lily < 0) {
2783            for (int i = start; i < len; i++) {
2784                prev = 0L;
2785                for (int j = ySections2; j >= 0; j--) {
2786                    tmp = prev;
2787                    prev = (data2[i * ySections + j] & ~(-1L << -lily)) << (64 + lily);
2788                    data2[i * ySections + j] >>>= -lily;
2789                    data2[i * ySections + j] |= tmp;
2790                }
2791            }
2792        }
2793        else if(lily > 0) {
2794            for (int i = start; i < start + len; i++) {
2795                prev = 0L;
2796                for (int j = 0; j < ySections2; j++) {
2797                    tmp = prev;
2798                    prev = (data2[i * ySections + j] & ~(-1L >>> lily)) >>> (64 - lily);
2799                    data2[i * ySections + j] <<= lily;
2800                    data2[i * ySections + j] |= tmp;
2801                }
2802            }
2803        }
2804
2805
2806        if(ySections2 > 0 && yEndMask2 != -1) {
2807            for (int a = ySections2 - 1; a < data2.length; a += ySections) {
2808                data2[a] &= yEndMask2;
2809                if(ySections2 < ySections)
2810                    data2[a+1] = 0L;
2811            }
2812        }
2813        for (int i = 0; i < width2; i++) {
2814            for (int j = 0; j < ySections2; j++) {
2815                prev = data2[i * ySections + j];
2816                tmp = prev >>> 32;
2817                prev &= 0xFFFFFFFFL;
2818                prev = (prev | (prev << 16)) & 0x0000FFFF0000FFFFL;
2819                prev = (prev | (prev << 8)) & 0x00FF00FF00FF00FFL;
2820                prev = (prev | (prev << 4)) & 0x0F0F0F0F0F0F0F0FL;
2821                prev = (prev | (prev << 2)) & 0x3333333333333333L;
2822                prev = (prev | (prev << 1)) & 0x5555555555555555L;
2823                prev <<= oddY;
2824                if(oddX == 1) {
2825                    if (i * 2 + 1 < width)
2826                        data[(i * ySections + j) * 2 + ySections] = prev;
2827                    if (i * 2 < width)
2828                        data[(i * ySections + j) * 2] = 0L;
2829                }
2830                else
2831                {
2832                    if (i * 2 < width)
2833                        data[(i * ySections + j) * 2] = prev;
2834                    if (i * 2 + 1 < width)
2835                        data[(i * ySections + j) * 2 + ySections] = 0L;
2836                }
2837                if(j * 2 + 1 < ySections) {
2838                    tmp = (tmp | (tmp << 16)) & 0x0000FFFF0000FFFFL;
2839                    tmp = (tmp | (tmp << 8)) & 0x00FF00FF00FF00FFL;
2840                    tmp = (tmp | (tmp << 4)) & 0x0F0F0F0F0F0F0F0FL;
2841                    tmp = (tmp | (tmp << 2)) & 0x3333333333333333L;
2842                    tmp = (tmp | (tmp << 1)) & 0x5555555555555555L;
2843                    tmp <<= oddY;
2844                    if(oddX == 1) {
2845                        if (i * 2 + 1 < width)
2846                            data[(i * ySections + j) * 2 + ySections + 1] = tmp;
2847                        if (i * 2 < width)
2848                            data[(i * ySections + j) * 2 + 1] = 0L;
2849                    }
2850                    else
2851                    {
2852                        if (i * 2 < width)
2853                            data[(i * ySections + j) * 2 + 1] = tmp;
2854                        if (i * 2 + 1 < width)
2855                            data[(i * ySections + j) * 2 + ySections + 1] = 0L;
2856                    }
2857                }
2858            }
2859        }
2860
2861        if(yEndMask != -1) {
2862            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < data.length; a += ySections) {
2863                data[a] &= yEndMask;
2864            }
2865        }
2866        tallied = false;
2867        return this;
2868    }

2870    /**
2871     * Takes the pairs of "on" cells in this GreasedRegion that are separated by exactly one cell in an orthogonal line,
2872     * and changes the gap cells to "on" as well.
2873     * <br>
2874     * This method is very efficient due to how the class is implemented, and the various spatial increase/decrease
2875     * methods (including {@link #expand()}, {@link #retract()}, {@link #fringe()}, and {@link #surface()}) all perform
2876     * very well by operating in bulk on up to 64 cells at a time.
2877     * @return this for chaining
2878     */
2879    public GreasedRegion connect()
2880    {
2881        if(width < 2 || ySections == 0)
2882            return this;
2883
2884        final long[] next = new long[width * ySections];
2885        System.arraycopy(data, 0, next, 0, width * ySections);
2886        for (int a = 0; a < ySections; a++) {
2887            next[a] |= ((data[a] << 1) & (data[a] >>> 1)) | data[a+ySections];
2888            next[(width-1)*ySections+a] |= ((data[(width-1)*ySections+a] << 1) & (data[(width-1)*ySections+a] >>> 1)) | data[(width-2) *ySections+a];
2889
2890            for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
2891                next[i] |= ((data[i] << 1) & (data[i] >>> 1)) | (data[i - ySections] & data[i + ySections]);
2892            }
2893
2894            if(a > 0) {
2895                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width-1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
2896                    next[i] |= (data[i - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63 & (data[i] >>> 1);
2897                }
2898            }
2899            else
2900            {
2901                for (int i = ySections; i < (width-1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
2902                    next[i] |= (data[i] >>> 1 & 1L);
2903                }
2904            }
2905
2906            if(a < ySections - 1) {
2907                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width-1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
2908                    next[i] |= (data[i + 1] & 1L) << 63 & (data[i] << 1);
2909                }
2910            }
2911            else
2912            {
2913                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width-1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
2914                    next[i] |= (data[i] << 1 & 0x8000000000000000L);
2915                }
2916
2917            }
2918        }
2919
2920        if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
2921            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < next.length; a += ySections) {
2922                next[a] &= yEndMask;
2923            }
2924        }
2925        data = next;
2926        tallied = false;
2927        return this;
2928    }
2929
2930    /**
2931     * Takes the pairs of "on" cells in this GreasedRegion that are separated by exactly one cell in an orthogonal or
2932     * diagonal line, and changes the gap cells to "on" as well.
2933     * <br>
2934     * This method is very efficient due to how the class is implemented, and the various spatial increase/decrease
2935     * methods (including {@link #expand()}, {@link #retract()}, {@link #fringe()}, and {@link #surface()}) all perform
2936     * very well by operating in bulk on up to 64 cells at a time.
2937     * @return this for chaining
2938     */
2939    public GreasedRegion connect8way()
2940    {
2941        if(width < 2 || ySections == 0)
2942            return this;
2943
2944        final long[] next = new long[width * ySections];
2945        System.arraycopy(data, 0, next, 0, width * ySections);
2946        for (int a = 0; a < ySections; a++) {
2947            next[a] |= ((data[a] << 1) & (data[a] >>> 1)) | data[a+ySections] | (data[a+ySections] << 1) | (data[a+ySections] >>> 1);
2948            next[(width-1)*ySections+a] |= ((data[(width-1)*ySections+a] << 1) & (data[(width-1)*ySections+a] >>> 1))
2949                    | data[(width-2) *ySections+a] | (data[(width-2)*ySections+a] << 1) | (data[(width-2)*ySections+a] >>> 1);
2950
2951            for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
2952                next[i] |= ((data[i] << 1) & (data[i] >>> 1)) | (data[i - ySections] & data[i + ySections])
2953                        | ((data[i - ySections] << 1) & (data[i + ySections] >>> 1))
2954                        | ((data[i + ySections] << 1) & (data[i - ySections] >>> 1));
2955            }
2956
2957            if(a > 0) {
2958                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width-1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
2959                    next[i] |= ((data[i - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63 & (data[i] >>> 1)) |
2960                            ((data[i - ySections - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63 & (data[i + ySections] >>> 1)) |
2961                            ((data[i + ySections - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63 & (data[i - ySections] >>> 1));
2962                }
2963            }
2964            else
2965            {
2966                for (int i = ySections; i < (width-1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
2967                    next[i] |= (data[i] >>> 1 & 1L) | (data[i - ySections] >>> 1 & 1L) | (data[i + ySections] >>> 1 & 1L);
2968                }
2969            }
2970
2971            if(a < ySections - 1) {
2972                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width-1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
2973                    next[i] |= ((data[i + 1] & 1L) << 63 & (data[i] << 1)) |
2974                            ((data[i - ySections + 1] & 1L) << 63 & (data[i + ySections] << 1)) |
2975                            ((data[i + ySections + 1] & 1L) << 63 & (data[i - ySections] << 1)) ;
2976                }
2977            }
2978            else
2979            {
2980                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width-1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
2981                    next[i] |= (data[i] << 1 & 0x8000000000000000L)
2982                            | (data[i - ySections] << 1 & 0x8000000000000000L) | (data[i + ySections] << 1 & 0x8000000000000000L);
2983                }
2984
2985            }
2986        }
2987
2988        if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
2989            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < next.length; a += ySections) {
2990                next[a] &= yEndMask;
2991            }
2992        }
2993        data = next;
2994        tallied = false;
2995        return this;
2996    }
2997    /**
2998     * Takes the pairs of "on" cells in this GreasedRegion that are separated by exactly one cell in an orthogonal or
2999     * diagonal line, and changes the gap cells to "on" as well. As a special case, this requires diagonals to either
3000     * have no "on" cells adjacent along the perpendicular diagonal, or both cells on that perpendicular diagonal need
3001     * to be "on." This is useful to counteract some less-desirable behavior of {@link #connect8way()}, where a right
3002     * angle would always get the inner corners filled because it was considered a diagonal.
3003     * <br>
3004     * This method is very efficient due to how the class is implemented, and the various spatial increase/decrease
3005     * methods (including {@link #expand()}, {@link #retract()}, {@link #fringe()}, and {@link #surface()}) all perform
3006     * very well by operating in bulk on up to 64 cells at a time.
3007     * @return this for chaining
3008     */
3009    public GreasedRegion connectLines()
3010    {
3011        if(width < 2 || ySections == 0)
3012            return this;
3013
3014        final long[] next = new long[width * ySections];
3015        System.arraycopy(data, 0, next, 0, width * ySections);
3016        for (int a = 0; a < ySections; a++) {
3017            next[a] |= ((data[a] << 1) & (data[a] >>> 1)) | data[a+ySections] | (data[a+ySections] << 1) | (data[a+ySections] >>> 1);
3018            next[(width-1)*ySections+a] |= ((data[(width-1)*ySections+a] << 1) & (data[(width-1)*ySections+a] >>> 1))
3019                    | data[(width-2) *ySections+a] | (data[(width-2)*ySections+a] << 1) | (data[(width-2)*ySections+a] >>> 1);
3020
3021            for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
3022                next[i] |= ((data[i] << 1) & (data[i] >>> 1)) | (data[i - ySections] & data[i + ySections])
3023                        | (((data[i - ySections] << 1) & (data[i + ySections] >>> 1))
3024                           ^ ((data[i + ySections] << 1) & (data[i - ySections] >>> 1)));
3025            }
3026
3027            if(a > 0) {
3028                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width-1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
3029                    next[i] |= ((data[i - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63 & (data[i] >>> 1))
3030                            | (((data[i - ySections - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63 & (data[i + ySections] >>> 1))
3031                               ^ ((data[i + ySections - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63 & (data[i - ySections] >>> 1)));
3032                }
3033            }
3034            else
3035            {
3036                for (int i = ySections; i < (width-1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
3037                    next[i] |= (data[i] >>> 1 & 1L) | (data[i - ySections] >>> 1 & 1L) | (data[i + ySections] >>> 1 & 1L);
3038                }
3039            }
3040
3041            if(a < ySections - 1) {
3042                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width-1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
3043                    next[i] |= ((data[i + 1] & 1L) << 63 & (data[i] << 1))
3044                            | (((data[i - ySections + 1] & 1L) << 63 & (data[i + ySections] << 1))
3045                               ^ ((data[i + ySections + 1] & 1L) << 63 & (data[i - ySections] << 1)));
3046                }
3047            }
3048            else
3049            {
3050                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width-1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
3051                    next[i] |= (data[i] << 1 & 0x8000000000000000L)
3052                            | (data[i - ySections] << 1 & 0x8000000000000000L) | (data[i + ySections] << 1 & 0x8000000000000000L);
3053                }
3054
3055            }
3056        }
3057
3058        if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
3059            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < next.length; a += ySections) {
3060                next[a] &= yEndMask;
3061            }
3062        }
3063        data = next;
3064        tallied = false;
3065        return this;
3066    }
3067
3068    /**
3069     * Like {@link #retract()}, this reduces the width of thick areas of this GreasedRegion, but thin() will not remove
3070     * areas that would be identical in a subsequent call to retract(), such as if the area would be eliminated. This
3071     * is useful primarily for adjusting areas so they do not exceed a width of 2 cells, though their length (the longer
3072     * of the two dimensions) will be unaffected by this. Especially wide, irregularly-shaped areas may have unintended
3073     * appearances if you call this repeatedly or use {@link #thinFully()}; consider using this sparingly, or primarily
3074     * when an area has just gotten thicker than desired.
3075     * <br>
3076     * This currently uses 4-way adjacency, but had previously used 8-way; if you want the behavior this previously had,
3077     * you can use {@link #thin8way()}, but it may be a good idea to try this method as well (some of the old behavior
3078     * had problems where it yielded significantly larger minimum widths in some areas).
3079     * @return this for chaining
3080     */
3081    public GreasedRegion thin()
3082    {
3083        if(width <= 2 || ySections <= 0)
3084            return this;
3085        GreasedRegion c1 = new GreasedRegion(this).retract(),
3086                c2 = new GreasedRegion(c1).expand().xor(this).expand().and(this);
3087        remake(c1).or(c2);
3088        /*
3089        System.out.println("\n\nc1:\n" + c1.toString() + "\n");
3090        System.out.println("\n\nc2:\n" + c2.toString() + "\n");
3091        System.out.println("\n\nthis:\n" + toString() + "\n");
3092        */
3093        return this;
3094    }

3096    /**
3097     * Calls {@link #thin()} repeatedly, until the result is unchanged from the last call. Consider using the idiom
3098     * {@code expand8way().retract().thinFully()} to help change a possibly-strange appearance when the GreasedRegion
3099     * this is called on touches the edges of the grid. In general, this method is likely to go too far when it tries to
3100     * thin a round or irregular area, and this often results in many diagonal lines spanning the formerly-thick area.
3101     * <br>
3102     * This currently uses 4-way adjacency, but had previously used 8-way; if you want the behavior this previously had,
3103     * you can use {@link #thinFully8way()}, but it may be a good idea to try this method as well (some of the old
3104     * behavior had problems where it yielded significantly larger minimum widths in some areas).
3105     * @return this for chaining
3106     */
3107    public GreasedRegion thinFully()
3108    {
3109        while (size() != thin().size());
3110        return this;
3111    }

3114    /**
3115     * Like {@link #retract8way()}, this reduces the width of thick areas of this GreasedRegion, but thin8way() will not
3116     * remove areas that would be identical in a subsequent call to retract8way(), such as if the area would be
3117     * eliminated. This is useful primarily for adjusting areas so they do not exceed a width of 2 cells, though their
3118     * length (the longer of the two dimensions) will be unaffected by this. Especially wide, irregularly-shaped areas
3119     * may have unintended appearances if you call this repeatedly or use {@link #thinFully8way()}; consider using this
3120     * sparingly, or primarily when an area has just gotten thicker than desired.
3121     * <br>
3122     * This method was called {@link #thin()}, but now that name refers to a variant that uses 4-way adjacency.
3123     * @return this for chaining
3124     */
3125    public GreasedRegion thin8way()
3126    {
3127        if(width <= 2 || ySections <= 0)
3128            return this;
3129        GreasedRegion c1 = new GreasedRegion(this).retract8way(),
3130                c2 = new GreasedRegion(c1).expand8way().xor(this).expand8way().and(this);
3131        remake(c1).or(c2);
3132        return this;
3133    }

3135    /**
3136     * Calls {@link #thin8way()} repeatedly, until the result is unchanged from the last call. Consider using the idiom
3137     * {@code expand8way().retract().thinFully8way()} to help change a strange appearance when the GreasedRegion this is
3138     * called on touches the edges of the grid. In general, this method is likely to go too far when it tries to thin a
3139     * round or irregular area, and this often results in many diagonal lines spanning the formerly-thick area.
3140     * <br>
3141     * This method was called {@link #thinFully()}, but now that name refers to a variant that uses 4-way adjacency.
3142     * @return this for chaining
3143     */
3144    public GreasedRegion thinFully8way()
3145    {
3146        while (size() != thin8way().size());
3147        return this;

3151    /**
3152     * Removes "on" cells that are orthogonally adjacent to other "on" cells, keeping at least one cell in a group "on."
3153     * Uses a "checkerboard" pattern to determine which cells to turn  off, with all cells that would be black on a
3154     * checkerboard turned off and all others kept as-is.
3155     * @return this for chaining
3156     */
3157    public GreasedRegion disperse()
3158    {
3159        if(width < 1 || ySections <= 0)
3160            return this;
3161        long mask = 0x5555555555555555L;
3162        for (int i = 0; i < width; i++) {
3163            for (int j = 0; j < ySections; j++) {
3164                data[j] &= mask;
3165            }
3166            mask = ~mask;
3167        }
3168        tallied = false;
3169        return this;
3170    }
3171    /**
3172     * Removes "on" cells that are 8-way adjacent to other "on" cells, keeping at least one cell in a group "on."
3173     * Uses a "grid-like" pattern to determine which cells to turn off, with all cells with even x and even y kept as-is
3174     * but all other cells (with either or both odd x or odd y) turned off.
3175     * @return this for chaining
3176     */
3177    public GreasedRegion disperse8way()
3178    {
3179        if(width < 1 || ySections <= 0)
3180            return this;
3181        int len = data.length;
3182        long mask = 0x5555555555555555L;
3183        for (int j = 0; j < len - 1; j += 2) {
3184            data[j] &= mask;
3185            data[j+1] = 0;
3186        }
3187        tallied = false;
3188        return this;
3189    }
3190    /**
3191     * Removes "on" cells that are nearby other "on" cells, with a random factor to which bits are actually turned off
3192     * that still ensures exactly half of the bits are kept as-is (the one exception is when height is an odd number,
3193     * which makes the bottom row slightly random).
3194     * @param random the RNG used for a random factor
3195     * @return this for chaining
3196     */
3197    public GreasedRegion disperseRandom(RandomnessSource random)
3198    {
3199        if(width < 1 || ySections <= 0)
3200            return this;
3201        int len = data.length;
3202        for (int j = 0; j < len; j++) {
3203            data[j] &= randomInterleave(random);
3204        }
3205        tallied = false;
3206        return this;
3207    }
3208    /**
3209     * Generates a random 64-bit long with a number of '1' bits (Hamming weight) equal on average to bitCount.
3210     * For example, calling this with a parameter of 32 will be equivalent to calling nextLong() on the given
3211     * RandomnessSource, which could be an {@link RNG} or any RandomnessSource with good 64-bit generation quality.
3212     * Calling this with a parameter of 16 will have on average 16 of the 64 bits in the returned long set to '1',
3213     * distributed pseudo-randomly, while a parameter of 47 will have on average 47 bits set. This can be useful for
3214     * certain code that uses bits to represent data but needs a different ratio of set bits to unset bits than 1:1.
3215     * <br>
3216     * The parameter {@code random} can be an object like a {@link DiverRNG}, an {@link RNG} backed by a
3217     * well-distributed RandomnessSource like its default, DiverRNG, a {@link GWTRNG} (especially if you target GWT,
3218     * where it will perform much better than most alternatives), or any of various other RandomnessSource
3219     * implementations that distribute bits well for {@link RandomnessSource#nextLong()}, but should not be
3220     * intentionally-biased RNGs like {@link DharmaRNG} or {@link EditRNG}, nor double-based QRNGs like
3221     * {@link VanDerCorputQRNG} or {@link SobolQRNG}.
3222     * @param random used to determine random factors; likely to be an {@link RNG}, {@link DiverRNG}, or {@link GWTRNG}
3223     * @param bitCount an int, only considered if between 0 and 64, that is the average number of bits to set
3224     * @return a 64-bit long that, on average, should have bitCount bits set to 1, potentially anywhere in the long
3225     */
3226    public static long approximateBits(RandomnessSource random, int bitCount) {
3227        if (bitCount <= 0)
3228            return 0L;
3229        if (bitCount >= 64)
3230            return -1L;
3231        if (bitCount == 32)
3232            return random.nextLong();
3233        boolean high = bitCount > 32;
3234        int altered = (high ? 64 - bitCount : bitCount), lsb = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(altered);
3235        long data = random.nextLong();
3236        for (int i = lsb << 1; i <= 16; i <<= 1) {
3237            if ((altered & i) == 0)
3238                data &= random.nextLong();
3239            else
3240                data |= random.nextLong();
3241        }
3242        return high ? ~(random.nextLong() & data) : (random.nextLong() & data);
3243    }
3244
3245    /**
3246     * Gets a somewhat-random long with exactly 32 bits set; in each pair of bits starting at bit 0 and bit 1, then bit
3247     * 2 and bit 3, up to bit 62 and bit 3, one bit will be 1 and one bit will be 0 in each pair.
3248     * <br>
3249     * Not exactly general-use; meant for generating data for GreasedRegion.
3250     * @return a random long with 32 "1" bits, distributed so exactly one bit is "1" for each pair of bits
3251     */
3252    public static long randomInterleave(RandomnessSource random) {
3253        long bits = random.nextLong() & 0xFFFFFFFFL, ib = ~bits & 0xFFFFFFFFL;
3254        bits |= (bits << 16);
3255        ib |= (ib << 16);
3256        bits &= 0x0000FFFF0000FFFFL;
3257        ib &= 0x0000FFFF0000FFFFL;
3258        bits |= (bits << 8);
3259        ib |= (ib << 8);
3260        bits &= 0x00FF00FF00FF00FFL;
3261        ib &= 0x00FF00FF00FF00FFL;
3262        bits |= (bits << 4);
3263        ib |= (ib << 4);
3264        bits &= 0x0F0F0F0F0F0F0F0FL;
3265        ib &= 0x0F0F0F0F0F0F0F0FL;
3266        bits |= (bits << 2);
3267        ib |= (ib << 2);
3268        bits &= 0x3333333333333333L;
3269        ib &= 0x3333333333333333L;
3270        bits |= (bits << 1);
3271        ib |= (ib << 1);
3272        bits &= 0x5555555555555555L;
3273        ib &= 0x5555555555555555L;
3274        return (bits | (ib << 1));
3275    }

3277    /**
3278     * Takes the "on" cells in this GreasedRegion and expands them by one cell in the 4 orthogonal directions, making
3279     * each "on" cell take up a plus-shaped area that may overlap with other "on" cells (which is just a normal "on"
3280     * cell then).
3281     * <br>
3282     * This method is very efficient due to how the class is implemented, and the various spatial increase/decrease
3283     * methods (including {@link #expand()}, {@link #retract()}, {@link #fringe()}, and {@link #surface()}) all perform
3284     * very well by operating in bulk on up to 64 cells at a time.
3285     * @return this for chaining
3286     */
3287    public GreasedRegion expand()
3288    {
3289        if(width < 2 || ySections == 0)
3290            return this;
3291
3292        final long[] next = new long[width * ySections];
3293        System.arraycopy(data, 0, next, 0, width * ySections);
3294        for (int a = 0; a < ySections; a++) {
3295            next[a] |= (data[a] << 1) | (data[a] >>> 1) | data[a+ySections];
3296            next[(width-1)*ySections+a] |= (data[(width-1)*ySections+a] << 1) | (data[(width-1)*ySections+a] >>> 1) | data[(width-2) *ySections+a];
3297
3298            for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
3299                next[i] |= (data[i] << 1) | (data[i] >>> 1) | data[i - ySections] | data[i + ySections];
3300            }
3301
3302            if(a > 0) {
3303                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width-1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
3304                    next[i] |= (data[i - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63;
3305                }
3306            }
3307
3308            if(a < ySections - 1) {
3309                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width-1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
3310                    next[i] |= (data[i + 1] & 1L) << 63;
3311                }
3312            }
3313        }
3314
3315        if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
3316            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < next.length; a += ySections) {
3317                next[a] &= yEndMask;
3318            }
3319        }
3320        data = next;
3321        tallied = false;
3322        return this;
3323    }
3324    /**
3325     * Takes the "on" cells in this GreasedRegion and expands them by amount cells in the 4 orthogonal directions,
3326     * making each "on" cell take up a plus-shaped area that may overlap with other "on" cells (which is just a normal
3327     * "on" cell then).
3328     * <br>
3329     * This method is very efficient due to how the class is implemented, and the various spatial increase/decrease
3330     * methods (including {@link #expand()}, {@link #retract()}, {@link #fringe()}, and {@link #surface()}) all perform
3331     * very well by operating in bulk on up to 64 cells at a time.
3332     * @return this for chaining
3333     */
3334    @Override
3335    public GreasedRegion expand(int amount)
3336    {
3337        for (int i = 0; i < amount; i++) {
3338            expand();
3339        }
3340        return this;
3341    }
3342    /**
3343     * Takes the "on" cells in this GreasedRegion and produces amount GreasedRegions, each one expanded by 1 cell in
3344     * the 4 orthogonal directions relative to the previous GreasedRegion, making each "on" cell take up a plus-shaped
3345     * area that may overlap with other "on" cells (which is just a normal "on" cell then). This returns an array of
3346     * GreasedRegions with progressively greater expansions, and does not modify this GreasedRegion.
3347     * <br>
3348     * This method is very efficient due to how the class is implemented, and the various spatial increase/decrease
3349     * methods (including {@link #expand()}, {@link #retract()}, {@link #fringe()}, and {@link #surface()}) all perform
3350     * very well by operating in bulk on up to 64 cells at a time.
3351     * @return an array of new GreasedRegions, length == amount, where each one is expanded by 1 relative to the last
3352     */
3353    public GreasedRegion[] expandSeries(int amount)
3354    {
3355        if(amount <= 0) return new GreasedRegion[0];
3356        GreasedRegion[] regions = new GreasedRegion[amount];
3357        GreasedRegion temp = new GreasedRegion(this);
3358        for (int i = 0; i < amount; i++) {
3359            regions[i] = new GreasedRegion(temp.expand());
3360        }
3361        return regions;
3362    }

3368        while (temp.size() != temp.expand().size()) {
3369            regions.add(new GreasedRegion(temp));

3373    /**
3374     * Takes the "on" cells in this GreasedRegion and expands them by one cell in the 4 orthogonal directions, producing
3375     * a diamoond shape, then removes the original area before expansion, producing only the cells that were "off" in
3376     * this and within 1 cell (orthogonal-only) of an "on" cell. This method is similar to {@link #surface()}, but
3377     * surface finds cells inside the current GreasedRegion, while fringe finds cells outside it.
3378     * <br>
3379     * This method is very efficient due to how the class is implemented, and the various spatial increase/decrease
3380     * methods (including {@link #expand()}, {@link #retract()}, {@link #fringe()}, and {@link #surface()}) all perform
3381     * very well by operating in bulk on up to 64 cells at a time. The surface and fringe methods do allocate one
3382     * temporary GreasedRegion to store the original before modification, but the others generally don't.
3383     * @return this for chaining
3384     */
3385    public GreasedRegion fringe()
3386    {
3387        GreasedRegion cpy = new GreasedRegion(this);
3388        expand();
3389        return andNot(cpy);
3390    }
3391    /**
3392     * Takes the "on" cells in this GreasedRegion and expands them by amount cells in the 4 orthogonal directions
3393     * (iteratively, producing a diamond shape), then removes the original area before expansion, producing only the
3394     * cells that were "off" in this and within amount cells (orthogonal-only) of an "on" cell. This method is similar
3395     * to {@link #surface()}, but surface finds cells inside the current GreasedRegion, while fringe finds cells outside
3396     * it.
3397     * <br>
3398     * This method is very efficient due to how the class is implemented, and the various spatial increase/decrease
3399     * methods (including {@link #expand()}, {@link #retract()}, {@link #fringe()}, and {@link #surface()}) all perform
3400     * very well by operating in bulk on up to 64 cells at a time. The surface and fringe methods do allocate one
3401     * temporary GreasedRegion to store the original before modification, but the others generally don't.
3402     * @return this for chaining
3403     */
3404
3405    public GreasedRegion fringe(int amount)
3406    {
3407        GreasedRegion cpy = new GreasedRegion(this);
3408        expand(amount);
3409        return andNot(cpy);
3410    }

3412    /**
3413     * Takes the "on" cells in this GreasedRegion and produces amount GreasedRegions, each one expanded by 1 cell in
3414     * the 4 orthogonal directions relative to the previous GreasedRegion, making each "on" cell take up a diamond-
3415     * shaped area. After producing the expansions, this removes the previous GreasedRegion from the next GreasedRegion
3416     * in the array, making each "fringe" in the series have 1 "thickness," which can be useful for finding which layer
3417     * of expansion a cell lies in. This returns an array of GreasedRegions with progressively greater expansions
3418     * without the cells of this GreasedRegion, and does not modify this GreasedRegion.
3419     * <br>
3420     * This method is very efficient due to how the class is implemented, and the various spatial increase/decrease
3421     * methods (including {@link #expand()}, {@link #retract()}, {@link #fringe()}, and {@link #surface()}) all perform
3422     * very well by operating in bulk on up to 64 cells at a time.
3423     * @return an array of new GreasedRegions, length == amount, where each one is a 1-depth fringe pushed further out from this
3424     */
3425    public GreasedRegion[] fringeSeries(int amount)
3426    {
3427        if(amount <= 0) return new GreasedRegion[0];
3428        GreasedRegion[] regions = new GreasedRegion[amount];
3429        GreasedRegion temp = new GreasedRegion(this);
3430        regions[0] = new GreasedRegion(temp);
3431        for (int i = 1; i < amount; i++) {
3432            regions[i] = new GreasedRegion(temp.expand());
3433        }
3434        for (int i = 0; i < amount - 1; i++) {
3435            regions[i].xor(regions[i + 1]);
3436        }
3437        regions[amount - 1].fringe();
3438        return regions;
3439    }
3440    public ArrayList<GreasedRegion> fringeSeriesToLimit()
3441    {
3442        ArrayList<GreasedRegion> regions = expandSeriesToLimit();
3443        for (int i = regions.size() - 1; i > 0; i--) {
3444            regions.get(i).xor(regions.get(i-1));
3445        }
3446        regions.get(0).xor(this);
3447        return regions;
3448    }

3450    /**
3451     * Takes the "on" cells in this GreasedRegion and retracts them by one cell in the 4 orthogonal directions,
3452     * making each "on" cell that was orthogonally adjacent to an "off" cell into an "off" cell.
3453     * <br>
3454     * This method is very efficient due to how the class is implemented, and the various spatial increase/decrease
3455     * methods (including {@link #expand()}, {@link #retract()}, {@link #fringe()}, and {@link #surface()}) all perform
3456     * very well by operating in bulk on up to 64 cells at a time.
3457     * @return this for chaining
3458     */
3459    public GreasedRegion retract()
3460    {
3461        if(width <= 2 || ySections <= 0)
3462            return this;
3463
3464        final long[] next = new long[width * ySections];
3465        System.arraycopy(data, ySections, next, ySections, (width - 2) * ySections);
3466        for (int a = 0; a < ySections; a++) {
3467            if(a > 0 && a < ySections - 1) {
3468                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
3469                    next[i] &= ((data[i] << 1) | ((data[i - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63))
3470                            & ((data[i] >>> 1) | ((data[i + 1] & 1L) << 63))
3471                            & data[i - ySections]
3472                            & data[i + ySections];
3473                }
3474            }
3475            else if(a > 0) {
3476                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
3477                    next[i] &= ((data[i] << 1) | ((data[i - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63))
3478                            & (data[i] >>> 1)
3479                            & data[i - ySections]
3480                            & data[i + ySections];
3481                }
3482            }
3483            else if(a < ySections - 1) {
3484                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
3485                    next[i] &= (data[i] << 1)
3486                            & ((data[i] >>> 1) | ((data[i + 1] & 1L) << 63))
3487                            & data[i - ySections]
3488                            & data[i + ySections];
3489                }
3490            }
3491            else // only the case when ySections == 1
3492            {
3493                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
3494                    next[i] &= (data[i] << 1) & (data[i] >>> 1) & data[i - ySections] & data[i + ySections];
3495                }
3496            }
3497        }
3498
3499        if(yEndMask != -1) {
3500            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < next.length; a += ySections) {
3501                next[a] &= yEndMask;
3502            }
3503        }
3504        data = next;
3505        tallied = false;
3506        return this;
3507    }

3511     * this iteeratively amount times, making each "on" cell that was within amount orthogonal distance to an "off" cell
3512     * into an "off" cell.
3513     * <br>
3514     * This method is very efficient due to how the class is implemented, and the various spatial increase/decrease
3515     * methods (including {@link #expand()}, {@link #retract()}, {@link #fringe()}, and {@link #surface()}) all perform
3516     * very well by operating in bulk on up to 64 cells at a time.
3517     * @return this for chaining
3518     */
3519    public GreasedRegion retract(int amount)
3520    {
3521        for (int i = 0; i < amount; i++) {
3522            retract();
3523        }
3524        return this;
3525    }

3559    public GreasedRegion[] surfaceSeries(int amount)
3560    {
3561        if(amount <= 0) return new GreasedRegion[0];
3562        GreasedRegion[] regions = new GreasedRegion[amount];
3563        GreasedRegion temp = new GreasedRegion(this);
3564        regions[0] = new GreasedRegion(temp);
3565        for (int i = 1; i < amount; i++) {
3566            regions[i] = new GreasedRegion(temp.retract());
3567        }
3568        for (int i = 0; i < amount - 1; i++) {
3569            regions[i].xor(regions[i + 1]);
3570        }
3571        regions[amount - 1].surface();
3572        return regions;
3573    }
3574
3575    public ArrayList<GreasedRegion> surfaceSeriesToLimit()
3576    {
3577        ArrayList<GreasedRegion> regions = retractSeriesToLimit();
3578        if(regions.isEmpty())
3579            return regions;
3580        regions.add(0, regions.get(0).copy().xor(this));
3581        for (int i = 1; i < regions.size() - 1; i++) {
3582            regions.get(i).xor(regions.get(i+1));
3583        }
3584        return regions;
3585    }
3586    public GreasedRegion expand8way()
3587    {
3588        if(width < 2 || ySections <= 0)
3589            return this;
3590
3591        final long[] next = new long[width * ySections];
3592        System.arraycopy(data, 0, next, 0, width * ySections);
3593        for (int a = 0; a < ySections; a++) {
3594            next[a] |= (data[a] << 1) | (data[a] >>> 1)
3595                    | data[a+ySections] | (data[a+ySections] << 1) | (data[a+ySections] >>> 1);
3596            next[(width-1)*ySections+a] |= (data[(width-1)*ySections+a] << 1) | (data[(width-1)*ySections+a] >>> 1)
3597                    | data[(width-2) *ySections+a] | (data[(width-2)*ySections+a] << 1) | (data[(width-2)*ySections+a] >>> 1);
3598
3599            for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
3600                next[i] |= (data[i] << 1) | (data[i] >>> 1)
3601                        | data[i - ySections] | (data[i - ySections] << 1) | (data[i - ySections] >>> 1)
3602                        | data[i + ySections] | (data[i + ySections] << 1) | (data[i + ySections] >>> 1);
3603            }
3604
3605            if(a > 0) {
3606                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width-1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
3607                    next[i] |= ((data[i - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63) |
3608                            ((data[i - ySections - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63) |
3609                            ((data[i + ySections - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63);
3610                }
3611            }
3612
3613            if(a < ySections - 1) {
3614                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width-1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
3615                    next[i] |= ((data[i + 1] & 1L) << 63) |
3616                            ((data[i - ySections + 1] & 1L) << 63) |
3617                            ((data[i + ySections+ 1] & 1L) << 63);
3618                }
3619            }
3620        }
3621
3622        if(ySections > 0 && yEndMask != -1) {
3623            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < next.length; a += ySections) {
3624                next[a] &= yEndMask;
3625            }
3626        }
3627        data = next;
3628        tallied = false;
3629        return this;
3630    }
3631
3632    @Override
3633    public GreasedRegion expand8way(int amount)
3634    {
3635        for (int i = 0; i < amount; i++) {
3636            expand8way();
3637        }
3638        return this;
3639    }
