3699    public GreasedRegion retract8way()
3700    {
3701        if(width <= 2 || ySections <= 0)
3702            return this;
3703
3704        final long[] next = new long[width * ySections];
3705        System.arraycopy(data, ySections, next, ySections, (width - 2) * ySections);
3706        for (int a = 0; a < ySections; a++) {
3707            if(a > 0 && a < ySections - 1) {
3708                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
3709                    next[i] &= ((data[i] << 1) | ((data[i - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63))
3710                            & ((data[i] >>> 1) | ((data[i + 1] & 1L) << 63))
3711                            & data[i - ySections]
3712                            & data[i + ySections]
3713                            & ((data[i - ySections] << 1) | ((data[i - 1 - ySections] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63))
3714                            & ((data[i + ySections] << 1) | ((data[i - 1 + ySections] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63))
3715                            & ((data[i - ySections] >>> 1) | ((data[i + 1 - ySections] & 1L) << 63))
3716                            & ((data[i + ySections] >>> 1) | ((data[i + 1 + ySections] & 1L) << 63));
3717                }
3718            }
3719            else if(a > 0) {
3720                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
3721                    next[i] &= ((data[i] << 1) | ((data[i - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63))
3722                            & (data[i] >>> 1)
3723                            & data[i - ySections]
3724                            & data[i + ySections]
3725                            & ((data[i - ySections] << 1) | ((data[i - 1 - ySections] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63))
3726                            & ((data[i + ySections] << 1) | ((data[i - 1 + ySections] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63))
3727                            & (data[i - ySections] >>> 1)
3728                            & (data[i + ySections] >>> 1);
3729                }
3730            }
3731            else if(a < ySections - 1) {
3732                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
3733                    next[i] &= (data[i] << 1)
3734                            & ((data[i] >>> 1) | ((data[i + 1] & 1L) << 63))
3735                            & data[i - ySections]
3736                            & data[i + ySections]
3737                            & (data[i - ySections] << 1)
3738                            & (data[i + ySections] << 1)
3739                            & ((data[i - ySections] >>> 1) | ((data[i + 1 - ySections] & 1L) << 63))
3740                            & ((data[i + ySections] >>> 1) | ((data[i + 1 + ySections] & 1L) << 63));
3741                }
3742            }
3743            else // only the case when ySections == 1
3744            {
3745                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
3746                    next[i] &= (data[i] << 1)
3747                            & (data[i] >>> 1)
3748                            & data[i - ySections]
3749                            & data[i + ySections]
3750                            & (data[i - ySections] << 1)
3751                            & (data[i + ySections] << 1)
3752                            & (data[i - ySections] >>> 1)
3753                            & (data[i + ySections] >>> 1);
3754                }
3755            }
3756        }
3757
3758        if(yEndMask != -1) {
3759            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < next.length; a += ySections) {
3760                next[a] &= yEndMask;
3761            }
3762        }
3763        data = next;
3764        tallied = false;
3765        return this;
3766    }

3771            retract8way();

3774    }

3835    public GreasedRegion flood(GreasedRegion bounds)
3836    {
3837        if(width < 2 || ySections <= 0 || bounds == null || bounds.width < 2 || bounds.ySections <= 0)
3838            return this;
3839
3840        final long[] next = new long[width * ySections];
3841        for (int a = 0; a < ySections && a < bounds.ySections; a++) {
3842            next[a] |= (data[a] |(data[a] << 1) | (data[a] >>> 1) | data[a+ySections]) & bounds.data[a];
3843            next[(width-1)*ySections+a] |= (data[(width-1)*ySections+a] | (data[(width-1)*ySections+a] << 1)
3844                    | (data[(width-1)*ySections+a] >>> 1) | data[(width-2) *ySections+a]) & bounds.data[(width-1)*bounds.ySections+a];
3845
3846            for (int i = ySections+a, j = bounds.ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections &&
3847                    j < (bounds.width - 1) * bounds.ySections; i+= ySections, j+= bounds.ySections) {
3848                next[i] |= (data[i] | (data[i] << 1) | (data[i] >>> 1) | data[i - ySections] | data[i + ySections]) & bounds.data[j];
3849            }
3850
3851            if(a > 0) {
3852                for (int i = ySections+a, j = bounds.ySections+a; i < (width-1) * ySections && j < (bounds.width-1) * bounds.ySections;
3853                     i+= ySections, j += bounds.ySections) {
3854                    next[i] |= (data[i] | ((data[i - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63)) & bounds.data[j];
3855                }
3856            }
3857
3858            if(a < ySections - 1 && a < bounds.ySections - 1) {
3859                for (int i = ySections+a, j = bounds.ySections+a;
3860                     i < (width-1) * ySections && j < (bounds.width-1) * bounds.ySections; i+= ySections, j += bounds.ySections) {
3861                    next[i] |= (data[i] | ((data[i + 1] & 1L) << 63)) & bounds.data[j];
3862                }
3863            }
3864        }
3865
3866        if(yEndMask != -1 && bounds.yEndMask != -1) {
3867            if(ySections == bounds.ySections) {
3868                long mask = ((yEndMask >>> 1) <= (bounds.yEndMask >>> 1))
3869                        ? yEndMask : bounds.yEndMask;
3870                for (int a = ySections - 1; a < next.length; a += ySections) {
3871                    next[a] &= mask;
3872                }
3873            }
3874            else if(ySections < bounds.ySections) {
3875                for (int a = ySections - 1; a < next.length; a += ySections) {
3876                    next[a] &= yEndMask;
3877                }
3878            }
3879            else {
3880                for (int a = bounds.ySections - 1; a < next.length; a += ySections) {
3881                    next[a] &= bounds.yEndMask;
3882                }
3883            }
3884        }
3885        data = next;
3886        tallied = false;
3887        return this;
3888    }

3890    public GreasedRegion flood(GreasedRegion bounds, int amount)
3891    {
3892        int ct = size(), ct2;
3893        for (int i = 0; i < amount; i++) {
3894            flood(bounds);
3895            if(ct == (ct2 = size()))
3896                break;
3897            else
3898                ct = ct2;
3899
3900        }
3901        return this;
3902    }

3946
3947        final long[] next = new long[width * ySections];
3948        for (int a = 0; a < ySections && a < bounds.ySections; a++) {
3949            next[a] |= (data[a] | (data[a] << 1) | (data[a] >>> 1)
3950                    | data[a+ySections] | (data[a+ySections] << 1) | (data[a+ySections] >>> 1)) & bounds.data[a];
3951            next[(width-1)*ySections+a] |= (data[(width-1)*ySections+a]
3952                    | (data[(width-1)*ySections+a] << 1) | (data[(width-1)*ySections+a] >>> 1)

3978                            ((data[i + ySections+ 1] & 1L) << 63)) & bounds.data[j];
3979                }
3980            }
3981        }

3988                    next[a] &= mask;
3989                }
3990            }
3991            else if(ySections < bounds.ySections) {

3994                }

4055    public GreasedRegion spill(GreasedRegion bounds, int volume, IRNG rng)
4056    {
4057        if(width < 2 || ySections <= 0 || bounds == null || bounds.width < 2 || bounds.ySections <= 0)
4058            return this;
4059        int current = size();
4060        if(current >= volume)
4061            return this;
4062        GreasedRegion t = new GreasedRegion(this).notAnd(bounds);
4063        long[] b2 = new long[t.data.length];
4064        System.arraycopy(t.data, 0, b2, 0, b2.length);
4065        t.remake(this).fringe().and(bounds).tally();
4066        if(t.ct <= 0)
4067            return this;
4068        Coord c;
4069        int x, y, p;
4070        for (int i = current; i < volume; i++) {
4071            c = t.singleRandom(rng);
4072            x = c.x;
4073            y = c.y;
4074            if(data[p = x * ySections + (y >> 6)] != (data[p] |= 1L << (y & 63)))
4075            {
4076                counts[p]++;
4077                for (int j = p+1; j < data.length; j++) {
4078                    if(counts[j] > 0) ++counts[j];
4079                }
4080                ct++;
4081                t.data[p] &= ~(1L << (y & 63));
4082//                b2[p] &= ~(1L << (y & 63));
4083                if(x < width - 1 && (b2[p = (x+1) * ySections + (y >> 6)] & 1L << (y & 63)) != 0)
4084                {
4085                    t.data[p] |= 1L << (y & 63);
4086                }
4087                if(y < height - 1 && (b2[p = x * ySections + (y+1 >> 6)] & 1L << (y+1 & 63)) != 0)
4088                {
4089                    t.data[p] |= 1L << (y+1 & 63);
4090                }
4091                if(y > 0 && (b2[p = x * ySections + (y-1 >> 6)] & 1L << (y-1 & 63)) != 0)
4092                {
4093                    t.data[p] |= 1L << (y-1 & 63);
4094                }
4095                if(x > 0 && (b2[p = (x-1) * ySections + (y >> 6)] & 1L << (y & 63)) != 0)
4096                {
4097
4098                    t.data[p] |= 1L << (y & 63);
4099                }
4100                t.tally();
4101                if(t.ct <= 0) break;
4102            }
4103        }
4104        tallied = false;
4105        return this;
4106    }
4107
4108    public GreasedRegion removeCorners()
4109    {
4110        if(width <= 2 || ySections <= 0)
4111            return this;
4112
4113        final long[] next = new long[width * ySections];
4114        System.arraycopy(data, 0, next, 0, width * ySections);
4115        for (int a = 0; a < ySections; a++) {
4116            if(a > 0 && a < ySections - 1) {
4117                next[a] &= (((data[a] << 1) | ((data[a - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63))
4118                        & ((data[a] >>> 1) | ((data[a + 1] & 1L) << 63)));
4119                next[(width - 1) * ySections + a] &= (((data[(width - 1) * ySections + a] << 1)
4120                        | ((data[(width - 1) * ySections + a - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63))
4121                        & ((data[(width - 1) * ySections + a] >>> 1)
4122                        | ((data[(width - 1) * ySections + a + 1] & 1L) << 63)));
4123                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
4124                    next[i] &= (((data[i] << 1) | ((data[i - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63))
4125                            & ((data[i] >>> 1) | ((data[i + 1] & 1L) << 63)))
4126                            | (data[i - ySections]
4127                            & data[i + ySections]);
4128                }
4129            }
4130            else if(a > 0) {
4131                next[a] &= (((data[a] << 1) | ((data[a - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63))
4132                        & (data[a] >>> 1));
4133                next[(width - 1) * ySections + a] &= (((data[(width - 1) * ySections + a] << 1)
4134                        | ((data[(width - 1) * ySections + a - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63))
4135                        & (data[(width - 1) * ySections + a] >>> 1));
4136                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
4137                    next[i] &= (((data[i] << 1) | ((data[i - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63))
4138                            & (data[i] >>> 1))
4139                            | (data[i - ySections]
4140                            & data[i + ySections]);
4141                }
4142            }
4143            else if(a < ySections - 1) {
4144                next[a] &= ((data[a] << 1)
4145                        & ((data[a] >>> 1)
4146                        | ((data[a + 1] & 1L) << 63)));
4147                next[(width - 1) * ySections + a] &= ((data[(width - 1) * ySections + a] << 1)
4148                        & ((data[(width - 1) * ySections + a] >>> 1)
4149                        | ((data[(width - 1) * ySections + a + 1] & 1L) << 63)));
4150                for (int i = ySections+a; i < (width - 1) * ySections; i+= ySections) {
4151                    next[i] &= ((data[i] << 1)
4152                            & ((data[i] >>> 1) | ((data[i + 1] & 1L) << 63)))
4153                            | (data[i - ySections]
4154                            & data[i + ySections]);
4155                }
4156            }
4157            else // only the case when ySections == 1
4158            {
4159                next[0] &= (data[0] << 1) & (data[0] >>> 1);
4160                next[width-1] &= (data[width-1] << 1) & (data[width-1] >>> 1);
4161                for (int i = 1+a; i < (width - 1); i++) {
4162                    next[i] &= ((data[i] << 1) & (data[i] >>> 1)) | (data[i - ySections] & data[i + ySections]);
4163                }
4164            }
4165        }
4166
4167        if(yEndMask != -1) {
4168            for (int a = ySections - 1; a < next.length; a += ySections) {
4169                next[a] &= yEndMask;
4170            }
4171        }
4172        data = next;
4173        tallied = false;
4174        return this;
4175    }
4176
4177    /**
4178     * If this GreasedRegion stores multiple unconnected "on" areas, this finds each isolated area (areas that
4179     * are only adjacent diagonally are considered separate from each other) and returns it as an element in an
4180     * ArrayList of GreasedRegion, with one GreasedRegion per isolated area. Not to be confused with
4181     * {@link #split8way()}, which considers diagonally-adjacent cells as part of one region, while this method requires
4182     * cells to be orthogonally adjacent.
4183     * <br>
4184     * Useful when you have, for example, all the rooms in a dungeon with their connecting corridors removed, but want
4185     * to separate the rooms. You can get the aforementioned data assuming a bare dungeon called map using:
4186     * <br>
4187     * {@code GreasedRegion floors = new GreasedRegion(map, '.'),
4188     * rooms = floors.copy().retract8way().flood(floors, 2),
4189     * corridors = floors.copy().andNot(rooms),
4190     * doors = rooms.copy().and(corridors.copy().fringe());}
4191     * <br>
4192     * You can then get all rooms as separate regions with {@code List<GreasedRegion> apart = split(rooms);}, or
4193     * substitute {@code split(corridors)} to get the corridors. The room-finding technique works by shrinking floors
4194     * by a radius of 1 (8-way), which causes thin areas like corridors of 2 or less width to be removed, then
4195     * flood-filling the floors out from the area that produces by 2 cells (4-way this time) to restore the original
4196     * size of non-corridor areas (plus some extra to ensure odd shapes are kept). Corridors are obtained by removing
4197     * the rooms from floors. The example code also gets the doors (which overlap with rooms, not corridors) by finding
4198     * where the a room and a corridor are adjacent. This technique is used with some enhancements in the RoomFinder
4199     * class.
4200     * @see squidpony.squidgrid.mapping.RoomFinder for a class that uses this technique without exposing GreasedRegion
4201     * @return an ArrayList containing each unconnected area from packed as a GreasedRegion element
4202     */
4203    public ArrayList<GreasedRegion> split()
4204    {
4205        ArrayList<GreasedRegion> scattered = new ArrayList<>(32);
4206        int fst = firstTight();
4207        GreasedRegion remaining = new GreasedRegion(this);
4208        while (fst >= 0) {
4209            GreasedRegion filled = new GreasedRegion(width, height).insert(fst).flood(remaining, width * height);
4210            scattered.add(filled);
4211            remaining.andNot(filled);
4212            fst = remaining.firstTight();
4213        }
4214        return scattered;
4215    }
4216    /**
4217     * If this GreasedRegion stores multiple unconnected "on" areas, this finds each isolated area (areas that
4218     * are only adjacent diagonally are considered <b>one area</b> with this) and returns it as an element in an
4219     * ArrayList of GreasedRegion, with one GreasedRegion per isolated area. This should not be confused with
4220     * {@link #split()}, which is almost identical except that split() considers only orthogonal connections, while this
4221     * method considers both orthogonal and diagonal connections between cells as joining an area.
4222     * <br>
4223     * Useful when you have, for example, all the rooms in a dungeon with their connecting corridors removed, but want
4224     * to separate the rooms. You can get the aforementioned data assuming a bare dungeon called map using:
4225     * <br>
4226     * {@code GreasedRegion floors = new GreasedRegion(map, '.'),
4227     * rooms = floors.copy().retract8way().flood(floors, 2),
4228     * corridors = floors.copy().andNot(rooms),
4229     * doors = rooms.copy().and(corridors.copy().fringe());}
4230     * <br>
4231     * You can then get all rooms as separate regions with {@code List<GreasedRegion> apart = split(rooms);}, or
4232     * substitute {@code split(corridors)} to get the corridors. The room-finding technique works by shrinking floors
4233     * by a radius of 1 (8-way), which causes thin areas like corridors of 2 or less width to be removed, then
4234     * flood-filling the floors out from the area that produces by 2 cells (4-way this time) to restore the original
4235     * size of non-corridor areas (plus some extra to ensure odd shapes are kept). Corridors are obtained by removing
4236     * the rooms from floors. The example code also gets the doors (which overlap with rooms, not corridors) by finding
4237     * where the a room and a corridor are adjacent. This technique is used with some enhancements in the RoomFinder
4238     * class.
4239     * @see squidpony.squidgrid.mapping.RoomFinder for a class that uses this technique without exposing GreasedRegion
4240     * @return an ArrayList containing each unconnected area from packed as a GreasedRegion element
4241     */
4242    public ArrayList<GreasedRegion> split8way()
4243    {
4244        ArrayList<GreasedRegion> scattered = new ArrayList<>(32);
4245        int fst = firstTight();
4246        GreasedRegion remaining = new GreasedRegion(this);
4247        while (fst >= 0) {
4248            GreasedRegion filled = new GreasedRegion(width, height).insert(fst).flood8way(remaining, width * height);
4249            scattered.add(filled);
4250            remaining.andNot(filled);
4251            fst = remaining.firstTight();
4252        }
4253        return scattered;
4254    }

4256    /**
4257     * Finds the largest contiguous area of "on" cells in this GreasedRegion and returns it; does not modify this
4258     * GreasedRegion. If there are multiple areas that are all equally large with no larger area, this returns the
4259     * region it checks first and still is largest (first determined by the same ordering {@link #nth(int)} takes).
4260     * This may return an empty GreasedRegion if there are no "on" cells, but it will never return null.
4261     * Here, contiguous means adjacent on an orthogonal direction, and this doesn't consider diagonally-connected cells
4262     * as contiguous unless they also have an orthogonal connection.
4263     * @return a new GreasedRegion that corresponds to the largest contiguous sub-region of "on" cells in this.
4264     */
4265    public GreasedRegion largestPart()
4266    {
4267        int fst = firstTight(), bestSize = 0, currentSize;
4268        GreasedRegion remaining = new GreasedRegion(this), filled = new GreasedRegion(width, height),
4269                choice = new GreasedRegion(width, height);
4270        while (fst >= 0) {
4271            filled.empty().insert(fst).flood(remaining, width * height);
4272            if((currentSize = filled.size()) > bestSize)
4273            {
4274                bestSize = currentSize;
4275                choice.remake(filled);
4276            }
4277            remaining.andNot(filled);
4278            fst = remaining.firstTight();
4279        }
4280        return choice;
4281    }
4282
4283    /**
4284     * Finds the largest contiguous area of "on" cells in this GreasedRegion and returns it; does not modify this
4285     * GreasedRegion. If there are multiple areas that are all equally large with no larger area, this returns the
4286     * region it checks first and still is largest (first determined by the same ordering {@link #nth(int)} takes).
4287     * This may return an empty GreasedRegion if there are no "on" cells, but it will never return null.
4288     * Here, contiguous means adjacent on any 8-way direction, and considers cells as part of a contiguous area even if
4289     * all connections but one, which can be orthogonal or diagonal, are blocked by "off" cells.
4290     * @return a new GreasedRegion that corresponds to the largest contiguous sub-region of "on" cells in this.
4291     */
4292    public GreasedRegion largestPart8way()
4293    {
4294        int fst = firstTight(), bestSize = 0, currentSize;
4295        GreasedRegion remaining = new GreasedRegion(this), filled = new GreasedRegion(width, height),
4296                choice = new GreasedRegion(width, height);
4297        while (fst >= 0) {
4298            filled.empty().insert(fst).flood8way(remaining, width * height);
4299            if((currentSize = filled.size()) > bestSize)
4300            {
4301                bestSize = currentSize;
4302                choice.remake(filled);
4303            }
4304            remaining.andNot(filled);
4305            fst = remaining.firstTight();
4306        }
4307        return choice;
4308    }

4310    /**
4311     * Modifies this GreasedRegion so the only cells that will be "on" have a neighbor upwards when this is called.
4312     * Up is defined as negative y. Neighbors are "on" cells exactly one cell away. A cell can have a neighbor
4313     * without itself being on; this is useful when finding the "shadow" cast away from "on" cells in one direction.
4314     * @return this, after modifications, for chaining
4315     */
4316    public GreasedRegion neighborUp()
4317    {
4318        if(width < 2 || ySections <= 0)
4319            return this;
4320        for (int a = ySections - 1; a >= 0; a--) {
4321            if(a > 0) {
4322                for (int i = a; i < width * ySections; i+= ySections) {
4323                    data[i] = (data[i] << 1) | ((data[i - 1] & 0x8000000000000000L) >>> 63);
4324                }
4325            }
4326            else {
4327                for (int i = a; i < width * ySections; i+= ySections) {
4328                    data[i] = (data[i] << 1);
4329                }
4330            }
4331        }
4332        tallied = false;
4333        return this;
4334    }

4349                    data[i] = (data[i] >>> 1) | ((data[i + 1] & 1L) << 63);

4353                for (int i = a; i < width * ySections; i+= ySections) {

4364     * Left is defined as negative x. Neighbors are "on" cells exactly one cell away. A cell can have a neighbor
4365     * without itself being on; this is useful when finding the "shadow" cast away from "on" cells in one direction.
4366     * @return this, after modifications, for chaining
4367     */
4368    public GreasedRegion neighborLeft()
4369    {

4371            return this;
4372        for (int a = 0; a < ySections; a++) {
4373            for (int i = ySections * (width - 1) + a; i >= ySections; i-= ySections) {
4374                data[i] = data[i - ySections];
4375            }
4376            data[a] = 0L;
4377        }
4378        tallied = false;
4379        return this;

4417                }

4517    public GreasedRegion removeIsolated()
4518    {
4519        int fst = firstTight();
4520        GreasedRegion remaining = new GreasedRegion(this), filled = new GreasedRegion(this);
4521        while (fst >= 0) {
4522            filled.empty().insert(fst).flood(remaining, 8);
4523            if(filled.size() <= 4)
4524                andNot(filled);
4525            remaining.andNot(filled);
4526            fst = remaining.firstTight();
4527        }
4528        return this;
4529    }

4531    /**
4532     * Returns true if any cell is "on" in both this GreasedRegion and in other; returns false otherwise. For example,
4533     * if (1,1) is "on" in this and (1,1) is "on" in other, this would return true, regardless of other cells.
4534     * @param other another GreasedRegion; its size does not have to match this GreasedRegion's size
4535     * @return true if this shares any "on" cells with other
4536     */
4537    public boolean intersects(GreasedRegion other)
4538    {
4539        if(other == null)
4540            return false;
4541        for (int x = 0; x < width && x < other.width; x++) {
4542            for (int y = 0; y < ySections && y < other.ySections; y++) {
4543                if((data[x * ySections + y] & other.data[x * ySections + y]) != 0)
4544                    return true;
4545            }
4546        }
4547        return false;
4548    }

4550    public static OrderedSet<GreasedRegion> whichContain(int x, int y, GreasedRegion ... packed)
4551    {
4552        OrderedSet<GreasedRegion> found = new OrderedSet<>(packed.length);
4553        GreasedRegion tmp;
4554        for (int i = 0; i < packed.length; i++) {
4555            if((tmp = packed[i]) != null && tmp.contains(x, y))
4556                found.add(tmp);
4557        }
4558        return found;
4559    }
4560
4561    public static OrderedSet<GreasedRegion> whichContain(int x, int y, Collection<GreasedRegion> packed)
4562    {
4563        OrderedSet<GreasedRegion> found = new OrderedSet<>(packed.size());
4564        for (GreasedRegion tmp : packed) {
4565            if(tmp != null && tmp.contains(x, y))
4566                found.add(tmp);
4567        }
4568        return found;
4569    }
4570    /**
4571     * Tries to look up the position x,y in each GreasedRegion in packed; each GreasedRegion that contains that x,y
4572     * point is appended into the Collection {@code into}.
4573     * @param into a Collection of GreasedRegion that will be modified if this succeeds
4574     * @param x the x-coordinate to look up
4575     * @param y the y-coordinate to look up
4576     * @param packed the array or varargs of GreasedRegion to try to look up the given position in
4577     * @return {@code into}, potentially modified
4578     */
4579    public static Collection<GreasedRegion> appendContaining(Collection<GreasedRegion> into, int x, int y, GreasedRegion ... packed)
4580    {
4581        GreasedRegion tmp;
4582        for (int i = 0; i < packed.length; i++) {
4583            if((tmp = packed[i]) != null && tmp.contains(x, y))
4584                into.add(tmp);
4585        }
4586        return into;
4587    }

4589    /**
4590     * Tries to look up the position x,y in each GreasedRegion in packed; each GreasedRegion that contains that x,y
4591     * point is appended into the Collection {@code into}.
4592     * @param into a Collection of GreasedRegion that will be modified if this succeeds
4593     * @param x the x-coordinate to look up
4594     * @param y the y-coordinate to look up
4595     * @param packed the Collection of GreasedRegion to try to look up the given position in
4596     * @return {@code into}, potentially modified
4597     */
4598    public static Collection<GreasedRegion> appendContaining(Collection<GreasedRegion> into, int x, int y, Collection<GreasedRegion> packed)
4599    {
4600        for (GreasedRegion tmp : packed) {
4601            if(tmp != null && tmp.contains(x, y))
4602                into.add(tmp);
4603        }
4604        return into;
4605    }

4608    public int size()
4609    {
4610        if(!tallied)
4611            tally();
4612        return ct;
4613    }
4614
4615    public Coord fit(double xFraction, double yFraction)
4616    {
4617        int tmp, xTotal = 0, yTotal = 0, xTarget, yTarget, bestX = -1;
4618        long t;
4619        int[] xCounts = new int[width];
4620        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
4621            for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
4622                t = data[x * ySections + s] | 0L;
4623                if (t != 0) {
4624                    tmp = Long.bitCount(t);
4625                    xCounts[x] += tmp;
4626                    xTotal += tmp;
4627                }
4628            }
4629        }
4630        xTarget = (int)(xTotal * xFraction);
4631        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
4632            if((xTarget -= xCounts[x]) < 0)
4633            {
4634                bestX = x;
4635                yTotal = xCounts[x];
4636                break;
4637            }
4638        }
4639        if(bestX < 0)
4640        {
4641            return Coord.get(-1, -1);
4642        }
4643        yTarget = (int)(yTotal * yFraction);
4644
4645        for (int s = 0, y = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
4646            t = data[bestX * ySections + s] | 0L;
4647            for (long cy = 1L; cy != 0L && y < height; y++, cy <<= 1) {
4648                if((t & (cy | 0L)) != 0 && --yTarget < 0)
4649                {
4650                    return Coord.get(bestX, y);
4651                }
4652            }
4653        }
4654
4655        return Coord.get(-1, -1);
4656    }
4657
4658    public int[][] fit(int[][] basis, int defaultValue)
4659    {
4660        int[][] next = ArrayTools.fill(defaultValue, width, height);
4661        if(basis == null || basis.length <= 0 || basis[0] == null || basis[0].length <= 0)
4662            return next;
4663        int tmp, xTotal = 0, yTotal = 0, xTarget, yTarget, bestX, oX = basis.length, oY = basis[0].length, ao;
4664        long t;
4665        int[] xCounts = new int[width];
4666        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
4667            for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
4668                t = data[x * ySections + s] | 0L;
4669                if (t != 0) {
4670                    tmp = Long.bitCount(t);
4671                    xCounts[x] += tmp;
4672                    xTotal += tmp;
4673                }
4674            }
4675        }
4676        if(xTotal <= 0)
4677            return next;
4678        for (int aX = 0; aX < oX; aX++) {
4679            CELL_WISE:
4680            for (int aY = 0; aY < oY; aY++) {
4681                if((ao = basis[aX][aY]) == defaultValue)
4682                    continue;
4683                xTarget = xTotal * aX / oX;
4684                for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
4685                    if((xTarget -= xCounts[x]) < 0)
4686                    {
4687                        bestX = x;
4688                        yTotal = xCounts[x];
4689                        yTarget = yTotal * aY / oY;
4690                        for (int s = 0, y = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
4691                            t = data[bestX * ySections + s] | 0L;
4692                            for (long cy = 1L; cy != 0L && y < height; y++, cy <<= 1) {
4693                                if((t & (cy|0L)) != 0 && --yTarget < 0)
4694                                {
4695                                    next[bestX][y] = ao;
4696                                    continue CELL_WISE;
4697                                }
4698                            }
4699                        }
4700                        continue CELL_WISE;
4701                    }
4702                }
4703
4704            }
4705        }
4706
4707        return next;
4708    }

4710    /**
4711     * Don't use this in new code; prefer {@link #mixedRandomSeparated(double)}, {@link #quasiRandomSeparated(double)},
4712     * or {@link #separatedZCurve(double)}. This method has issues with being unable to fill the requested fraction, but
4713     * the others mentioned don't. See their documentation for what all these group of methods do.
4714     * @param fraction between 0.0 and 1.0
4715     * @return a Coord array that may not have the full fraction used; you have been advised
4716     */
4717    public Coord[] separatedPortion(double fraction)
4718    {
4719        if(fraction < 0)
4720            return new Coord[0];
4721        if(fraction > 1)
4722            fraction = 1;
4723        int ct, tmp, xTotal = 0, yTotal = 0, xTarget, yTarget, bestX = -1;
4724        long t;
4725        int[] xCounts = new int[width];
4726        for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
4727            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
4728                t = data[x * ySections + s] | 0L;
4729                if (t != 0) {
4730                    tmp = Long.bitCount(t);
4731                    xCounts[x] += tmp;
4732                    xTotal += tmp;
4733                }
4734            }
4735        }
4736        Coord[] vl = new Coord[ct = (int)(fraction * xTotal)];
4737        double[] vec = new double[2];
4738        sobol.skipTo(1337);
4739        EACH_SOBOL:
4740        for (int i = 0; i < ct; i++)
4741        {
4742            sobol.fillVector(vec);
4743            xTarget = (int) (xTotal * vec[0]);
4744            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
4745                if ((xTarget -= xCounts[x]) < 0) {
4746                    bestX = x;
4747                    yTotal = xCounts[x];
4748                    break;
4749                }
4750            }
4751            yTarget = (int) (yTotal * vec[1]);
4752
4753            for (int s = 0, y = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
4754                t = data[bestX * ySections + s] | 0L;
4755                for (long cy = 1L; cy != 0L && y < height; y++, cy <<= 1) {
4756                    if ((t & (cy|0L)) != 0 && --yTarget < 0) {
4757                        vl[i] = Coord.get(bestX, y);
4758                        continue EACH_SOBOL;
4759                    }
4760                }
4761            }
4762        }
4763        return vl;
4764
4765    }
4766    /**
4767     * Don't use this in new code; prefer {@link #mixedRandomSeparated(double, int, long)} with a random long as the
4768     * last parameter. This method has issues with being unable to fill the requested fraction, but mixedRandomSeparated
4769     * does not. See its documentation for what this method is supposed to do.
4770     * @param fraction between 0.0 and 1.0
4771     * @param rng an IRNG that will be used to get a random starting point in the Sobol sequence this uses internally
4772     * @return a Coord array that may not have the full fraction used; you have been advised
4773     */
4774    public Coord[] randomSeparated(double fraction, IRNG rng)
4775    {
4776        return randomSeparated(fraction, rng, -1);
4777    }
4778    /**
4779     * Don't use this in new code; prefer {@link #mixedRandomSeparated(double, int, long)} with a random long as the
4780     * last parameter. This method has issues with being unable to fill the requested fraction, but mixedRandomSeparated
4781     * does not. See its documentation for what this method is supposed to do.
4782     * @param fraction between 0.0 and 1.0
4783     * @param rng an IRNG that will be used to get a random starting point in the Sobol sequence this uses internally
4784     * @param limit how many Coord values this should return, at most; typically this will return less
4785     * @return a Coord array that may not have the full fraction used; you have been advised
4786     */
4787    public Coord[] randomSeparated(double fraction, IRNG rng, int limit)
4788    {
4789        if(fraction < 0)
4790            return new Coord[0];
4791        if(fraction > 1)
4792            fraction = 1;
4793        int ct, tmp, xTotal = 0, yTotal = 0, xTarget, yTarget, bestX = -1;
4794        long t;
4795        int[] xCounts = new int[width];
4796        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
4797            for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
4798                t = data[x * ySections + s] | 0L;
4799                if (t != 0) {
4800                    tmp = Long.bitCount(t);
4801                    xCounts[x] += tmp;
4802                    xTotal += tmp;
4803                }
4804            }
4805        }
4806        ct = (int)(fraction * xTotal);
4807        if(limit >= 0 && limit < ct)
4808            ct = limit;
4809        Coord[] vl = new Coord[ct];
4810        double[] vec = new double[2];
4811        sobol.skipTo(rng.between(1000, 65000));
4812        EACH_SOBOL:
4813        for (int i = 0; i < ct; i++)
4814        {
4815            sobol.fillVector(vec);
4816            xTarget = (int) (xTotal * vec[0]);
4817            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
4818                if ((xTarget -= xCounts[x]) < 0) {
4819                    bestX = x;
4820                    yTotal = xCounts[x];
4821                    break;
4822                }
4823            }
4824            yTarget = (int) (yTotal * vec[1]);
4825
4826            for (int s = 0, y = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
4827                t = data[bestX * ySections + s] | 0L;
4828                for (long cy = 1; cy != 0 && y < height; y++, cy <<= 1) {
4829                    if ((t & (cy|0L)) != 0 && --yTarget < 0) {
4830                        vl[i] = Coord.get(bestX, y);
4831                        continue EACH_SOBOL;
4832                    }
4833                }
4834            }
4835        }
4836        return vl;
4837
4838    }

4840    /**
4841     * Gets a Coord array from the "on" contents of this GreasedRegion, using a deterministic but random-seeming
4842     * scattering of chosen cells with a count that matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells
4843     * in this. This is pseudo-random with a fixed seed, but is very good at avoiding overlap (just as good as
4844     * {@link #separatedRegionZCurve(double, int)}, and probably faster). If you request too many cells (too high of a
4845     * value for fraction), it will start to overlap, but a fraction value of 0.4 reliably has had no overlap in
4846     * testing. Does not restrict the size of the returned array other than only using up to
4847     * {@code fraction * size()} cells.
4848     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
4849     * @return a freshly-allocated Coord array containing the quasi-random cells
4850     */
4851    public Coord[] mixedRandomSeparated(double fraction)
4852    {
4853        return mixedRandomSeparated(fraction, -1, 1L);
4854    }

4856    /**
4857     * Gets a Coord array from the "on" contents of this GreasedRegion, using a deterministic but random-seeming
4858     * scattering of chosen cells with a count that matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells
4859     * in this. This is pseudo-random with a fixed seed, but is very good at avoiding overlap (just as good as
4860     * {@link #separatedRegionZCurve(double, int)}, and probably faster). If you request too many cells (too high of a
4861     * value for fraction), it will start to overlap, but a fraction value of 0.4 reliably has had no overlap in
4862     * testing. Restricts the total size of the returned array to a maximum of {@code limit} (minimum is 0 if no cells
4863     * are "on"). If limit is negative, this will not restrict the size.
4864     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
4865     * @param limit the maximum size of the array to return
4866     * @return a freshly-allocated Coord array containing the pseudo-random cells
4867     */
4868    public Coord[] mixedRandomSeparated(double fraction, int limit)
4869    {
4870        return mixedRandomSeparated(fraction, limit, 1L);
4871    }

4873    /**
4874     * Gets a Coord array from the "on" contents of this GreasedRegion, using a deterministic but random-seeming
4875     * scattering of chosen cells with a count that matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells
4876     * in this. This is pseudo-random with the given seed (which will be made into an odd number if it is not one
4877     * already), and is very good at avoiding overlap (just as good as {@link #separatedZCurve(double, int)}, and
4878     * probably faster). If you request too many cells (too high of a value for fraction), it will start to overlap, but
4879     * a fraction value of 0.4 reliably has had no overlap in testing. Restricts the total size of the returned array to
4880     * a maximum of {@code limit} (minimum is 0 if no cells are "on"). If limit is negative, this will not restrict the
4881     * size.
4882     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
4883     * @param limit the maximum size of the array to return
4884     * @param seed a long seed to change the points; the most significant 21 bits (except the sign bit) and least significant bit are ignored
4885     * @return a freshly-allocated Coord array containing the pseudo-random cells
4886     */
4887    public Coord[] mixedRandomSeparated(double fraction, int limit, long seed) {
4888        if (fraction < 0)
4889            return new Coord[0];
4890        if (fraction > 1)
4891            fraction = 1;
4892        int tmp, ic;
4893        long t, w;
4894        seed |= 1L;
4895        final int total = size();
4896        int ct = (int) (total * fraction);
4897        if (limit >= 0 && limit < ct)
4898            ct = limit;
4899        Coord[] vl = new Coord[ct];
4900        EACH_QUASI:
4901        for (int i = 0; i < ct; i++) {
4902            tmp = (int) (VanDerCorputQRNG.altDetermine(seed, i + 1) * total);
4903
4904            for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
4905                for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
4906                    if ((ic = counts[x * ySections + s]) > tmp) {
4907                        t = data[x * ySections + s]|0L;
4908                        for (--ic; t != 0; ic--) {
4909                            w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
4910                            if (ic == tmp) {
4911                                vl[i] = Coord.get(x, (s << 6) | Long.bitCount(w - 1));
4912                                continue EACH_QUASI;
4913                            }
4914                            t ^= w;
4915                        }
4916                    }
4917                }
4918            }
4919        }
4920        return vl;
4921    }

4926     * Modifies this GreasedRegion so it contains a deterministic but random-seeming subset of its previous contents,
4927     * choosing cells so that the {@link #size()} matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells
4928     * in this. This is pseudo-random with a fixed seed, and is very good at avoiding overlap (just as good as
4929     * {@link #separatedRegionZCurve(double, int)}, and probably faster). If you request too many cells (too high of a
4930     * value for fraction), it will start to overlap, but a fraction value of 0.4 reliably has had no overlap in
4931     * testing. Does not restrict the count of "on" cells after this returns other than by only using up to
4932     * {@code fraction * size()} cells.
4933     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
4934     * @return this for chaining
4935     */
4936    public GreasedRegion mixedRandomRegion(double fraction) {
4937        return mixedRandomRegion(fraction, -1, 1L);

4939    /**
4940     * Modifies this GreasedRegion so it contains a deterministic but random-seeming subset of its previous contents,
4941     * choosing cells so that the {@link #size()} matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells
4942     * in this. This is pseudo-random with a fixed seed, and is very good at avoiding overlap (just as good as
4943     * {@link #separatedRegionZCurve(double, int)}, and probably faster). If you request too many cells (too high of a
4944     * value for fraction), it will start to overlap, but a fraction value of 0.4 reliably has had no overlap in
4945     * testing. Restricts the total count of "on" cells after this returns to a maximum of {@code limit} (minimum is 0
4946     * if no cells are "on"). If limit is negative, this will not restrict the count.
4947     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
4948     * @param limit the maximum count of "on" cells to keep
4949     * @return this for chaining
4950     */
4951    public GreasedRegion mixedRandomRegion(double fraction, int limit) {
4952        return mixedRandomRegion(fraction, limit, 1L);
4953    }
4954    /**
4955     * Modifies this GreasedRegion so it contains a deterministic but random-seeming subset of its previous contents,
4956     * choosing cells so that the {@link #size()} matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells
4957     * in this. This is pseudo-random with the given seed (which will be made into an odd number if it is not one
4958     * already), and is very good at avoiding overlap (just as good as {@link #separatedZCurve(double, int)}, and
4959     * probably faster). If you request too many cells (too high of a value for fraction), it will start to overlap, but
4960     * a fraction value of 0.4 reliably has had no overlap in testing. Restricts the total count of "on" cells after
4961     * this returns to a maximum of {@code limit} (minimum is 0 if no cells are "on"). If limit is negative, this will
4962     * not restrict the count.
4963     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
4964     * @param limit the maximum count of "on" cells to keep
4965     * @return this for chaining
4966     */
4967    public GreasedRegion mixedRandomRegion(double fraction, int limit, long seed) {
4968        int idx, run = 0;
4969        final int total = size();
4970        if (total <= limit)
4971            return this;
4972        if (total <= 0)
4973            return empty();
4974        if (limit < 0)
4975            limit = (int) (fraction * ct);
4976        if(limit <= 0)
4977            return empty();
4978        seed |= 1L;
4979        int[] order = new int[limit];
4980        for (int i = 0, m = 1; i < limit; i++, m++) {
4981            idx = (int)(VanDerCorputQRNG.altDetermine(seed, m) * total);
4982            BIG:
4983            while (true) {
4984                for (int j = 0; j < i; j++) {
4985                    if (order[j] == idx) {
4986                        idx = (int)(VanDerCorputQRNG.altDetermine(seed, ++m) * total);
4987                        continue BIG;
4988                    }
4989                }
4990                break;
4991            }
4992            order[i] = idx;
4993        }
4994        idx = 0;
4995        Arrays.sort(order);
4996        long t, w;
4997        ALL:
4998        for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
4999            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
5000                if ((t = data[x * ySections + s]|0L) != 0L) {
5001                    w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
5002                    while (w != 0) {
5003                        if (run++ == order[idx]) {
5004                            if (++idx >= limit) {
5005                                data[x * ySections + s] &= (w<<1)-1;
5006                                for (int rx = x+1; rx < width; rx++) {
5007                                    data[rx * ySections + s] = 0;
5008                                }
5009                                for (int rs = s+1; rs < ySections; rs++) {
5010                                    for (int rx = 0; rx < width; rx++) {
5011                                        data[rx * ySections + rs] = 0;
5012                                    }
5013                                }
5014                                break ALL;
5015                            }
5016                        } else {
5017                            data[x * ySections + s] ^= w;
5018                        }
5019                        t ^= w;
5020                        w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
5021                    }
5022                }
5023            }
5024        }
5025        tallied = false;
5026        return this;
5027    }

5029    /**
5030     * Gets a Coord array from the "on" contents of this GreasedRegion, using a quasi-random scattering of chosen cells
5031     * with a count that matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells in this. This is quasi-
5032     * random instead of pseudo-random because it is somewhat less likely to produce nearby cells in the result. If you
5033     * request too many cells (too high of a value for fraction), it will start to overlap, however.
5034     * Does not restrict the size of the returned array other than only using up to {@code fraction * size()} cells.
5035     * <br>
5036     * You can choose between {@link #mixedRandomSeparated(double)}, {@link #separatedZCurve(double)}, and this method,
5037     * where all are quasi-random, mixedRandom is probably fastest, ZCurve may have better 2-dimensional gaps between
5038     * cells, and this method is somewhere in the middle.
5039     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
5040     * @return a freshly-allocated Coord array containing the quasi-random cells
5041     */
5042    public Coord[] quasiRandomSeparated(double fraction)
5043    {
5044        return quasiRandomSeparated(fraction, -1);
5045    }
5046
5047    /**
5048     * Gets a Coord array from the "on" contents of this GreasedRegion, using a quasi-random scattering of chosen cells
5049     * with a count that matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells in this. This is quasi-
5050     * random instead of pseudo-random because it is somewhat less likely to produce nearby cells in the result. If you
5051     * request too many cells (too high of a value for fraction), it will start to overlap, however.
5052     * Restricts the total size of the returned array to a maximum of {@code limit} (minimum is 0 if no cells are "on").
5053     * If limit is negative, this will not restrict the size.
5054     * <br>
5055     * You can choose between {@link #mixedRandomSeparated(double, int)}, {@link #separatedZCurve(double, int)}, and
5056     * this method, where all are quasi-random, mixedRandom is probably fastest, ZCurve may have better 2-dimensional
5057     * gaps between cells, and this method is somewhere in the middle.
5058     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
5059     * @param limit the maximum size of the array to return
5060     * @return a freshly-allocated Coord array containing the quasi-random cells
5061     */
5062    public Coord[] quasiRandomSeparated(double fraction, int limit)
5063    {
5064        if(fraction < 0)
5065            return new Coord[0];
5066        if(fraction > 1)
5067            fraction = 1;
5068        int ct = 0, tmp, total, ic;
5069        long t, w;
5070        int[] counts = new int[width * ySections];
5071        for (int i = 0; i < width * ySections; i++) {
5072            tmp = Long.bitCount(data[i]);
5073            counts[i] = tmp == 0 ? -1 : (ct += tmp);
5074        }
5075        total = ct;
5076        ct *= fraction;// (int)(fraction * ct);
5077        if(limit >= 0 && limit < ct)
5078            ct = limit;
5079        Coord[] vl = new Coord[ct];
5080        EACH_QUASI:
5081        for (int i = 0; i < ct; i++)
5082        {
5083            tmp = (int)(VanDerCorputQRNG.determine2(i ^ i >>> 1) * total);
5084            for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
5085                for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
5086                    if ((ic = counts[x * ySections + s]) > tmp) {
5087                        t = data[x * ySections + s];
5088                        w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
5089                        for (--ic; w != 0; ic--) {
5090                            if (ic == tmp) {
5091                                vl[i] = Coord.get(x, (s << 6) | Long.numberOfTrailingZeros(w));
5092                                continue EACH_QUASI;
5093                            }
5094                            t ^= w;
5095                            w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
5096                        }
5097                    }
5098                }
5099            }
5100            vl[i] = atFraction(tmp);
5101        }
5102        return vl;
5103    }

5108     * Modifies this GreasedRegion so it contains a quasi-random subset of its previous contents, choosing cells so that
5109     * the {@link #size()} matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells in this. This is quasi-
5110     * random instead of pseudo-random because it is somewhat less likely to produce nearby cells in the result. If you
5111     * request too many cells (too high of a value for fraction), it will start to overlap, however.
5112     * Does not restrict the count of "on" cells after this returns other than by only using up to
5113     * {@code fraction * size()} cells.
5114     * <br>
5115     * You can choose between {@link #mixedRandomRegion(double)}, {@link #separatedRegionZCurve(double)}, and this
5116     * method, where all are quasi-random, mixedRandom is probably fastest, ZCurve may have better 2-dimensional gaps
5117     * between cells, and this method is somewhere in the middle.
5118     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
5119     * @return this for chaining

5121    public GreasedRegion quasiRandomRegion(double fraction) {

5124    /**
5125     * Modifies this GreasedRegion so it contains a quasi-random subset of its previous contents, choosing cells so that
5126     * the {@link #size()} matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells in this. This is quasi-
5127     * random instead of pseudo-random because it is somewhat less likely to produce nearby cells in the result. If you
5128     * request too many cells (too high of a value for fraction), it will start to overlap, however.
5129     * Restricts the total count of "on" cells after this returns to a maximum of {@code limit} (minimum is 0 if no
5130     * cells are "on"). If limit is negative, this will not restrict the count.
5131     * <br>
5132     * You can choose between {@link #mixedRandomRegion(double, int)}, {@link #separatedRegionZCurve(double, int)}, and
5133     * this method, where all are quasi-random, mixedRandom is probably fastest, ZCurve may have better 2-dimensional
5134     * gaps between cells, and this method is somewhere in the middle.
5135     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
5136     * @param limit the maximum count of "on" cells to keep
5137     * @return this for chaining
5138     */
5139    public GreasedRegion quasiRandomRegion(double fraction, int limit) {
5140        int ct = size(), idx, run = 0;
5141        if (ct <= limit)
5142            return this;
5143        if (ct <= 0)
5144            return empty();
5145        if (limit < 0)
5146            limit = (int) (fraction * ct);
5147        if(limit <= 0)
5148            return empty();
5149        int[] order = new int[limit];
5150        for (int i = 0, m = 1; i < limit; i++, m++) {
5151            idx = (int) (VanDerCorputQRNG.determine2(m) * ct);
5152            BIG:
5153            while (true) {
5154                for (int j = 0; j < i; j++) {
5155                    if (order[j] == idx) {
5156                        idx = (int) (VanDerCorputQRNG.determine2(++m) * ct);
5157                        continue BIG;
5158                    }
5159                }
5160                break;
5161            }
5162            order[i] = idx;
5163        }
5164        idx = 0;
5165        Arrays.sort(order);
5166        long t, w;
5167        ALL:
5168        for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
5169            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
5170                if ((t = data[x * ySections + s]) != 0) {
5171                    w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
5172                    while (w != 0) {
5173                        if (run++ == order[idx]) {
5174                            if (++idx >= limit) {
5175                                data[x * ySections + s] &= (w<<1)-1;
5176                                for (int rx = x+1; rx < width; rx++) {
5177                                    data[rx * ySections + s] = 0;
5178                                }
5179                                for (int rs = s+1; rs < ySections; rs++) {
5180                                    for (int rx = 0; rx < width; rx++) {
5181                                        data[rx * ySections + rs] = 0;
5182                                    }
5183                                }
5184                                break ALL;
5185                            }
5186                        } else {
5187                            data[x * ySections + s] ^= w;
5188                        }
5189                        t ^= w;
5190                        w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
5191                    }
5192                }
5193            }
5194        }
5195        tallied = false;
5196        return this;
5197    }
5198
5199    /**
5200     * Like {@link #retract()}, this removes the "on" cells that are 4-way-adjacent to any "off" cell, but unlike that
5201     * method it keeps a fraction of those surface cells, quasi-randomly selecting them. This can be thought of as
5202     * running {@link #surface()} on a copy of this GreasedRegion, running {@link #quasiRandomRegion(double)} on that
5203     * surface with the given fractionKept, taking the original GreasedRegion and removing its whole surface with
5204     * {@link #retract()}, then inserting the quasi-randomly-removed surface into this GreasedRegion to replace its
5205     * surface with a randomly "damaged" one.
5206     * @param fractionKept the fraction between 0.0 and 1.0 of how many cells on the outer surface of this to keep "on"
5207     * @return this for chaining
5208     */
5209    public GreasedRegion fray(double fractionKept)
5210    {
5211        GreasedRegion cpy = new GreasedRegion(this).retract();
5212        return xor(cpy).quasiRandomRegion(1.0 - fractionKept).or(cpy);
5213    }

5215    /**
5216     * Modifies this GreasedRegion so it contains a random subset of its previous contents, choosing cells so that the
5217     * distance between any two "on" cells is at least {@code minimumDistance}, with at least one cell as "on" if any
5218     * were "on" in this originally. Does not limit the count of "on" cells in the result.
5219     * @param rng used to generate random positions
5220     * @param minimumDistance the minimum distance between "on" cells in the result
5221     * @return this for chaining
5222     */
5223    public GreasedRegion randomScatter(IRNG rng, int minimumDistance) {
5224        return randomScatter(rng, minimumDistance, -1);
5225    }
5226    /**
5227     * Modifies this GreasedRegion so it contains a random subset of its previous contents, choosing cells so that the
5228     * distance between any two "on" cells is at least {@code minimumDistance}, with at least one cell as "on" if any
5229     * were "on" in this originally.
5230     * Restricts the total count of "on" cells after this returns to a maximum of {@code limit} (minimum is 0 if no
5231     * cells are "on"). If limit is negative, this will not restrict the count.
5232     * @param rng used to generate random positions
5233     * @param minimumDistance the minimum distance between "on" cells in the result
5234     * @param limit the maximum count of "on" cells to keep
5235     * @return this for chaining
5236     */
5237    public GreasedRegion randomScatter(IRNG rng, int minimumDistance, int limit) {
5238        int tmp, total = 0, ct;
5239        tally();
5240        if(this.ct == 0)
5241            return this;
5242        if(limit == 0)
5243            return empty();
5244        else if(limit < 0)
5245            limit = width * height;
5246        long t, w;
5247        long[] data2 = new long[data.length];
5248        MAIN_LOOP:
5249        while (total < limit) { 
5250            if(!tallied) 
5251                tally();
5252            tmp = rng.nextInt(this.ct);
5253
5254            for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
5255                for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
5256                    if ((ct = counts[x * ySections + s]) > tmp) {
5257                        t = data[x * ySections + s];
5258                        w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
5259                        for (--ct; w != 0; ct--) {
5260                            if (ct == tmp) {
5261                                removeRectangle(x - minimumDistance,
5262                                        ((s << 6) | Long.numberOfTrailingZeros(w)) - minimumDistance,
5263                                        minimumDistance << 1 | 1, minimumDistance << 1 | 1);
5264                                data2[x * ySections + s] |= w;
5265                                ++total;
5266                                continue MAIN_LOOP;
5267                            }
5268                            t ^= w;
5269                            w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
5270                        }
5271                    }
5272                }
5273            }
5274            break;
5275        }
5276        data = data2;
5277        tallied = false;
5278        return this;
5279    }

5281    public double rateDensity()
5282    {
5283        double sz = height * width;
5284        if(sz == 0)
5285            return 0;
5286        double onAmount = sz - size(), retractedOn = sz - copy().retract().size();
5287        return (onAmount + retractedOn) / (sz * 2.0);
5288    }
5289    public double rateRegularity()
5290    {
5291        GreasedRegion me2 = copy().surface8way();
5292        double irregularCount = me2.size();
5293        if(irregularCount == 0)
5294            return 0;
5295        return me2.remake(this).surface().size() / irregularCount;
5296    }

5298    private static int median(int[] working, int start, int amount)
5299    {
5300        Arrays.sort(working, start, start + amount);
5301        if ((amount & 1) == 0) {
5302            return working[start + (amount >> 1) - 1] + working[start + (amount >> 1)] >>> 1;
5303        } else {
5304            return working[start + (amount >> 1)];
5305        }
5306    }
5307
5308    /**
5309     * Calculates a perceptual hash for this GreasedRegion using a method that is only precise for some sizes of
5310     * GreasedRegion; it writes a result to into, and uses working as a temporary buffer. The lengths of into and
5311     * working should be related; if into is length 1, then working should be length 64, and though the hash won't be
5312     * very detailed, it will work well for images with width and height that are multiples of 8; if into is length 4,
5313     * then working should be length 256, and this will work with more detail on images that have width and height that
5314     * are multiples of 16. If working is null or is too small, then this won't reuse it and will allocate an
5315     * appropriately-sized array for internal use.
5316     * <br>
5317     * Ported from https://github.com/commonsmachinery/blockhash/blob/master/blockhash.c , which is MIT-licensed.
5318     * @param into should be a long array of length 1 or 4; the contents don't matter and this will be where output is written to
5319     * @param working should be an int array of length 64 (if into has length 1) or 256 (if into has length 4); may be null if you like garbage collection
5320     */
5321    public void perceptualHashQuick(long[] into, int[] working)
5322    {
5323        final int bits = 8 << (Integer.numberOfTrailingZeros(Integer.highestOneBit(into.length)) >> 1);
5324        if(working == null || working.length < bits * bits)
5325            working = new int[bits * bits];
5326        final int blockWidth = width / bits, blockHeight = height / bits, blockWidthSections = blockWidth * ySections;
5327        if(blockHeight == 1)
5328        {
5329            for (int y = 0; y < bits; y++) {
5330                for (int x = 0; x < bits; x++) {
5331                    int value = 0;
5332                    for (int ix = 0; ix < blockWidthSections; ix += ySections) {
5333                        value += (data[x * blockWidthSections + ix + (y >> 6)] >>> (y & 63) & 1L);
5334                    }
5335                    working[x * bits + y] = value;
5336                }
5337            }
5338        }
5339        else if(blockHeight < 64 && Integer.bitCount(blockHeight) == 1) {
5340            final long yBlockMask = ~(-1L << blockHeight);
5341            final int divisorMask = (64 / blockHeight) - 1;
5342            long currentMask;
5343            int blockY = 0;
5344            for (int y = 0; y < bits; y++, blockY += blockHeight) {
5345                currentMask = yBlockMask << ((y & divisorMask) << blockHeight);
5346                for (int x = 0; x < bits; x++) {
5347                    int value = 0;
5348                    for (int ix = 0; ix < blockWidthSections; ix += ySections) {
5349                        value += Long.bitCount(data[x * blockWidthSections + ix + (blockY >> 6)] & currentMask);
5350                    }
5351                    working[x * bits + y] = value;
5352                }
5353            }
5354        }
5355        final int cellsPerBlock = blockWidth * blockHeight, numBlocks = bits * bits,
5356                halfCellCount = cellsPerBlock >>> 1;
5357        int bandSize = numBlocks >>> 2;
5358        int m, v;
5359        int currentInto = 0;
5360        long currentIntoPos = 1L;
5361        for (int i = 0; i < 4; i++) {
5362            m = median(working, i * bandSize, bandSize);
5363            for (int j = i * bandSize; j < (i + 1) * bandSize; j++) {
5364                v = working[j];
5365                if(v > m || (v - m == 0 && m > halfCellCount)) into[currentInto] |= currentIntoPos;
5366                if((currentIntoPos <<= 1) == 0)
5367                {
5368                    ++currentInto;
5369                    currentIntoPos = 1L;
5370                }
5371            }
5372        }
5373    }

5375    /*
5376    // This showed a strong x-y correlation because it didn't have a way to use a non-base-2 van der Corput sequence.
5377    // It also produced very close-together points, unfortunately.
5378    public static double quasiRandomX(int idx)
5379    {
5380        return atVDCSequence(26 + idx * 5);
5381    }
5382    public static double quasiRandomY(int idx)
5383    {
5384        return atVDCSequence(19 + idx * 3);
5385    }
5386
5387    private static double atVDCSequence(int idx)
5388    {
5389        int leading = Integer.numberOfLeadingZeros(idx);
5390        return (Integer.reverse(idx) >>> leading) / (1.0 * (1 << (32 - leading)));
5391    }
5392    */
5393    public Coord[] asCoords()
5394    {
5395        return asCoords(new Coord[size()]);
5396
5397    }
5398    public Coord[] asCoords(Coord[] points)
5399    {
5400        if(points == null)
5401            points = new Coord[size()];
5402        int idx = 0, len = points.length;
5403        long t, w;
5404        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
5405            for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
5406                if((t = data[x * ySections + s]) != 0)
5407                {
5408                    w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
5409                    while (w != 0) {
5410                        if(idx >= len) return points;
5411                        points[idx++] = Coord.get(x, (s << 6) | Long.numberOfTrailingZeros(w));
5412                        t ^= w;
5413                        w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
5414                    }
5415                }
5416            }
5417        }
5418        return points;
5419    }
5420    public int[] asEncoded()
5421    {
5422        int ct = size(), idx = 0;
5423        int[] points = new int[ct];
5424        long t, w;
5425        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
5426            for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
5427                if((t = data[x * ySections + s]) != 0)
5428                {
5429                    w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
5430                    while (w != 0) {
5431                        points[idx++] = Coord.pureEncode(x, (s << 6) | Long.numberOfTrailingZeros(w));
5432                        t ^= w;
5433                        w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
5434                    }
5435                }
5436            }
5437        }
5438        return points;
5439    }

5489    public Coord first()

5493            for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
5494                if ((w = (data[x * ySections + s])) != 0) {
5495                    return Coord.get(x, (s << 6) | Long.numberOfTrailingZeros(w));
5496                }
5497            }
5498        }

5516     * Gets the last Coord in the iteration order, or (-1,-1) if this GreasedRegion is empty.
5517     * @return the last Coord in the iteration order, or (-1,-1) if this GreasedRegion is empty
5518     */
5519    public Coord last()
5520    {
5521        long w;
5522        for (int x = width - 1; x >= 0; x--) {
5523            for (int s = ySections - 1; s >= 0; s--) {
5524                if ((w = (data[x * ySections + s])) != 0) {
5525                    return Coord.get(x, (s << 6) | 63 - Long.numberOfLeadingZeros(w));
5526                }
5527            }
5528        }
5529        return Coord.get(-1, -1);

5545    public Coord nth(final int index)
5546    {
5547        if(index < 0)
5548            return Coord.get(-1, -1);
5549        int ct = size(), tmp;
5550        if(index >= ct)
5551            return Coord.get(-1, -1);
5552        long t, w;
5553        for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
5554            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
5555                if ((ct = counts[x * ySections + s]) > index) {
5556                    t = data[x * ySections + s];
5557                    w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
5558                    for (--ct; w != 0; ct--) {
5559                        if (ct == index)
5560                            return Coord.get(x, (s << 6) | Long.numberOfTrailingZeros(w));
5561                        t ^= w;
5562                        w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
5563                    }
5564                }
5565            }
5566        }
5567        return Coord.get(-1, -1);
5568    }

5578                if ((ct = counts[x * ySections + s]) > tmp) {

5584                        t ^= w;
5585                        w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
5586                    }
5587                }
5588            }
5589        }

5617    /**
5618     * Gets a single random Coord from the "on" positions in this GreasedRegion, or the Coord (-1,-1) if this is empty.
5619     * Uses the given IRNG to generate one random int, which is used as an index. The technique this uses to iterate
5620     * over bits can be credited to Erling Ellingsen and Daniel Lemire, found
5621     * <a href="https://lemire.me/blog/2013/12/23/even-faster-bitmap-decoding/">here</a>, and seems to be a little
5622     * faster than the previous method. The fastest way to get a random Coord from a GreasedRegion is to avoid iterating
5623     * over the bits at all, so if your region data doesn't change you should get it as a Coord array with
5624     * {@link #asCoords()} and call {@link IRNG#getRandomElement(Object[])} with that array as the parameter. If you
5625     * take the asCoords() call out of consideration, getting random elements out of an array (especially a large one)
5626     * can be hundreds of times faster.
5627     * @param rng an IRNG such as an {@link RNG} or {@link GWTRNG}
5628     * @return a single randomly-chosen Coord from the "on" positions in this GreasedRegion, or (-1,-1) if empty
5629     */
5630    public Coord singleRandom(IRNG rng)
5631    {
5632        int ct = size(), tmp = rng.nextInt(ct);
5633        long t, w;
5634        for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
5635            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
5636                if ((ct = counts[x * ySections + s]) > tmp) {
5637                    t = data[x * ySections + s] | 0L;
5638                    for (--ct; t != 0; ct--) {
5639                        w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
5640                        if (ct == tmp)
5641                            return Coord.get(x, (s << 6) | Long.bitCount(w-1));
5642                        t ^= w;
5643                    }
5644                }
5645            }
5646        }
5647        return Coord.get(-1, -1);
5648    }

5660                        if (ct == tmp)
5661                            return ((s << 6) | Long.numberOfTrailingZeros(w)) * width + x;
5662                        t ^= w;
5663                        w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);

5666            }
