5672    /**
5673     * Narrow-purpose; takes an x and a y value, each between 0 and 65535 inclusive, and interleaves their bits so the
5674     * least significant bit and every other bit after it are filled with the bits of x, while the
5675     * second-least-significant bit and every other bit after that are filled with the bits of y. Essentially, this
5676     * takes two numbers with bits labeled like {@code a b c} for x and {@code R S T} for y and makes a number with
5677     * those bits arranged like {@code R a S b T c}.
5678     * @param x an int between 0 and 65535, inclusive
5679     * @param y an int between 0 and 65535, inclusive
5680     * @return an int that interleaves x and y, with x in the least significant bit position
5681     */
5682    public static int interleaveBits(int x, int y)
5683    {
5684        x |= y << 16;
5685        x =    ((x & 0x0000ff00) << 8) | ((x >>> 8) & 0x0000ff00) | (x & 0xff0000ff);
5686        x =    ((x & 0x00f000f0) << 4) | ((x >>> 4) & 0x00f000f0) | (x & 0xf00ff00f);
5687        x =    ((x & 0x0c0c0c0c) << 2) | ((x >>> 2) & 0x0c0c0c0c) | (x & 0xc3c3c3c3);
5688        return ((x & 0x22222222) << 1) | ((x >>> 1) & 0x22222222) | (x & 0x99999999);
5689    }
5690
5691    /**
5692     * Narrow-purpose; takes an int that represents a distance down the Z-order curve and moves its bits around so that
5693     * its x component is stored in the bottom 16 bits (use {@code (n & 0xffff)} to obtain) and its y component is
5694     * stored in the upper 16 bits (use {@code (n >>> 16)} to obtain). This may be useful for ordering traversals of all
5695     * points in a GreasedRegion less predictably.
5696     * @param n an int that has already been interleaved, though this can really be any int
5697     * @return an int with x in its lower bits ({@code x = n & 0xffff;}) and y in its upper bits ({@code y = n >>> 16;})
5698     */
5699    public static int disperseBits(int n)
5700    {
5701        n =    ((n & 0x22222222) << 1) | ((n >>> 1) & 0x22222222) | (n & 0x99999999);
5702        n =    ((n & 0x0c0c0c0c) << 2) | ((n >>> 2) & 0x0c0c0c0c) | (n & 0xc3c3c3c3);
5703        n =    ((n & 0x00f000f0) << 4) | ((n >>> 4) & 0x00f000f0) | (n & 0xf00ff00f);
5704        return ((n & 0x0000ff00) << 8) | ((n >>> 8) & 0x0000ff00) | (n & 0xff0000ff);
5705    }
5706    private static int nextPowerOfTwo(int n)
5707    {
5708        final int highest = Integer.highestOneBit(n);
5709        return  (highest == NumberTools.lowestOneBit(n)) ? highest : highest << 1;
5710    }
5711
5712    /**
5713     * Like {@link #nth(int)}, this gets the Coord at a given index along a path through the GreasedRegion, but unlike
5714     * nth(), this traverses the path in a zig-zag pattern called the Z-Order Curve. This method is often not very fast
5715     * compared to nth(), but this different path can help if iteration needs to seem less regular while still covering
5716     * all "on" cells in the GresedRegion eventually.
5717     * @param index the distance along the Z-order curve to travel, only counting "on" cells in this GreasedRegion.
5718     * @return the Coord at the given distance, or the Coord with x and y both -1 if index is too high or low
5719     */
5720    public Coord nthZCurve(final int index)
5721    {
5722        int ct = -1, x, y, s, d, max = nextPowerOfTwo(width) * nextPowerOfTwo(height);
5723        long t, w;
5724        for (int o = 0; o < max; o++) {
5725            d = disperseBits(o);
5726            x = d & 0xffff;
5727            y = d >>> 16;
5728            if(x >= width && y >= height)
5729                break;
5730            if(x >= width)
5731                continue;
5732            if(y >= height)
5733                continue;
5734            s = d >>> 22;
5735            t = data[x * ySections + s];
5736            if((ct += (t >>> (y & 63) & 1L)) == index)
5737                return Coord.get(x, y);
5738        }
5739        return Coord.get(-1, -1);
5740    }
5741    /**
5742     * Like {@link #nth(int)}, this finds a given index along a path through the GreasedRegion, but unlike nth(), this
5743     * traverses the path in a zig-zag pattern called the Z-Order Curve, and unlike {@link #nthZCurve(int)}, this does
5744     * not return a Coord and instead produces a "tight"-encoded int. This method is often not very fast compared to
5745     * nth(), but this different path can help if iteration needs to seem less regular while still covering all "on"
5746     * cells in the GreasedRegion eventually, and the tight encoding may be handy if you need to use ints.
5747     * @param index the distance along the Z-order curve to travel, only counting "on" cells in this GreasedRegion.
5748     * @return the "tight" encoded point at the given distance, or -1 if index is too high or low
5749     */
5750
5751    public int nthZCurveTight(final int index)
5752    {
5753        int ct = -1, x, y, s, d, max = nextPowerOfTwo(width) * nextPowerOfTwo(height);
5754        long t;
5755        for (int o = 0; o < max; o++) {
5756            d = disperseBits(o);
5757            x = d & 0xffff;
5758            y = d >>> 16;
5759            if(x >= width && y >= height)
5760                break;
5761            if(x >= width)
5762                continue;
5763            if(y >= height)
5764                continue;
5765            s = d >>> 22;
5766            t = data[x * ySections + s];
5767            if((ct += (t >>> (y & 63) & 1L)) == index)
5768                return y * width + x;
5769        }
5770        return -1;
5771    }
5772
5773    /**
5774     * Gets a Coord array from the "on" contents of this GreasedRegion, using a quasi-random scattering of chosen cells
5775     * with a count that matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells in this. This is quasi-
5776     * random instead of pseudo-random because it is somewhat less likely to produce nearby cells in the result. If you
5777     * request too many cells (too high of a value for fraction), it will start to overlap, however. Contrast with
5778     * {@link #mixedRandomSeparated(double, int)}, which tends to overlap more frequently. This method seems to work
5779     * well because it chooses quasi-random points by their index in the Z-Order Curve as opposed to the simpler
5780     * approach mixedRandomSeparated uses to traverse points (which just runs through the "on" cells a column at a time,
5781     * not caring if two points are in adjacent cells as long as they are in different columns). Testing with a dungeon
5782     * layout of mostly-on cells, this method has no overlap with a fraction of 0.4, while mixedRandomSeparated has
5783     * overlap as early as 0.15 for fraction, and it only gets worse at higher values. A change to the algorithm used by
5784     * {@link #quasiRandomSeparated(double)} has it overlapping at the same rate as this method, though it should be
5785     * much faster. This method can be especially slow, since each Z-Order traversal may need to try many cells that are
5786     * outside the GreasedRegion but are on the Z-Order Curve.
5787     * Does not restrict the size of the returned array other than only using up to {@code fraction * size()} cells.
5788     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
5789     * @return a freshly-allocated Coord array containing the quasi-random cells
5790     */
5791    public Coord[] separatedZCurve(double fraction)
5792    {
5793        return separatedZCurve(fraction, -1);
5794    }
5795
5796    /**
5797     * Gets a Coord array from the "on" contents of this GreasedRegion, using a quasi-random scattering of chosen cells
5798     * with a count that matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells in this. This is quasi-
5799     * random instead of pseudo-random because it is somewhat less likely to produce nearby cells in the result. If you
5800     * request too many cells (too high of a value for fraction), it will start to overlap, however. Contrast with
5801     * {@link #mixedRandomSeparated(double, int)}, which tends to overlap more frequently. This method seems to work
5802     * well because it chooses quasi-random points by their index in the Z-Order Curve as opposed to the simpler
5803     * approach mixedRandomSeparated uses to traverse points (which just runs through the "on" cells a column at a time,
5804     * not caring if two points are in adjacent cells as long as they are in different columns). Testing with a dungeon
5805     * layout of mostly-on cells, this method has no overlap with a fraction of 0.4, while mixedRandomSeparated has
5806     * overlap as early as 0.15 for fraction, and it only gets worse at higher values. A change to the algorithm used by
5807     * {@link #quasiRandomSeparated(double, int)} has it overlapping at the same rate as this method, though it should
5808     * be much faster. This method can be especially slow, since each Z-Order traversal may need to try many cells that
5809     * are outside the GreasedRegion but are on the Z-Order Curve.
5810     * Restricts the total size of the returned array to a maximum of {@code limit} (minimum is 0 if no cells are "on").
5811     * If limit is negative, this will not restrict the size.
5812     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
5813     * @param limit the maximum size of the array to return
5814     * @return a freshly-allocated Coord array containing the quasi-random cells
5815     */
5816    public Coord[] separatedZCurve(double fraction, int limit)
5817    {
5818        if(fraction < 0)
5819            return new Coord[0];
5820        if(fraction > 1)
5821            fraction = 1;
5822        int ct = size(), total;
5823        total = ct;
5824        ct *= fraction;
5825        if(limit >= 0 && limit < ct)
5826            ct = limit;
5827        Coord[] vl = new Coord[ct];
5828        for (int i = 0; i < ct; i++)
5829        {
5830            vl[i] = nthZCurve((int) (VanDerCorputQRNG.determine2(i ^ i >>> 1) * total));
5831        }
5832        return vl;
5833    }
5834    /**
5835     * Modifies this GreasedRegion so it contains a quasi-random subset of its previous contents, choosing cells so that
5836     * the {@link #size()} matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells in this. This is quasi-
5837     * random instead of pseudo-random because it is somewhat less likely to produce nearby cells in the result. If you
5838     * request too many cells (too high of a value for fraction), it will start to overlap, however. Contrast with
5839     * {@link #mixedRandomRegion(double)}, which tends to overlap more frequently. This method seems to work
5840     * well because it chooses quasi-random points by their index in the Z-Order Curve as opposed to the simpler
5841     * approach mixedRandomRegion uses to traverse points (which just runs through the "on" cells a column at a time,
5842     * not caring if two points are in adjacent cells as long as they are in different columns). Testing with a dungeon
5843     * layout of mostly-on cells, this method has no overlap with a fraction of 0.4, while mixedRandomRegion has
5844     * overlap as early as 0.15 for fraction, and it only gets worse at higher values. A change to the algorithm used by
5845     * {@link #quasiRandomRegion(double)} has it overlapping at the same rate as this method, though it should be much
5846     * faster. This method can be especially slow, since each Z-Order traversal may need to try many cells that are
5847     * outside the GreasedRegion but are on the Z-Order Curve.
5848     * Does not restrict the size of the returned array other than only using up to {@code fraction * size()} cells.
5849     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
5850     * @return this, after modifications, for chaining
5851     */
5852    public GreasedRegion separatedRegionZCurve(double fraction)
5853    {
5854        return separatedRegionZCurve(fraction, -1);
5855    }

5857    /**
5858     * Modifies this GreasedRegion so it contains a quasi-random subset of its previous contents, choosing cells so that
5859     * the {@link #size()} matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells in this. This is quasi-
5860     * random instead of pseudo-random because it is somewhat less likely to produce nearby cells in the result. If you
5861     * request too many cells (too high of a value for fraction), it will start to overlap, however. Contrast with
5862     * {@link #mixedRandomRegion(double, int)}, which tends to overlap more frequently. This method seems to work
5863     * well because it chooses quasi-random points by their index in the Z-Order Curve as opposed to the simpler
5864     * approach mixedRandomRegion uses to traverse points (which just runs through the "on" cells a column at a time,
5865     * not caring if two points are in adjacent cells as long as they are in different columns). Testing with a dungeon
5866     * layout of mostly-on cells, this method has no overlap with a fraction of 0.4, while mixedRandomRegion has
5867     * overlap as early as 0.15 for fraction, and it only gets worse at higher values. A change to the algorithm used by
5868     * {@link #quasiRandomRegion(double, int)} has it overlapping at the same rate as this method, though it should be
5869     * much faster. This method can be especially slow, since each Z-Order traversal may need to try many cells that
5870     * are outside the GreasedRegion but are on the Z-Order Curve.
5871     * Restricts the total size of the returned array to a maximum of {@code limit} (minimum is 0 if no cells are "on").
5872     * If limit is negative, this will not restrict the size.
5873     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
5874     * @param limit the maximum size of the array to return
5875     * @return this, after modifications, for chaining
5876     */
5877    public GreasedRegion separatedRegionZCurve(double fraction, int limit)
5878    {
5879        if(fraction <= 0)
5880            return empty();
5881        if(fraction >= 1)
5882            return this;
5883        int ct = size(), total;
5884        if(limit >= ct)
5885            return this;
5886        total = ct;
5887        ct *= fraction;
5888        if(limit >= 0 && limit < ct)
5889            ct = limit;
5890        int[] vl = new int[ct];
5891        for (int i = 0; i < ct; i++)
5892        {
5893            vl[i] = nthZCurveTight((int) (VanDerCorputQRNG.determine2(i ^ i >>> 1) * total));
5894        }
5895        return empty().insertSeveral(vl);
5896    }

5898    /**
5899     * Gets a Coord array from the "on" contents of this GreasedRegion, using a quasi-random scattering of chosen cells
5900     * with a count that matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells in this. This is quasi-
5901     * random instead of pseudo-random because it uses blue noise to sharply limit the likelihood of nearby points being
5902     * chosen when fraction is small. If you request too many cells (too high of a value for fraction), it will start to
5903     * have nearby cells, however. Does not restrict the size of the returned array other than only using up to
5904     * {@code fraction * size()} cells.
5905     * <br>
5906     * Also take a look at {@link #separatedZCurve(double, int)}, {@link #quasiRandomSeparated(double, int)},
5907     * {@link #mixedRandomSeparated(double, int, long)}, and {@link #separatedRegionBlue(double, int)}. Internally, this
5908     * is a thin wrapper around {@link #separatedRegionBlue(double, int)}, and won't be more efficient than that method.
5909     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
5910     * @return a freshly-allocated Coord array containing the quasi-random cells
5911     */
5912    public Coord[] separatedBlue(double fraction)
5913    {
5914        return separatedBlue(fraction, -1);
5915    }

5917    /**
5918     * Gets a Coord array from the "on" contents of this GreasedRegion, using a quasi-random scattering of chosen cells
5919     * with a count that matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells in this. This is quasi-
5920     * random instead of pseudo-random because it uses blue noise to sharply limit the likelihood of nearby points being
5921     * chosen when fraction is small. If you request too many cells (too high of a value for fraction), it will start to
5922     * have nearby cells, however. Restricts the total size of the returned array to a maximum of {@code limit} (minimum
5923     * is 0 if no cells are "on"). If limit is negative, this will not restrict the size.
5924     * <br>
5925     * Also take a look at {@link #separatedZCurve(double, int)}, {@link #quasiRandomSeparated(double, int)},
5926     * {@link #mixedRandomSeparated(double, int, long)}, and {@link #separatedRegionBlue(double, int)}. Internally, this
5927     * is a thin wrapper around {@link #separatedRegionBlue(double, int)}, and won't be more efficient than that method.
5928     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
5929     * @param limit the maximum size of the array to return; may return less
5930     * @return a freshly-allocated Coord array containing the quasi-random cells
5931     */
5932    public Coord[] separatedBlue(double fraction, int limit)
5933    {
5934        if(fraction <= 0)
5935            return new Coord[0];
5936        if(fraction > 0xFFp-8)
5937            fraction = 0xFFp-8;
5938        int ct = size();
5939        if(limit >= ct)
5940            return asCoords();
5941        return copy().separatedRegionBlue(fraction, limit).asCoords();
5942    }
5943    /**
5944     * Modifies this GreasedRegion so it contains a quasi-random subset of its previous contents, choosing cells so that
5945     * the {@link #size()} matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells in this. This is quasi-
5946     * random instead of pseudo-random because it uses blue noise to sharply limit the likelihood of nearby points being
5947     * chosen when fraction is small. If you request too many cells (too high of a value for fraction), it will start to
5948     * have nearby cells, however. Does not restrict the size of the returned GreasedRegion other than only using up to
5949     * {@code fraction * size()} cells.
5950     * <br>
5951     * Also take a look at {@link #separatedRegionZCurve(double, int)}, {@link #quasiRandomRegion(double, int)},
5952     * {@link #mixedRandomRegion(double, int, long)}, and {@link #separatedBlue(double, int)}.
5953     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
5954     * @return this, after modifications, for chaining

5956    public GreasedRegion separatedRegionBlue(double fraction)

5961    /**
5962     * Modifies this GreasedRegion so it contains a quasi-random subset of its previous contents, choosing cells so that
5963     * the {@link #size()} matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells in this. This is quasi-
5964     * random instead of pseudo-random because it uses blue noise to sharply limit the likelihood of nearby points being
5965     * chosen when fraction is small. If you request too many cells (too high of a value for fraction), it will start to
5966     * have nearby cells, however. Restricts the total size of the returned GreasedRegion to a maximum of {@code limit}
5967     * (minimum is 0 if no cells are "on"). If limit is negative, this will not restrict the size.
5968     * <br>
5969     * Also take a look at {@link #separatedRegionZCurve(double, int)}, {@link #quasiRandomRegion(double, int)},
5970     * {@link #mixedRandomRegion(double, int, long)}, and {@link #separatedBlue(double, int)}.
5971     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to quasi-randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
5972     * @param limit the maximum size of the array to return; may return less
5973     * @return this, after modifications, for chaining
5974     */
5975    public GreasedRegion separatedRegionBlue(double fraction, int limit)
5976    {
5977        if(fraction <= 0)
5978            return empty();
5979        if(fraction > 0xFFp-8)
5980            fraction = 0xFFp-8;
5981        int ct = size();
5982        if(limit >= ct)
5983            return this;
5984        ct *= fraction;
5985        if(limit >= 0 && limit < ct)
5986            ct = limit;
5987        for (int i = 255; i >= 0; i--) {
5988            if(ct >= andWrapping64(BlueNoise.LEVELS[i]).size())
5989                return this;
5990        }
5991        return this;
5992    }
5993
5994    public Coord[] randomPortion(IRNG rng, int size)
5995    {
5996        int ct = size(), idx = 0, run = 0;
5997        if(ct <= 0 || size <= 0)
5998            return new Coord[0];
5999        if(ct <= size)
6000            return asCoords();
6001        Coord[] points = new Coord[size];
6002        int[] order = rng.randomOrdering(ct);
6003        Arrays.sort(order, 0, size);
6004        long t, w;
6005        ALL:
6006        for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
6007            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
6008                if((t = data[x * ySections + s]) != 0)
6009                {
6010                    w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
6011                    while (w != 0) {
6012                        if (run++ == order[idx]) {
6013                            points[idx++] = Coord.get(x, (s << 6) | Long.numberOfTrailingZeros(w));
6014                            if (idx >= size) break ALL;
6015                        }
6016                        t ^= w;
6017                        w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
6018                    }
6019                }
6020            }
6021        }
6022        return points;
6023    }
6024
6025    public GreasedRegion randomRegion(IRNG rng, int size)
6026    {
6027        int ct = size(), idx = 0, run = 0;
6028        if(ct <= 0 || size <= 0)
6029            return empty();
6030        if(ct <= size)
6031            return this;
6032        int[] order = rng.randomOrdering(ct);
6033        Arrays.sort(order, 0, size);
6034        long t, w;
6035        ALL:
6036        for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
6037            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
6038                if((t = data[x * ySections + s]) != 0)
6039                {
6040                    w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
6041                    while (w != 0) {
6042                        if (run++ == order[idx]) {
6043                            if(++idx >= size) break ALL;
6044                        }
6045                        else
6046                        {
6047                            data[x * ySections + s] &= ~(1L << Long.numberOfTrailingZeros(w));
6048                        }
6049                        t ^= w;
6050                        w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
6051                    }
6052                }
6053            }
6054        }
6055        tallied = false;
6056        return this;
6057    }
6058
6059    @Override
6060    public boolean contains(int x, int y)
6061    {
6062        return x >= 0 && y >= 0 && x < width && y < height && ySections > 0 &&
6063                ((data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] & (1L << (y & 63))) != 0);
6064    }
6065
6066
6067    /**
6068     * @return Whether this zone is empty.
6069     */
6070    @Override
6071    public boolean isEmpty() {
6072        if(tallied) return ct > 0;
6073        for (int i = 0; i < data.length; i++) {
6074            if(data[i] != 0L) return false;
6075        }
6076        return true;
6077    }
6078
6079    /**
6080     * Generates a 2D int array from an array or vararg of GreasedRegions, starting at all 0 and adding 1 to the int at
6081     * a position once for every GreasedRegion that has that cell as "on." This means if you give 8 GreasedRegions to
6082     * this method, it can produce any number between 0 and 8 in a cell; if you give 16 GreasedRegions, then it can
6083     * produce any number between 0 and 16 in a cell.
6084     * @param regions an array or vararg of GreasedRegions; must all have the same width and height
6085     * @return a 2D int array with the same width and height as the regions, where an int cell equals the number of given GreasedRegions that had an "on" cell at that position
6086     */
6087    public static int[][] sum(GreasedRegion... regions)
6088    {
6089        if(regions == null || regions.length <= 0)
6090            return new int[0][0];
6091        int w = regions[0].width, h = regions[0].height, l = regions.length, ys = regions[0].ySections;
6092        int[][] numbers = new int[w][h];
6093        for (int x = 0; x < w; x++) {
6094            for (int y = 0; y < h; y++) {
6095                for (int i = 0; i < l; i++) {
6096                    numbers[x][y] += (regions[i].data[x * ys + (y >> 6)] & (1L << (y & 63))) != 0 ? 1 : 0;
6097                }
6098            }
6099        }
6100        return numbers;
6101    }
6102
6103    /**
6104     * Generates a 2D int array from a List of GreasedRegions, starting at all 0 and adding 1 to the int at
6105     * a position once for every GreasedRegion that has that cell as "on." This means if you give 8 GreasedRegions to
6106     * this method, it can produce any number between 0 and 8 in a cell; if you give 16 GreasedRegions, then it can
6107     * produce any number between 0 and 16 in a cell.
6108     * @param regions a List of GreasedRegions; must all have the same width and height
6109     * @return a 2D int array with the same width and height as the regions, where an int cell equals the number of given GreasedRegions that had an "on" cell at that position
6110     */
6111    public static int[][] sum(List<GreasedRegion> regions)
6112    {
6113        if(regions == null || regions.isEmpty())
6114            return new int[0][0];
6115        GreasedRegion t = regions.get(0);
6116        int w = t.width, h = t.height, l = regions.size(), ys = t.ySections;
6117        int[][] numbers = new int[w][h];
6118        for (int x = 0; x < w; x++) {
6119            for (int y = 0; y < h; y++) {
6120                for (int i = 0; i < l; i++) {
6121                    numbers[x][y] += (regions.get(i).data[x * ys + (y >> 6)] & (1L << (y & 63))) != 0 ? 1 : 0;
6122                }
6123            }
6124        }
6125        return numbers;
6126    }
6127
6128    /**
6129     * Generates a 2D double array from an array or vararg of GreasedRegions, starting at all 0 and adding 1 to the double at
6130     * a position once for every GreasedRegion that has that cell as "on." This means if you give 8 GreasedRegions to
6131     * this method, it can produce any number between 0 and 8 in a cell; if you give 16 GreasedRegions, then it can
6132     * produce any number between 0 and 16 in a cell.
6133     * @param regions an array or vararg of GreasedRegions; must all have the same width and height
6134     * @return a 2D double array with the same width and height as the regions, where an double cell equals the number of given GreasedRegions that had an "on" cell at that position
6135     */
6136    public static double[][] sumDouble(GreasedRegion... regions)
6137    {
6138        if(regions == null || regions.length <= 0)
6139            return new double[0][0];
6140        int w = regions[0].width, h = regions[0].height, l = regions.length, ys = regions[0].ySections;
6141        double[][] numbers = new double[w][h];
6142        for (int x = 0; x < w; x++) {
6143            for (int y = 0; y < h; y++) {
6144                for (int i = 0; i < l; i++) {
6145                    numbers[x][y] += (regions[i].data[x * ys + (y >> 6)] & (1L << (y & 63))) != 0 ? 1.0 : 0.0;
6146                }
6147            }
6148        }
6149        return numbers;
6150    }

6152    /**
6153     * Generates a 2D double array from a List of GreasedRegions, starting at all 0 and adding 1 to the double at
6154     * a position once for every GreasedRegion that has that cell as "on." This means if you give 8 GreasedRegions to
6155     * this method, it can produce any number between 0 and 8 in a cell; if you give 16 GreasedRegions, then it can
6156     * produce any number between 0 and 16 in a cell.
6157     * @param regions a List of GreasedRegions; must all have the same width and height
6158     * @return a 2D double array with the same width and height as the regions, where an double cell equals the number of given GreasedRegions that had an "on" cell at that position
6159     */
6160    public static double[][] sumDouble(List<GreasedRegion> regions)
6161    {
6162        if(regions == null || regions.isEmpty())
6163            return new double[0][0];
6164        GreasedRegion t = regions.get(0);
6165        int w = t.width, h = t.height, l = regions.size(), ys = t.ySections;
6166        double[][] numbers = new double[w][h];
6167        for (int x = 0; x < w; x++) {
6168            for (int y = 0; y < h; y++) {
6169                for (int i = 0; i < l; i++) {
6170                    numbers[x][y] += (regions.get(i).data[x * ys + (y >> 6)] & (1L << (y & 63))) != 0 ? 1.0 : 0.0;
6171                }
6172            }
6173        }
6174        return numbers;
6175    }

6177    /**
6178     * Generates a 2D int array from an array of GreasedRegions and an array of weights, starting the 2D result at all 0
6179     * and, for every GreasedRegion that has that cell as "on," adding the int in the corresponding weights array at
6180     * the position of that cell. This means if you give an array of 4 GreasedRegions to this method along with the
6181     * weights {@code 1, 2, 3, 4}, it can produce a number between 0 and 10 in a cell (where 10 is used when all 4
6182     * GreasedRegions have a cell "on," since {@code 1 + 2 + 3 + 4 == 10}); if the weights are instead
6183     * {@code 1, 10, 100, 1000}, then the results can vary between 0 and 1111, where 1111 is only if all GreasedRegions
6184     * have a cell as "on." The weights array must have a length at least equal to the length of the regions array.
6185     * @param regions an array of GreasedRegions; must all have the same width and height
6186     * @param weights an array of ints; must have length at least equal to regions' length
6187     * @return a 2D int array with the same width and height as the regions, where an int cell equals the sum of the weights corresponding to GreasedRegions that had an "on" cell at that position
6188     */
6189    public static int[][] sumWeighted(GreasedRegion[] regions, int[] weights)
6190    {
6191        if(regions == null || regions.length <= 0 || weights == null || weights.length < regions.length)
6192            return new int[0][0];
6193        int w = regions[0].width, h = regions[0].height, l = regions.length, ys = regions[0].ySections;
6194        int[][] numbers = new int[w][h];
6195        for (int x = 0; x < w; x++) {
6196            for (int y = 0; y < h; y++) {
6197                for (int i = 0; i < l; i++) {
6198                    numbers[x][y] += (regions[i].data[x * ys + (y >> 6)] & (1L << (y & 63))) != 0 ? weights[i] : 0;
6199                }
6200            }
6201        }
6202        return numbers;
6203    }

6233    /**
6234     * Adds to an existing 2D int array with an array or vararg of GreasedRegions, adding 1 to the int in existing at
6235     * a position once for every GreasedRegion that has that cell as "on." This means if you give 8 GreasedRegions to
6236     * this method, it can increment by any number between 0 and 8 in a cell; if you give 16 GreasedRegions, then it can
6237     * increase the value in existing by any number between 0 and 16 in a cell.
6238     * @param existing a non-null 2D int array that will have each cell incremented by the sum of the GreasedRegions
6239     * @param regions an array or vararg of GreasedRegions; must all have the same width and height
6240     * @return existing, after modification, where an int cell will be changed by the number of given GreasedRegions that had an "on" cell at that position
6241     */
6242    public static int[][] sumInto(int[][] existing, GreasedRegion... regions)
6243    {
6244        if(regions == null || regions.length <= 0 || existing == null || existing.length == 0 || existing[0].length == 0)
6245            return existing;
6246        int w = existing.length, h = existing[0].length, l = regions.length, ys;
6247        for (int i = 0; i < l; i++) {
6248            GreasedRegion region = regions[i];
6249            ys = region.ySections;
6250            for (int x = 0; x < w && x < region.width; x++) {
6251                for (int y = 0; y < h && y < region.height; y++) {
6252                    existing[x][y] += (region.data[x * ys + (y >> 6)] & (1L << (y & 63))) != 0 ? 1 : 0;
6253                }
6254            }
6255        }
6256        return existing;
6257    }

6284    /**
6285     * Discouraged from active use; slower than {@link squidpony.squidai.DijkstraMap} and has less features.
6286     * @param map a 2D char array where '#' is a wall
6287     * @param goals an array or vararg of Coord to get the distances toward
6288     * @return a 2D double array of distances from a cell to the nearest goal
6289     */
6290    public static double[][] dijkstraScan(char[][] map, Coord... goals)
6291    {
6292        if(map == null || map.length <= 0 || map[0].length <= 0 || goals == null || goals.length <= 0)
6293            return new double[0][0];
6294        int w = map.length, h = map[0].length, ys = (h + 63) >>> 6;
6295        double[][] numbers = new double[w][h];
6296        GreasedRegion walls = new GreasedRegion(map, '#'), floors = new GreasedRegion(walls).not(),
6297                middle = new GreasedRegion(w, h, goals).and(floors);
6298        ArrayList<GreasedRegion> regions = middle.floodSeriesToLimit(floors);
6299        int l = regions.size();
6300        for (int x = 0; x < w; x++) {
6301            for (int y = 0; y < h; y++) {
6302                for (int i = 0; i < l; i++) {
6303                    numbers[x][y] += (regions.get(i).data[x * ys + (y >> 6)] & (1L << (y & 63))) != 0 ? 1 : 0;
6304                }
6305            }
6306        }
6307        return numbers;
6308    }

6335    /**
6336     * Generates a 2D int array from an array or vararg of GreasedRegions, treating each cell in the nth region as the
6337     * nth bit of the int at the corresponding x,y cell in the int array. This means if you give 8 GreasedRegions to
6338     * this method, it can produce any 8-bit number in a cell (0-255); if you give 16 GreasedRegions, then it can
6339     * produce any 16-bit number (0-65535).
6340     * @param regions an array or vararg of GreasedRegions; must all have the same width and height
6341     * @return a 2D int array with the same width and height as the regions, with bits per int taken from the regions
6342     */
6343    public static int[][] bitSum(GreasedRegion... regions)
6344    {
6345        if(regions == null || regions.length <= 0)
6346            return new int[0][0];
6347        int w = regions[0].width, h = regions[0].height, l = Math.min(32, regions.length), ys = regions[0].ySections;
6348        int[][] numbers = new int[w][h];
6349        for (int x = 0; x < w; x++) {
6350            for (int y = 0; y < h; y++) {
6351                for (int i = 0; i < l; i++) {
6352                    numbers[x][y] |= (regions[i].data[x * ys + (y >> 6)] & (1L << (y & 63))) != 0 ? 1 << i : 0;
6353                }
6354            }
6355        }
6356        return numbers;
6357    }

6374    @Override
6375    public boolean equals(Object o) {
6376        if (this == o) return true;
6377        if (o == null || getClass() != o.getClass()) return false;
6378
6379        GreasedRegion that = (GreasedRegion) o;
6380
6381        if (height != that.height) return false;
6382        if (width != that.width) return false;
6383        if (ySections != that.ySections) return false;
6384        if (yEndMask != that.yEndMask) return false;
6385        return Arrays.equals(data, that.data);
6386    }

6425    /**
6426     * Computes a 64-bit hash code of this GreasedRegion given a 64-bit seed; even if given two very similar seeds,
6427     * this should produce very different hash codes for the same GreasedRegion.
6428     * <br>
6429     * Meant for potential use in Bloom filters. Uses {@link CrossHash.Yolk}'s algorithm(s).
6430     * @param seed a seed that will determine how the hashing algorithm works; all 64 bits are used.
6431     * @return a 64-bit hash code for this GreasedRegion
6432     */
6433    public long hash64(long seed)
6434    {
6435        seed += b1;
6436        seed ^= seed >>> 23 ^ seed >>> 48 ^ seed << 7 ^ seed << 53;
6437        long a = seed + b4, b = seed + b3, c = seed + b2, d = seed + b1;
6438        final int len = data.length;
6439        for (int i = 3; i < len; i+=4) {
6440            a ^= data[i-3] * b1; a = (a << 23 | a >>> 41) * b3;
6441            b ^= data[i-2] * b2; b = (b << 25 | b >>> 39) * b4;
6442            c ^= data[i-1] * b3; c = (c << 29 | c >>> 35) * b5;
6443            d ^= data[i  ] * b4; d = (d << 31 | d >>> 33) * b1;
6444            seed += a + b + c + d;
6445        }
6446        seed += b5;
6447        switch (len & 3) {
6448            case 1: seed = wow(seed, b1 ^ data[len-1]); break;
6449            case 2: seed = wow(seed + data[len-2], b2 + data[len-1]); break;
6450            case 3: seed = wow(seed + data[len-3], b2 + data[len-2]) ^ wow(seed + data[len-1], seed ^ b3); break;
6451        }
6452        seed = wow(seed + height, b4 + width);
6453        seed = (seed ^ seed << 16) * (len ^ b0 ^ seed >>> 32);
6454        return seed - (seed >>> 31) + (seed << 33);
6455
6456    }

6458    public String serializeToString()
6459    {
6460        return width +
6461                "," + height +
6462                "," + StringKit.joinAlt(",",data);
6463    }
6464    public static GreasedRegion deserializeFromString(String s)
6465    {
6466        if(s == null || s.isEmpty())
6467            return null;
6468        int gap = s.indexOf(','), w = Integer.parseInt(s.substring(0, gap)),
6469                gap2 = s.indexOf(',', gap+1), h = Integer.parseInt(s.substring(gap+1, gap2));
6470        String[] splits = StringKit.split(s.substring(gap2+1), ",");
6471        long[] data = new long[splits.length];
6472        for (int i = 0; i < splits.length; i++) {
6473            data[i] = StringKit.longFromDec(splits[i]);
6474        }
6475        return new GreasedRegion(data, w, h);
6476    }

6486    public static GreasedRegion of(final int width, final int height, final long... data)

6491    /**
6492     * Compresses this GreasedRegion into a UTF-16 String and returns the String without modifying this GreasedRegion.
6493     * Uses {@link CoordPacker}'s algorithm and data to compress this GreasedRegion in 256x128 blocks, storing the
6494     * CoordPacker-like data as chars with values from 256 to 33023 (a concept also used in {@link squidpony.LZSPlus}),
6495     * and using ASCII semicolons to separate them or store other info (just width and height, which are given first as
6496     * 16 hex digits).
6497     * @return a String that could be used to reconstruct this GreasedRegion using {@link #decompress(String)}
6498     */
6499    @Beta
6500    public String toCompressedString()
6501    {
6502        CoordPacker.init();
6503        StringBuilder packing = new StringBuilder(width * height >> 3);
6504        StringKit.appendHex(packing, width);
6505        StringKit.appendHex(packing, height);
6506        final int chunksX = width + 255 >> 8, chunksY = height + 127 >> 7;
6507        for (int bigX = 0, baseX = 0; bigX < chunksX; bigX++, baseX += 256) {
6508            for (int bigY = 0, baseY = 0; bigY < chunksY; bigY++, baseY += 128) {
6509                packing.append(';');
6510                boolean on = false, current;
6511                short skip = 0, hx, hy;
6512                int xSize = Math.min(256, width - baseX), ySize = Math.min(128, height - baseY),
6513                        limit = 0x8000, mapLimit = xSize * ySize;
6514                if (xSize <= 128) {
6515                    limit >>= 1;
6516                    if (xSize <= 64) {
6517                        limit >>= 1;
6518                        if (ySize <= 64) {
6519                            limit >>= 1;
6520                            if (ySize <= 32) {
6521                                limit >>= 1;
6522                                if (xSize <= 32) {
6523                                    limit >>= 1;
6524                                }
6525                            }
6526                        }
6527                    }
6528                }
6529                for (int i = 0, ml = 0; i < limit && ml < mapLimit; i++, skip++) {
6530                    hx = CoordPacker.hilbertX[i];
6531                    hy = CoordPacker.hilbertY[i];
6532                    if (hx >= xSize || hy >= ySize) {
6533                        if (on) {
6534                            on = false;
6535                            packing.append((char) (skip + 256));
6536                            skip = 0;
6537                        }
6538                        continue;
6539                    }
6540                    ml++;
6541                    current = ((data[(baseX + hx) * ySections + (baseY + hy >> 6)] & (1L << hy)) != 0);
6542                    if (current != on) {
6543                        packing.append((char) (skip + 256));
6544                        skip = 0;
6545                        on = current;
6546                    }
6547                }
6548                if (on)
6549                    packing.append((char) (skip + 256));
6550            }
6551        }
6552        return packing.toString();
6553    }
6554
6555    /**
6556     * Decompresses a String returned by {@link #toCompressedString()}, returning a new GreasedRegion with identical
6557     * width, height, and contents to the GreasedRegion before compression.
6558     * @param compressed a String that was compressed by {@link #toCompressedString()}, without changes
6559     * @return a new copy of the GreasedRegion that was previously compressed
6560     */
6561    @Beta
6562    public static GreasedRegion decompress(String compressed)
6563    {
6564        CoordPacker.init();
6565        GreasedRegion target;
6566        final int width = StringKit.intFromHex(compressed), height = StringKit.intFromHex(compressed, 8, 16);
6567        target = new GreasedRegion(width, height);
6568        final int chunksX = width + 255 >> 8, chunksY = height + 127 >> 7;
6569        int startPack = 16, endPack, idx;//, hy;
6570        boolean on;
6571        for (int bigX = 0, baseX = 0; bigX < chunksX; bigX++, baseX += 256) {
6572            for (int bigY = 0, baseY = 0; bigY < chunksY; bigY++, baseY += 128) {
6573                ++startPack;
6574                endPack = compressed.indexOf(';', startPack);
6575                if(endPack < 0) endPack = compressed.length();
6576                on = false;
6577                idx = 0;
6578                for(int p = startPack; p < endPack; p++, on = !on) {
6579                    if (on) {
6580                        for (int toSkip = idx + (compressed.charAt(p) - 256); idx < toSkip && idx < 0x8000; idx++) {
6581                            target.insert(CoordPacker.hilbertX[idx] + baseX, CoordPacker.hilbertY[idx] + baseY);
6582                            //hy = CoordPacker.hilbertY[idx] + baseY;
6583                            //target.data[(CoordPacker.hilbertX[idx] + baseX) * target.ySections + (hy >> 6)] |= 1L << (hy & 63);
6584                        }
6585                    } else {
6586                        idx += compressed.charAt(p) - 256;
6587                    }
6588                }
6589                startPack = endPack;
6590            }
6591        }
6592//        target.tallied = false;
6593        return target;
6594    }

6678    @Override
6679    public boolean retainAll(Collection<?> c) {
6680        GreasedRegion g2 = new GreasedRegion(width, height);
6681        for(Object o : c)
6682        {
6683            if(contains(o) && o instanceof Coord)
6684            {
6685                g2.add((Coord)o);
6686            }
6687        }
6688        boolean changed = equals(g2);
6689        remake(g2);
6690        return changed;
6691    }

6693    /**
6694     * Randomly removes points from a GreasedRegion, with larger values for preservation keeping more of the existing
6695     * shape intact. If preservation is 1, roughly 1/2 of all points will be removed; if 2, roughly 1/4, if 3, roughly
6696     * 1/8, and so on, so that preservation can be thought of as a negative exponent of 2.
6697     * @param rng used to determine random factors
6698     * @param preservation roughly what degree of points to remove (higher keeps more); removes about {@code 1/(2^preservation)} points
6699     * @return a randomly modified change to this GreasedRegion
6700     */
6701    public GreasedRegion deteriorate(RandomnessSource rng, int preservation) {
6702        if(rng == null || width <= 2 || ySections <= 0 || preservation <= 0)
6703            return this;
6704        long mash;
6705        for (int i = 0; i < width * ySections; i++) {
6706            mash = rng.nextLong();
6707            for (int j = i; j < preservation; j++) {
6708                mash |= rng.nextLong();
6709            }
6710            data[i] &= mash;
6711        }
6712        tallied = false;
6713        return this;
6714    }
6715
6716    /**
6717     * Randomly removes points from a GreasedRegion, with preservation as a fraction between 1.0 (keep all) and 0.0
6718     * (remove all). If preservation is 0.5, roughly 1/2 of all points will be removed; if 0.25, roughly 3/4 will be
6719     * removed (roughly 0.25 will be _kept_), if 0.8, roughly 1/5 will be removed (and about 0.8 will be kept), and so
6720     * on. Preservation must be between 0.0 and 1.0 for this to have the intended behavior; 1.0 or higher will keep all
6721     * points without change (returning this GreasedRegion), while anything less than 0.015625 (1.0/64) will empty this
6722     * GreasedRegion (using {@link #empty()}) and then return it. The parameter {@code random} can be an object like a
6723     * {@link DiverRNG}, an {@link RNG} backed by a well-distributed RandomnessSource like its default, DiverRNG, a
6724     * {@link GWTRNG} (especially if you target GWT, where it will perform much better than most alternatives), or any
6725     * of various other RandomnessSource implementations that distribute bits well for
6726     * {@link RandomnessSource#nextLong()}, but should not be intentionally-biased RNGs like {@link DharmaRNG} or 
6727     * {@link EditRNG}, nor double-based QRNGs like {@link VanDerCorputQRNG} or {@link SobolQRNG}.
6728     * @param random used to determine random factors; likely to be an {@link RNG}, {@link DiverRNG}, or {@link GWTRNG}
6729     * @param preservation the rough fraction of points to keep, between 0.0 and 1.0
6730     * @return a randomly modified change to this GreasedRegion
6731     */
6732    public GreasedRegion deteriorate(final RandomnessSource random, final double preservation) {
6733        if(random == null || width <= 2 || ySections <= 0 || preservation >= 1)
6734            return this;
6735        if(preservation <= 0)
6736            return empty();
6737        int bitCount = (int) (preservation * 64);
6738        for (int i = 0; i < width * ySections; i++) {
6739            data[i] &= approximateBits(random, bitCount);
6740        }
6741        tallied = false;
6742        return this;
6743    }
6744
6745    /**
6746     * Inverts the on/off state of the cell with the given x and y.
6747     * @param x the x position of the cell to flip
6748     * @param y the y position of the cell to flip
6749     * @return this for chaining, modified
6750     */
6751    public GreasedRegion flip(int x, int y) {
6752        if(x >= 0 && y >= 0 && x < width && y < height && ySections > 0)
6753        {
6754            data[x * ySections + (y >> 6)] ^= (1L << (y & 63));
6755            tallied = false;
6756        }
6757        return this;
6758
6759    }
6760
6761    /**
6762     * Returns a new GreasedRegion that has been mirrored along the rightmost edge, parallel to the y-axis. The new
6763     * GreasedRegion will have exactly twice the width, the additional width will have the contents of the original
6764     * GreasesRegion in reversed order. The positions shared by both GreasedRegions will be the same, that is, any area
6765     * not added to the original will be equal to the original.
6766     * @return a new GreasedRegion with twice the width of {@code this}, that is mirrored along the rightmost edge
6767     */
6768    public GreasedRegion mirrorY()
6769    {
6770        GreasedRegion next = new GreasedRegion(data, width, height, width * 2, height);
6771        for (int i = 0, o = width * 2 - 1; i < width; i++, o--) {
6772            System.arraycopy(data, ySections * i, next.data, ySections * o, ySections);
6773        }
6774        return next;
6775    }
6776
6777    @Override
6778    public boolean intersectsWith(Zone other) {
6779        if (other instanceof GreasedRegion)
6780            return intersects((GreasedRegion) other);
6781        long t, w;
6782        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
6783            for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
6784                if ((t = data[x * ySections + s]) != 0) {
6785                    w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
6786                    while (w != 0) {
6787                        if (other.contains(x, (s << 6) | Long.numberOfTrailingZeros(w)))
6788                            return true;
6789                        t ^= w;
6790                        w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
6791                    }
6792                }
6793            }
6794        }
6795        return false;
6796    }
6797    /**
6798     * Translates a copy of {@code this} by the x,y values in {@code c}.
6799     * Implemented with {@code return copy().translate(c.x, c.y);}
6800     * @return {@code this} copied and shifted by {@code (c.x,c.y)}
6801     */
6802    @Override
6803    public GreasedRegion translate(Coord c) {
6804        return copy().translate(c.x, c.y);
6805    }

6809     * methods in CoordPacker and GreasedRegion, but guaranteed to use 8-way
6810     * adjacency and to return a new Collection of Coord. This implementation returns

6821     * Gets a new Zone that contains all the Coords in {@code this} plus all
6822     * neighboring Coords, which can be orthogonally or diagonally adjacent
6823     * to any Coord this has in it. Related to the expand() methods in
6824     * CoordPacker and GreasedRegion, but guaranteed to use 8-way adjacency
6825     * and to return a new Zone. This implementation returns a GreasedRegion
6826     * produced simply by {@code return copy().expand8way();} .
6827     * @return A new GreasedRegion where "off" cells adjacent to {@code this}
6828     *         (orthogonally or diagonally) have been added to the "on" cells

6831    @Override

6836    /**
6837     * Checks if {@code c} is present in this GreasedRegion. Returns true if and only if c is present in this
6838     * GreasedRegion as an "on" cell. This will never be true if c is null, has negative x or y, has a value for x that
6839     * is equal to or greater than {@link #width}, or has a value for y that is equal to or greater than
6840     * {@link #height}, but none of those conditions will cause Exceptions to be thrown.
6841     * @param c a Coord to try to find in this GreasedRegion; if null this will always return false
6842     * @return true if {@code c} is an "on" cell in this GreasedRegion, or false otherwise, including if c is null
6843     */
6844    @Override
6845    public boolean contains(Coord c) {
6846        return c != null && contains(c.x, c.y);
6847    }

6849    /**
6850     * Checks whether all Coords in {@code other} are also present in {@code this}.
6851     * Requires that {@code other} won't give a null Coord while this method iterates over it.
6852     * @param other another Zone, such as a GreasedRegion or a {@link squidpony.squidgrid.zone.CoordPackerZone}
6853     * @return true if all Coords in other are "on" in this GreasedRegion, or false otherwise
6854     */
6855    @Override
6856    public boolean contains(Zone other) {
6857        if(other instanceof Collection)
6858            return containsAll((Collection) other);
6859        for(Coord c : other)
6860        {
6861            if(!contains(c.x, c.y))
6862                return false;
6863        }
6864        return true;
6865    }

6867    /**
6868     * @param findSmallest if true, finds the smallest x-coordinate value;
6869     *                          if false, finds the biggest.
6870     * @return The x-coordinate of the Coord within {@code this} that has the
6871     * smallest (or biggest) x-coordinate. Or -1 if the zone is empty.
6872     */
6873    @Override
6874    public int xBound(boolean findSmallest) {
6875        if(findSmallest)
6876            return first().x;
6877        else
6878            return last().x;
6879    }
6880
6881    /**
6882     * @param findSmallest if true, finds the smallest y-coordinate value;
6883     *                          if false, finds the biggest.
6884     * @return The y-coordinate of the Coord within {@code this} that has the
6885     * smallest (or biggest) y-coordinate. Or -1 if the zone is empty.
6886     */
6887    @Override
6888    public int yBound(boolean findSmallest) {
6889        long t = 0L;
6890        if(findSmallest) {
6891            for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
6892                for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
6893                    t |= data[x * ySections + s];
6894                }
6895                if(t != 0L)
6896                    return s << 6 | Long.numberOfTrailingZeros(t);
6897            }
6898            return -1;
6899        }
6900        else
6901        {
6902            for (int s = ySections - 1; s >= 0; s--) {
6903                for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
6904                    t |= data[x * ySections + s];
6905                }
6906                if(t != 0L)
6907                    return s << 6 | 63 - Long.numberOfLeadingZeros(t);
6908            }
6909            return -1;
6910        }
6911    }

6913    /**
6914     * Gets the distance between the minimum x-value contained in this GreasedRegion and the maximum x-value in it.
6915     * Not the same as accessing the field {@link #width} on a GreasedRegion! The field will get the span of the space
6916     * that the GreasedRegion can use, including "on" and "off" cells. This method will only get the distance between
6917     * the furthest-separated "on" cells on the x-axis, and won't consider "off" cells. This method can return -1 if the
6918     * GreasedRegion is empty, 0 if the "on" cells are all in a vertical line (that is, when the minimum x is equal to
6919     * the maximum x), or a positive int in other cases with multiple x-values.
6920     * @return the distance on the x-axis between the "on" cell with the lowest x-value and the one with the highest
6921     */
6922    @Override
6923    public int getWidth() {
6924        if (super.width == -2)
6925            super.width = isEmpty() ? -1 : xBound(false) - xBound(true);
6926        return super.width;
6927    }
6928    /**
6929     * Gets the distance between the minimum y-value contained in this GreasedRegion and the maximum y-value in it.
6930     * Not the same as accessing the field {@link #height} on a GreasedRegion! The field will get the span of the space
6931     * that the GreasedRegion can use, including "on" and "off" cells. This method will only get the distance between
6932     * the furthest-separated "on" cells on the y-axis, and won't consider "off" cells. This method can return -1 if the
6933     * GreasedRegion is empty, 0 if the "on" cells are all in a horizontal line (that is, when the minimum y is equal to
6934     * the maximum y), or a positive int in other cases with multiple y-values.
6935     * @return the distance on the y-axis between the "on" cell with the lowest y-value and the one with the highest
6936     */
6937    @Override
6938    public int getHeight() {
6939        if (super.height == -2)
6940            super.height = isEmpty() ? -1 : yBound(false) - yBound(true);
6941        return super.height;
6942    }
6943
6944    /**
6945     * Gets the diagonal distance from the point combining the lowest x-value present in this GreasedRegion with the
6946     * lowest y-value in this, to the point combining the highest x-value and the highest y-value. These minimum and
6947     * maximum values don't necessarily match a single "on" cell for each min and max corner, and can take their x and y
6948     * values from two different points. The diagonal distance uses Euclidean measurement (basic Pythagorean Theorem
6949     * math here), and will be a double.
6950     * @return the diagonal distance from (min x, min y) to (max x, max y), as a double
6951     */
6952    @Override
6953    public double getDiagonal() {
6954        final int w = getWidth();
6955        final int h = getHeight();
6956        return Math.sqrt((w * w) + (h * h));
6957    }

6969    /**
6970     * Gets a Coord array from the "on" contents of this GreasedRegion, using a deterministic but random-seeming
6971     * scattering of chosen cells with a count that matches the given {@code fraction} of the total amount of "on" cells
6972     * in this. This is pseudo-random with the given seed (which will be made into an odd number if it is not one
6973     * already), and is very good at avoiding overlap (just as good as {@link #separatedZCurve(double, int)}, and
6974     * much faster). If you request too many cells (too high of a value for fraction), it will start to overlap, but
6975     * a fraction value of 0.4 reliably has had no overlap in testing. Restricts the total size of the returned array to
6976     * a maximum of {@code limit} (minimum is 0 if no cells are "on"). If limit is negative, this will not restrict the
6977     * size.
6978     * @param fraction the fraction of "on" cells to randomly select, between 0.0 and 1.0
6979     * @param limit the maximum size of the array to return
6980     * @param seed a long seed to change the points; the most significant 21 bits (except the sign bit) and least significant bit are ignored
6981     * @return a freshly-allocated Coord array containing the pseudo-random cells
6982     */
6983    public Coord[] mixedRandomSeparatedAlt(double fraction, int limit, long seed)
6984    {
6985        if(fraction < 0)
6986            return new Coord[0];
6987        if(fraction > 1)
6988            fraction = 1;
6989        int tmp, ic;
6990        long t, w;
6991        seed |= 1L;
6992        final int total = size();
6993        int ct = (int)(total * fraction);
6994        if(limit >= 0 && limit < ct)
6995            ct = limit;
6996        Coord[] vl = new Coord[ct];
6997        EACH_QUASI:
6998        for (int i = 0; i < ct; i++)
6999        {
7000            tmp = (int)(VanDerCorputQRNG.altDetermine(seed, i+1) * total);
7001
7002            for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
7003                for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
7004                    if ((ic = counts[x * ySections + s]) > tmp) {
7005                        t = data[x * ySections + s];
7006                        for (--ic; t != 0; ic--) {
7007                            w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
7008                            if (ic == tmp)
7009                            {
7010                                vl[i] = Coord.get(x, (s << 6) | Long.bitCount(w-1));
7011                                continue EACH_QUASI;
7012                            }
7013                            t ^= w;
7014                        }
7015                    }
7016                }
7017            }
7018        }
7019        return vl;
7020    }
7021

7023    public class GRIterator implements Iterator<Coord>
7024    {
7025        public int index = 0;
7026        private long t, w;
7027        public GRIterator()
7028        {
7029            if(!tallied)
7030                tally();
7031        }
7032        @Override
7033        public boolean hasNext() {
7034            return index < ct;
7035        }
7036
7037        @Override
7038        public Coord next() {
7039            int c;
7040            if(index >= ct)
7041                return null;
7042            for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
7043                for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
7044                    if ((c = counts[x * ySections + s]) > index) {
7045                        t = data[x * ySections + s] | 0L;
7046                        for (--c; t != 0; c--) {
7047                            w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(t);
7048                            if (c == index)
7049                            {
7050                                index++;
7051                                return Coord.get(x, (s << 6) | Long.bitCount(w-1));
7052                            }
7053                            t ^= w;
7054                        }
7055                    }
7056                }
7057            }
7058            return null;
7059
7060            /*
7061            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
7062                for (int s = 0; s < ySections; s++) {
7063                    if ((w = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(data[x * ySections + s])) != 0 && i++ >= index) {
7064                        if(index++ < limit)
7065                            return Coord.get(x, (s << 6) | Long.numberOfTrailingZeros(w));
7066                        else
7067                            return null;
7068                    }
7069                }
7070            }
7071            */
7072        }
7073
7074        @Override
7075        public void remove() {
7076            throw new UnsupportedOperationException("remove() is not supported on this Iterator.");
7077        }
7078    }
